name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President Anastasiades, thank you for coming to Strasbourg for this debate on the future of the European Union. It is important for us to know the position of your country and your personal position on the future of our continent and of our institutions. This Parliament is the heart of democracy, and we want to have an open debate with European leaders on our future. But today is a very difficult day for everyone in Europe.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate with the President of the Republic of Cyprus, Nicos Anastasiades, on the future of Europe (2018/2797(RSP)).

name: Νίκος Αναστασιάδης
text: President of Cyprus. Mr President of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, Allow me first to condemn in the strongest terms the terrorist attack that took place yesterday here in Strasbourg. I express my deepest sympathy and condolences to the families, and wish a speedy and full recovery to those who were injured.  Terrorism constitutes one of the more serious threats to the peace and security of our Union. We shall not allow fear and terror to prevail. Instead, we shall remain united in enhancing our efforts to eliminate this deplorable phenomenon. Mr President, it is a high honour for me to address the plenary session of the European Parliament in the presence of the Presidents of the EU political institutions and before the European citizens, and to have the opportunity to present my thoughts and ideas, but most of all, my vision for the future of the Union. I do so, ladies and gentlemen, with full conscience that I am addressing the institution and symbol, if you will, of the heart of democratic Europe, which embodies the timeless principles and values that permeate the becoming of the great common European family. As the European Parliament, you are one of the main pillars and actors in ensuring the democratic functioning of the Union, which is why your role is and will remain crucial.  Ladies and gentlemen, for Cyprus and its people, its accession to the European Union in 2004 was a seal of a European orientation but also of a millennial identity. It was strongly supported by the Cypriots not only as a source of stability and a prospect of prosperity but also as a potential catalyst in the ongoing efforts to reunite and consolidate security and peace in my country.  I would like to stress that Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots, in 2004, have identical their own future to the future of Europe, in the belief that soon the same conditions of normality, peace and security prevailing in the other Member States would prevail in our country. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's Europe was founded on the horrors of two world wars as a result of collective conscience and responsibility of bold leaders who believed in cooperation and unity. Their aim was economic cooperation in principle, but in evolution the safeguarding of human rights, the rule of law, the well-being and security of citizens through economic integration and the establishment of the four basic freedoms. In order to achieve these objectives with collective, hard work and work, the Union has emerged as the most remarkable model of peace and prosperity in modern history, a model that we must preserve and strengthen, and it is really with great anxiety that we are following the latest developments and trends that tend to shake the unity that has distinguished the Union for years. Developments and trends such as the withdrawal of a Member State from the European Union, the closure of borders in violation of the Schengen Treaty, the revival of nationalist tendencies, the obsolescence of the role played by the Union through the rise of populism and, as they see fit, exacerbating the phenomenon of terrorism, such as what we unfortunately experienced yesterday, I think we should be deeply concerned about. These are phenomena that we collectively have to deal with in order to protect geographical, political and economic unity, that is, the European integration for which you have worked hard.  Ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker had presented an ambitious programme for the mandate of this Commission with a view to the next European elections, which are now approaching. Cyprus as a strong supporter of a stronger, more democratic and more united Europe has been and remains a helper in the implementation of this programme. In this context, the ongoing consultation concerns our future, the future of Europe. It is a first-class opportunity to listen to civil society so that we are better able to assess effectiveness and to redefine our policies in a targeted way, to make them more beneficial to citizens. We need to listen to the citizens in order to understand the root causes of the obsolescence expressed as an indication of the high abstention rate in the European elections and to understand the reasons for the gap and the crisis of confidence.  Ladies and gentlemen, the consultation on the future of Europe in each Member State should be based in my view on the following questions: Which Europe do we want but also what lessons are we learning from Europe's progress so far? What is it that we need to improve and how? How close are we to the citizens? What are the root causes of the growing current of nationalist and populist movements and how could this phenomenon be treated? How are growing social and economic inequalities in Europe addressed? In my view, there is now an urgent need for clear answers in the context of sincere self-criticism, reflection and ultimately reordering, so that we can understand what we have failed and what we should do better so that the citizen can re-trust the Union and its institutions. To feel safe again, convinced that all challenges are faced, to experience in his daily life the positive impact of common policies in areas such as health, the environment, working conditions, areas that affect the problems of daily life and the well-being of citizens.  Mr President, there is no way that the European Union is a mosaic of states and peoples, the beauty and value of which results from composition and diversity. Each piece has its own value, less or greater, as well as has its own peculiarities.  The mosaic remains in any case incomplete, when even the smallest part is absent from it. Therefore, power and value lie in composition and unity. This is what our cooperation is based on: unity and solidarity.   Ladies and gentlemen, in 2013, when I took over the presidency of the state, I was faced with painful dilemmas. Cyprus has faced a strong economic crisis, which, given the size and nature of its economy, has adversely affected the majority of its citizens.  By taking difficult but necessary decisions with concrete and coherent measures and supporting Cypriot society, which has experienced economic consequences comparable to those that followed the 1974 invasion, we have implemented substantial sections and reforms that have enabled our economic reconstruction sooner than even the most optimistic would expect.  An epigrammatic reference to the positive results achieved by the Cypriot economy in recent years vindicates the series of responsibility decisions we have taken as a government. Among other things, I could briefly mention the exit from the economic adjustment programme, and in a shorter period than the international community expected, continuous upgrades from the rating agencies and the reintegration of Cyprus into the investment tier, Cyprus' exit to the international markets, for the fourth consecutive year a positive growth rate of close to 4% is recorded, a continuous downward trend in unemployment recording the highest annual decrease among Member States and , for the fifth year in a row, we are now projected to have an asthmatic budget.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are committed and determined to maintain macroeconomic stability, to broaden the conditions under which the surplus and high growth rates have occurred and to give further impetus to the excellent prospects created for the main productive sectors.  It is in exactly the same spirit that we are moving forward with regard to the European Union budget, the ongoing negotiations on the new multiannual financial framework for 2021-2027, which must reflect the growth path that Europe has entered after a difficult decade as a result of the global economic crisis.  We want an ambitious budget that includes those necessary costs to address modern social challenges; challenges involving a wide range of key areas such as the transition to digital integration, promoting sustainable development, climate change, innovation, migration, the rise of extreme nationalism, asymmetric threats and the fight against terrorism. At the same time, the new multiannual financial framework must focus on people, focus on the European citizen and improve his quality of life. Through cost rationalisation and proper planning to make sure that European taxpayer's money is spent on targeted policies and is in no way wasted, it is not wasted on inefficient programmes. The new budget, now that we will be a Europe of 27, must be properly adapted but also flexible and balance between our traditional policies and modern needs. In this context, i.e. closer economic understanding, we must seek to complete the banking union project in the light of a renewed monetary and economic union and to promote the capital markets union which will mobilise capital for investment in the Member States.  Mr President, there is no doubt that the common market, which has recently reached its 25th birthday, is one of the most important achievements of the European Union. The long-term objective of defending the acquis of the common market requires all those, all the necessary measures in order to achieve adaptation to the new data, as they have been developed in the meantime, in order to fully respond to the modern needs of the digital age, to the challenges of the low energy footprint of a circular economy and above all to have a positive impact on the daily lives of its citizens. I look forward to tomorrow's debate on these issues during the work of the European Council, from which I expect a strong commitment to a strengthened common market for the future. Ladies and gentlemen, as we move from soft power to the Union's common defence armour, it is a fact that much has been achieved with the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon. Clearly there is room for further improvements, always in a climate of consensus and respect for the particular sensitivities of each Member State. Any differentiation in the way decisions are taken in the field of defence, I believe, would be counterproductive in terms of the necessary convergences. Cyprus has been and continues to be a strong supporter of the ever-increasing defence and military cooperation between Member States. It is one of those countries which have expressed from the outlying the desire to join permanent structured cooperation, known as PESCO. Although we recognise PESCO as a decisive step, our vision remains the military self-determination of Europe. The creation of a Euro-army, a body of power that will protect the Union's borders and operate – and I would like to emphasise this – always dissuasive and defensive and not aggressively in the interests of the European Union. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would then like to refer to some external factors, but which undermine the cohesion of the European Union, factors which, in my view, must be tackled with determination in a climate of unity and solidarity. The unprecedented humanitarian crisis that we have faced in recent years primarily imposes the need to set aside different approaches and narrow nationalist priorities.  The southern neighbourhood of Europe is facing massive migratory flows and the burden is disproportionate to the Member States, especially the front line, among them I must admit our country, which has recently been under increasing excessive migratory pressure, so that it is now at the top of the host countries for political asylum seekers, always in proportion to the population of course. Additional reasons that exacerbate the problem in Cyprus are on the one hand the dividing line between free and occupied areas and on the other hand Turkey's continued refusal not only to recognise the Republic of Cyprus but also to implement the agreements it has concluded with the European Union, such as the readmission agreement. It does not even cooperate with the Cypriot authorities, because it considers, otherwise a candidate country, that the Republic of Cyprus, a Member State of the European Union, is deceased. I would say more generally with regard to the system that an immediate review of the common European asylum system and the Dublin regulations is needed for a fairer distribution of the migrant and refugee burden between the Member States, as this is now absolutely necessary. Another challenge we face, ladies and gentlemen, is that of climate change. Our commitment to the Paris Agreement and to systematic and coordinated action for a more ambitious policy at the ongoing summit in Katowice, Poland, is imperative. If we underestimate the visible risks, the consequences will unfortunately be dramatic not only for the ecosystem but also for the economy and, as you all understand, for the daily lives of our fellow citizens.  In the context of the wider regional role we are developing and the tripartite cooperation, it is our intention to take on a coordinating role at regional level to address the consequences of climate change and related synergies with countries in the region. As you are well aware, the Eastern Mediterranean region is one of those regions which has already had a profound impact on environmental change.  Mr President, the most substantial challenge in the Union's long history is the Decision of the United Kingdom to withdraw, with the result that for the first time the 27 are called upon to manage such a project. Respect for the decision of the British people was of course the only option. As the European Union we negotiated with seriousness and unity, supporting Michel Barnier's team, which prepared the web of principles that will allow the United Kingdom to leave the Union as smoothly as possible. We are – I must say – completely satisfied with the overall outcome of the negotiations. We support a broad and multi-layered relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union and in this direction we will continue to work. The new relationship must be mutually beneficial, in full harmony with the principles of the European Union, its intersection and its autonomy.  With regard to the British bases in Cyprus, we are also pleased, since we have ensured what we had set ourselves from the outset, namely the uninterrupted continuation of the implementation of the European acquis, so that all European citizens residing on the British bases benefit from the privileges of the European acquis and continue to enjoy the rights and benefits of the Union.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as Cyprus we want through our actions to contribute to a strong and united European Union that promotes peace, stability, security, solidarity and the well-being of the peoples who make up its unique mosaic.  In this context, building on our geographical position and excellent relations with neighbouring peoples, we have developed actions and synergies in the Eastern Mediterranean area in recent years. In an unstable region we have methodically established, together with Greece, tripartite cooperation mechanisms with countries in the region such as Egypt, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon and Palestine on the basis of international law and on the values of mutual respect and solidarity.  On the recommendation of the Cypriot Government, our proposal to set up a permanent tripartite secretariat based in Cyprus has been approved, in order to make the coordination between us more effective as well as the continuous monitoring and evaluation of the progress of these partnerships. The institutionalisation of tripartite cooperation is also proving to be particularly beneficial for the European Union, particularly in the energy sector, contributing to the desired energy security and diversification of the Union's energy sources and supply corridors.  It is also very important that the European Union remains clearly in solidarity with the Republic of Cyprus in the exercise of its sovereign rights to research and exploit its natural resources within the exclusive economic zone, while consistently and consistently pointing out the avoidance of any threats or destabilising actions incompatible with what international law and European law dictate. Ladies and gentlemen, in the introductory part of my address I pointed out that the Cypriots identified, at the time of Cyprus' accession to the European Union, their own future with the future of the Union and the other European citizens. They expected that integration would have a catalytic role and give them the same rights and the same level of respect for their fundamental freedoms as other European citizens enjoyed and enjoyed in their countries without dividing lines, without guaranteeing and invasive rights of third parties, in the presence of an occupying army and restrictions on basic freedoms. I often refer to my vision of a Cyprus beacon of stability in the Eastern Mediterranean region. Realistically speaking, ladies and gentlemen, we know that the light of this lighthouse will fall short of its potential maximum power as long as Cyprus remains divided.  Sometimes the current challenges, ladies and gentlemen, make us forget great historical truths, but the problem of Cyprus remains basically a problem of foreign invasion and occupation and violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms, since in 1974 more than a third of the population of Cyprus was forced to appeal to its own country. At a time when the Union is dealing with the management of new tragic wars that have resulted in millions of people being brought in, the refugees of Cyprus continue to be de-disabled of their basic freedoms, unable to enjoy their property peacefully and live in their homes, as they have every right.  While we are discussing our future, the future of Europe, for Cypriot citizens, even these four basic freedoms – self-evident for all other European citizens – are a difficult task to achieve.  The Chair and the members of the Committee on Petitions of the European Parliament are fully aware of the realities and allow me here to express on behalf of all Cypriots thanks and satisfaction for the response of the committee and its action especially with regard to the enclosed city of Famagusta.  I could only agree with the conclusions of the report in particular by saying that the return of varosians to their legal inhabitants would be the ideal model of confidence-building measures, a model of coexistence and cooperation between Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots. An excellent precursor – if you will – of the overall solution.  I would also remind you that in 1984 and 1992 the international community through the United Nations Security Council and Resolutions 550 and 789 called for the transfer of the administration of the region concerned, which is under Turkish occupation, to the responsibility of the United Nations. Unfortunately, this was not possible because of Ankara's attitude.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe, which is rightly involved in or taking initiatives to solve international problems, is of the opinion that it has a moral duty to contribute to solving a problem of a Member State. A problem that is an open wound in her own body. Healing this wound will strengthen the Union not only morally but also substantially, since only then will Cyprus be able to play its full potential in a region that is particularly important to the interests of the Union. What I want to assure the Members of the European Parliament is the will and determination to work hard to achieve a solution that does not create winners or leaves losers, a solution that fully respects the expectations and concerns of Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots, that creates a functioning and sustainable federal state, on the basis of UN Security Council resolutions. , from time to time agreements between the leaders of the two communities, a sovereign and independent State, free from any third-party dependencies through invasive or guarantee rights or occupation armies. A European state whose structure, institutions and functions are fully in line with European principles and values.  That is why we support in every way the efforts of the Secretary-General of the United Nations and his special envoy, in the hope that very soon those conditions will be created that will return us to the negotiating table, to the bank of an agreed framework and the conditions of reference under way with a view to a comprehensive solution and the reunification of the homeland.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it would be an incomparable omission if, on the occasion given to me today, I did not express the grateful thanks of the Cypriot people, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots, to the European Parliament for their full support for our efforts to find a peaceful solution in a European state.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in conclusion I would once again like to thank you for the opportunity you have given me to develop my vision for the future of Europe, how we Cypriots view the European Union. There are many, friends and friends, challenges and justifiably high expectations of us. But there are all the necessary ingredients and guarantees, as long as we remain in solidarity and respect for the core values that the Union has long advocated. We are the continuators of the original vision of a strong and prosperous Europe, not only to preserve our precious mosaic but to highlight it further. It is for this prosperous Europe that we must join forces, leaving aside different approaches and narrow national interests, in order to effectively address the common challenges. Only in this way can we achieve a bright future for the Union and for its citizens. Thank you very much. (applause)

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, President Anastasiades, our thoughts and hearts are with the victims of last night’s horrible attack against humanity. This we condemn with great firmness. We are grateful for the tireless work of the first responders, and we trust in the work of the law enforcement services to bring those responsible to justice. We will continue to defend our free and open societies by all means available to us. The city of Strasbourg is a symbol of European peace and democracy: values that we will always defend. The European Commission stands alongside France and the French people at this very difficult moment. Honourable Members, I wished we had a better situation to talk about the future of Europe than where we are today. Nevertheless, we cannot give up. We need to continue building a better and safer Europe for our citizens. Intolerance and hate don’t belong in our societies, and they don’t represent our values. I want to thank Mr President, my good friend Nicos, for being here today to debate the future of Europe. I remember when we talked about the future of the EU in the Prime Minister’s office in Finland many years back. We have continued this discussion during all these years, and now we are here in the European Parliament to discuss with you, honourable Members, the challenges, opportunities and direction of the European Union. Mr President, you and your country has always shown a great European solidarity. You have shown this time and again over the years. When it comes to migration, you have always been there and taken much more than your fair share of responsibility. The financial economic crisis also hit Cyprus harder than most. The effects will not go away overnight, but today I see a recovering labour market and economy – growing by over 4% in 2017 and continuing at an impressive rate this year. I see a more stable financial sector with a lower – although still too high – rate of non-performing loans. I see also investment returning thanks, in part, to the Juncker Plan, which has helped trigger EUR 109 million of additional investment. It has also supported 124 smaller companies, or start-ups, to grow and create jobs locally. I will visit Cyprus at the end of January to discuss further use of the Juncker Plan in order to help boost growth and job creation. But if the situation has turned around, it is because of the strength and hard work of the Cypriot people. I want to pay tribute to them in particular, for everything they have done. I also want to pay tribute to you, Mr President, dear Nicos, for your commitment to the programme of recovery. Tough decisions made and the commitment to making them work should never be overlooked by anyone in Europe. We know there’s still a long way to go and the Commission will assist you every step of the way, including through tailored support offered by a structural reform support service. It has already provided EUR 520 million to support the economic integration of the island and improve links and contacts between its two communities. But it also continues to support Cyprus across the board, including meeting its climate and energy costs. The point is that as we look to the future, Europe will stand in solidarity with Cyprus, just as Cyprus has always stood in solidarity with Europe. And nowhere is that more important than when it comes to bringing to an end the division of the island. The Commission will stand ready to assist any efforts. The Commission will always answer your call to support any negotiations or discussions held under the auspices of the United Nations that work towards a fair, comprehensive and viable settlement. This would be beneficial for Cyprus, for Europe and for the wider security and stability in the region. There would be no more important message for our common future. But we must prepare that future as of today. Later this week, European leaders, including the President, will have a real discussion on our future long-term budget. This is not about numbers or figures only; it is about our future. It is about deciding what Europe should achieve, and it is about deciding where to invest in our future, on the issues that matter to most to the people of Cyprus and the whole of Europe. This is why the Commission has put forward a fair, modern and balanced budget. A budget that is more efficient and more focused on the issues that matter to most – just as Cyprus has all along been calling for. For instance, there will be an almost three-fold increase in funding for migration and security, to make sure that Europe can protect its citizens. This will be especially important for Cyprus, as a country that has taken so much responsibility in this area. Funding for research and innovation will be increased by 50%. We have also proposed to double the means of Erasmus+ and a new Digital Europe programme worth EUR 9 billion will support Europe’s digital transformation. All of these will provide real opportunities for Cypriots and further boost the productivity of the Cypriot economy. We have also proposed an enhanced reform support programme with EUR 22 billion earmarked for key reforms identified in the European Semester. All of this will make a real difference on the ground in Cyprus and across our Union. So it is crucially important that we can agree on our new budget as swiftly as possible. Mr President, I count on your support, your counterparts’ support, and this House’s support, in order to make all this happen.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: im Namen der PPE-Fraktion. – Meine Herren Präsidenten, sehr geehrter Präsident Anastasiades! Eine schreckliche Nacht liegt hinter uns. Ich möchte zunächst Dank sagen, Herr Präsident Tajani, bei Ihnen für die Abläufe, für das Management in dieser schwierigen Nacht für uns. Sie haben das Parlament hier stark geführt. Und ich möchte auch den Mitarbeitern ein herzliches Dankeschön sagen, weil die Versorgung im Haus sichergestellt worden ist und die Fahrer gearbeitet haben in der Nacht. Alle waren bereit, in dieser schwierigen Situation Verantwortung zu übernehmen. Und deswegen: Lassen Sie ein herzliches Dankeschön auch an die Mitarbeiter des Hauses ausrichten. (Beifall) Meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren! Der Tag erinnert uns an unsere Werte, an das friedliche Miteinander auf diesem Kontinent. In dieser Nacht und in diesen Stunden sind wir vor allem Demokraten. Europa ist für uns der Kontinent der Freiheit, den es zu verteidigen gilt. Deswegen muss angesichts der schrecklichen Vorkommnisse der letzten Stunden eines politisch klargestellt werden: dass wir uns nicht von Radikalen aufhetzen lassen, dass es nicht um die Chance geht, Hass zu säen, dass es keinen Kampf der Kulturen gibt. Es gibt keinen Kampf der Religionen, sondern was es gibt, ist ein Aufstehen der Humanität gegen verblendete Verbrecher. Wir dürfen nicht zulassen, dass Hass gesät wird. (Beifall) The best answer we can give is what our President said: to continue our work. Tonight, we learned a lot about our identity, about freedom in the European Union. When we look to Cyprus, Mr President, we can learn a lot about our identity. Seventy-two per cent of your citizens in Cyprus feel like citizens of the European Union, so they feel at home in the European Union. Sometimes we probably make the mistake that we speak too much about the few anti—Europeans in Europe and we forget about the millions and millions of Europeans who really feel like Europeans, like your citizens in Cyprus. Even in difficult times, they continue to do so. Cyprus managed to overcome the euro crisis – Jyrki Katainen was referring to this. In only three years, Cyprus has completed the adjustment programme and GDP grew almost twice as much as in the Eurozone average in the last year. Today, Cyprus enjoys the highest government surplus in the European Union – 1.8% – and in the last year, the unemployment rate decreased from 10.5% to 7.5%. Twelve thousand Cypriots have found a job during the last years, in a small country that matters a lot. So congratulations, Mr President.  (Applause) It is the achievement of your country, and it is the achievement of you as the president of this country and your idea to have stability, to have the will for reforms and also the will for investment, which is exactly what Jyrki Katainen proposed for the future for the eurozone, to have positive economic development. What I want to underline is your readiness to take over responsibility. You didn’t blame Brussels for any kind of measures; you didn’t attack Brussels for any kind of activities, like so many other leaders in the European Union are doing every day. You took over responsibility, and that’s why I want really to congratulate you for the efforts you made.  The second point I want to underline is security. Cyprus is one of our smaller countries, and in your country’s geographical situation, it is important to talk about defence. That’s why I thank you so much for your clear commitment towards a strong pillar of defence for the European Union. My group is strongly supporting the idea of a cyber-security unit, and also of a unit for drone technologies, though especially in the modern forms of defence we have strongly to work together. And on the Turkey question, we know Turkey goes in the wrong direction: away from democracy, less freedom of press, less rule of law. Turkey is distancing itself from the values of the European Union, and that’s why I think it’s time to consider a new approach on the cooperation with Turkey. Take case by case relationships to open a door for the future. On the concrete Cyprus question, it’s clear for us that the interests of Cyprus are the interests of the European Union. Mr President, please pass a message in this question of Turkey: we all are Cypriots, we are backing the position of the Cypriot President. And on the Energy Union, as a final point, I want to underline that today we, as Europeans, are depending a lot on oil and gas from foreign sources. The efforts of Cyprus to find greater supply of natural gas would not only benefit your country, but also benefit the interests of the whole European Union. That’s why we, as Europeans, do not allow any forms of threat and blackmailing from our neighbours. We must stop, on the one hand, Nord Stream 2, which would make Europe more dependant on Russian gas. And on the other hand, we will not permit Turkey to slow down the Cypriots in their search for different energy sources. Cyprus can count on Europe in this concrete question. And for the conclusions, Cyprus is a small country, but it makes a difference in Europe. Many big Member States should take Cyprus as an example for the determination and for the courage you had and you showed. The people of Cyprus have to know that Europe is your safe home and Europe will stand beside you.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome President Anastasiades to the European Parliament, and I will start by reiterating what is most important. Cyprus is an important Member State of the European Union and the future of reform in a united, prosperous Europe depends on the success of Cyprus. The stability and security of all Member States and the well-being of European citizens, including all Greek and Turkish Cypriots, are a priority and should remain a priority for us. I was very hopeful the last time we met, Mr President, believing that, at a time when Europe was facing many challenges and disappointments, Cyprus would be a success story, that the Greek and Turkish Cypriots would be the ones to overcome divisions and hate. I must admit that the failure of the talks in Crans-Montana saddened all of us. My political group, the Socialists and Democrats, remains committed to the reunification of Cyprus, as, I believe, the European Parliament does. We are committed to a stable and lasting solution, based on EU values and on all EU and relevant resolutions, but, most of all, to a solution that benefits the citizens living in Cyprus, be they Greek or Turkish, who are worried about the current deadlock in the negotiations. And we call on you, Mr President, on your vision and on your courage, to overcome the deadlock and to explore any possibility of resuming talks and ensuring clear terms of reference that will enable swift results. I think this will be a major breakthrough, and the Cypriot people deserve that. The EU is ready to back you in all of these very difficult endeavours. I can assure you of my Group’s readiness to play the most constructive possible role in the future agreement on the reunification of Cyprus. That said, I would like to share with you some concerns. First on the economic situation of your country. In spite of the clear re-launching of economic growth in Cyprus – four percentage points is quite significant in comparison to the much lower and slower economic growth in other Member States – the Commission has reported that inequality is one of the most alarming factors. Inequality is rising not only in Cyprus but at EU level too, and the austerity policies of the last decade, and the Troika policy which played a devastating role in your country, have contributed to increasing the gap. Let’s try to reverse the trend. It is timely to work on fighting this, so let’s work together, in each and every Member State and at Union level, on the social model: on a fair Union that can face the challenges of populism and nationalism. It is true that nationalism and populism are on the rise, but let us tackle the poverty and inequality that constitute fertile ground for those extreme political trends. Mr President, I have a serious concern about something which is quite alarming for both security and social reasons, namely the ‘citizenship by investment’ programme. You are providing European citizenship to nationals of third countries and, looking at the breakdown of those who benefit from this programme, I think you should work on winding it down and stopping it – and this is not to intervene in any way in your internal decisions. Mr President, as a Romanian, and knowing that Romania will soon hold the rotating Council Presidency, I’m deeply convinced that full and sincere cooperation among all Member States will provide the future EU summit in Sibiu with a good result for Europe. The future of the Union is based, as you rightly said, on unity and solidarity: a future of the Union which diminishes frustrations and divisions and ensures, for all of us, that there will be no double standards in the Union. Thank you once again for your contribution. I am absolutely convinced that Cyprus will remain one of the most active contributors to unity and to a prosperous future in our Union. (Applause)

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioners, Your Excellency, you are president of a small island and remote state of the European Union and you manage the only weapon at its disposal: the identity of its existence, the title of the Republic of Cyprus. I will ask my major question from the outset, which is this: What future can the European Union have if it sacrifices a Member State, leaving it to become a Turkish protectorate for the benefit of economic interests and trade under a dictatorial regime.  Colleagues, territories of the Republic of Cyprus are held militarily by Turkey, which constantly threatens it and carries heavy weaponry to the occupied areas. Mr President, you have raised all the major issues that concern our country. I will not refer to them. I will confine myself only to the Cyprus issue, because your efforts to resolve the Cyprus issue have collapsed despite the goodwill you have shown, due to the aggressive and intransigent attitude of Turkey, whose objective remains full control of the land and sea area of the Republic of Cyprus, while the solution you have sought to date has proved impractical and unworkable and impractical.  Since 2004 the Republic of Cyprus has been a Member State of the European Union, and here the following questions are being asked: Why did the Republic of Cyprus not require the European Union to implement the provisions of the Treaties, the European acquis, the principles and values of the European Union, the Charter of Human Rights, the Accession Protocol, the Additional Protocol, the counter-declaration of 21 September 2005 , the resolution on Famagusta (The Written Declaration) and many other legal declarations that would shield the Republic of Cyprus and make the solution viable, fair and functional?  Why did the Republic of Cyprus never react when Turkey, by illegally, did not sign with Cyprus the Treaties it signed with the 27 Member States? Why did he not react when Tsavousoglou submitted a document to the Commission describing Cyprus as a deceased? Why did you accept the signing and updating of the European Union-Turkey Customs Union? Why did you accept the readmission agreement? Why did you accept the refugee agreement and many other treaties signed with the 27 Member States but not with the Republic of Cyprus? All these agreements apply to the detriment of the status of the Cypriot state and peace, since Turkey is not under any pressure to resolve the Cyprus problem. On the other hand, why does the European Union accept to talk and give billions to a dictatorial state, which is a candidate for membership of the European Union, while it holds part of European territory and does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus? Why does it apply conditions that are not signed with a Member State and do not interrupt accession? Why is it imposing sanctions on Russia for the integration of Crimea and leaving Turkey undisturbed while it holds a military member state?  The European Union must demand turkey's recognition of the Republic of Cyprus and respect for the rights of our state. The European Union cannot recognise the effects of the blind war violence of 1974 and accept the dissolution of the Republic of Cyprus. The solution must be based on the principles and values of the European Union and on the full implementation and full respect of the four basic freedoms, guaranteed by the democratic principles of the European Union. The European Union cannot allow Cyprus to be transformed into a Turkish protectorate. Thank you, Mr President, and welcome to the European Parliament.  I am very sorry that not all colleagues are here and would be if we did not have the false facts.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Mr Anastasiades, as Spanish and as representative of the ALDE Group I defend and defend the absolute and radical unity of the Republic of Cyprus. For me and the ALDE Group, there are no two communities, but a Cypriot European nation and compatriots. A single Republic of Cyprus.  But, Mr President, Cyprus has both internal and external pathology. When we talk about Cyprus has three guaranteeing countries — which are: Britain, about to leave the European Union; another outside the European Union, which is Turkey; and another that is within the European Union, which is Greece—what we see is a pathological situation that does not take place in any country in the world and is a consequence of a situation that you know, which is the horrible war of both liberation and independence and intercommunal warfare before 1960, with the situation of the EOKA and what you know. At the bloody Christmas of 1963, horrific events occurred in the two communities, and the Turkish community was removed from the institutions in 1964. The Republic of Cyprus has too many "taksim", it has too many "Megali Idea", too many ideas of "enosis" in the past. And it also has the story of Nikos Sampson's coup against President Makarios in 1974.  And what is a pathology, and I tell you from what I know, is that, for one part of the Cypriot community — and I am talking about the Cypriot community, a single Cyprus — there is an occupation, but for another part of that Cypriot community it is a guarantee. And that's pathological. Therefore, the first thing we have to raise is why all this exists and not simply to raise it as a question of metaphysical situation, but of real situation in the split society, divided and separate Cypriot. And this brings me to the following issues.  The first one. Nearly half a century, Mr. President, half a century, of two separate communities living back and back; they are generations that have not been known; generations who live looking the other way. This objectively means a situation of deepening social division, apart from geographical division. If we continue in the blocking situation, which is what is happening now, it will continue to delve into two social situations that will not be understood because they are not known.  The second one. And this brings me to politicians. Crans-Montana came very close to the agreement, but to what extent is there a lack of political decision? That decision made by a political leader, Winston Churchill, when he was able to take the risk of prioritizing the interests of the British nation and not the interests of its particular political interests. And in Crans-Montana, so close and so far. The next question is, therefore: when will Cypriot politicians understand that the nation is more important than its particular interests? The third concerns the objective situation. When you enter the Parliament of Cyprus, a part of Parliament is empty, it is that of your compatriots — my Fellow Turkish Cypriots Europeans - who are absent. Here, on the other hand, all the posts of the European Parliament are occupied, but they do not represent the entire Cypriot community, they represent one side, and that is also a pathological situation. And this brings me to the last question. Crans-Montana was so close and so far away that there is talk of a new agreement, a new understanding, a new encounter. Do you think that, with all the experiences of nearly fifty years of failed talks, the Annan plan, which got nowhere, will be worth a new meeting or serve to permanently maintain a division that decisively affects the national and economic future of the island as well? And so I am asking you, Mr President: wouldn't it be time for us, by abandoning external protectors, which are actually external blockers many times, to go to arbitration by the member countries of the European Union — from their European family — and end the pathology of the island of Cyprus?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, allow me on behalf of the Left Group to express our shock at yesterday's victims of the attack, to express our condolences to the family of the victims and our sympathy and solidarity with the city of Strasbourg and the entire French people. Mr President of the Republic of Cyprus, I welcome you from the European United Left/Northern Green Left to the European Parliament, transferring first of all the universal, timeless, undying support of our group in the struggle of Cyprus against occupation and division, for a solution of the Cyprus problem on the basis of un resolutions, international and European law, for the reunification of Cyprus on the basis of the solution of the bi-social bi-community federation, for a Cyprus without occupying armies and foreign guardians, common homeland of Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots. That is why, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, the Union has a responsibility, instead of discussing today the upgrading of the Customs Union with Turkey, to resolutely demand the implementation of Ankara's obligations, including the Cyprus obligations.  Mr President, if we are debating today with concern and fear about the future of Europe, it is because something has gone wrong with the past and the present of the Union, with the course it has taken, with the policies that dominate, because in previous years the anxieties of the people and the demands of the workers have not been heard. Only two years ago in this Chamber President Juncker was forced to admit that the European Union is losing its social character, that it is in danger of becoming the Wild West of social dumping. But he did not admit what policies led to it. The relentless truth is that the recipe for neoliberalism has been followed, with the result that European societies are reaping unemployment, poverty, regional and social inequalities, while at the same time it is these policies that are smoothing the ground for racism, xenophobia and fascism. Those who do not recognize the cause will obviously continue with the same recipes and on the same path.  Cyprus is unfortunately no exception. It is a prime example, because the memoranda expire but they don't actually go away. Their dramatic consequences have not only remained in society and in industrial relations in a number of Member States, but have now become pan-European laws within the framework of economic governance. What is remarkable is that your government, Mr President, is not only implementing these policies but is proving to be more neoliberal than neoliberals. What's the result? The growth you project is only for the benefit of the few. Unfortunately, our country is a champion in Europe in increasing income inequality and increasing poverty.  Let us not forget, moreover, that the two major financial crimes committed in recent years in Cyprus, the haircut of deposits in 2013 and the closure of the Co-operation, do not only have the stamp of the European Union; they are also your achievements, Mr President.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what Europe needs today is social justice and social solidarity. It needs an economy that works for the many, those who produce wealth, not for banks and multinationals.  Another path of growth that creates permanent full and decent jobs. To defend the public nature of each country's strategic sectors and services. Strengthen social protection for the weak and not distribute greetings without any binding force, such as the notorious European social pillar. The European Union needs a bold policy to tackle climate change outside market logic and more ambitious than the Paris agreement. When the citizens of the Union hear that EUR 38.5 billion will be given to the defence fund, they reasonably wonder how there can always be money for the war industries but never enough for social expenditure, education and health.  Finally, Europe needs an asylum and immigration policy based on international law, humanitarian solidarity with refugees and solidarity between Member States. Rightly, Mr President, Cyprus supports the need to create a permanent mechanism for hosting all refugees in all Member States according to their capabilities. But, Mr President, first of all you must put this request to the European People's Party, to those like-minded people who block this proposal, so that the countries of the Mediterranean South receive a disproportionate share of responsibility. Mr President, in order to do all this, we need other policies, or better yet we need another Europe, the Europe for which the Left is fighting, The Europe that resists and fights, the Europe of the peoples.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to join colleagues in expressing my solidarity with the victims of yesterday’s attack and their relatives. I would like to thank all the emergency services and everyone who helped yesterday in the city, as well as here in the European Parliament. President Anastasiades, thank you very much for joining us in this debate on the future of Europe. Cyprus is, of course, in a very difficult spot on the European map. Your island is still divided, and I want to applaud you for all the efforts that you have undertaken in the past to overcome this divide and to get closer together for a solution on the island, based on the UN parameters. But I am also worried that we haven’t seen much progress – any progress, really – on the talks recently. I would really like to urge you not to let this favourable political constellation pass  by, because we might not have that opportunity in a long time – we might never see it again. We have a once-in-a-lifetime chance to find that solution. And just as in Europe overall, a united Cyprus will be beneficial for all its citizens. The EU also needs to be there and ready to provide any help necessary to achieve a solution.  And you are in that unique situation right now to overcome the last divide in Europe, to bridge the last divided capital in Europe, and I wish you a lot of luck in dealing with that situation. But I’m also afraid that luck alone won’t be enough. It also needs common action by all of us. You are in a very unique spot, so it will need a lot of courage and a lot of action. President Anastasiades, I am very grateful that you brought up the issue of climate change. I  have to tell you that not many of your colleagues have done so before you, and of course Cyprus is also one of the countries that’s most affected by climate change in the European Union, even though none of us is going to be spared. We’ve seen desertification happening on the island, also extreme weather events. All those effects of climate change are very well known in Cyprus. Right now, we have the Climate Summit happening in Katowice, and the EU’s role in achieving a safeguard for our common planet is absolutely vital. But the EU can only be as strong as its members are – and are willing to be – so I’m asking you: what is your government strategy and concrete proposals to mitigate the impact of climate change in Cyprus? And what can you do in order to pressurise the other Member States to do their share as well, because not everyone is really helpful in doing so? And of course to put words into actions we also need exactly the money in the long term budget that Mr Katainen mentioned earlier. The MFF will be absolutely crucial in putting money behind words. Words alone are not enough, and we need to act now in order to save that planet, because we only have one. Cyprus would have a great potential, for example, for renewable energy. It could be a frontrunner in this regard, showing other Member States the way forward, showing the whole EU how it could be done, and it could also become a hotspot for the relevant technology – but only if your government is ready to do something for that.  Finally, I would like to stress that the future of Europe depends on all of us. It doesn’t only depend on big countries, some countries; it depends on all countries. It depends on all of us together – bigger or smaller countries, north or south, all Member States have a responsibility to bring Europe forward or it will not go forward. And we, in this House, also share that responsibility. No matter what party we are from, no matter which country we are from, the future of the European Union depends on all of us inside this House, but of course also on each and every citizen. And there are always many opponents and many obstacles and times are always difficult, but that can never be an excuse for concrete action.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, France, like other European countries, was struck again, bloodied, bereaved by terrorism, last night, right here in Strasbourg. On behalf of our europe of nations and freedoms group, I would like to express my condolences and solidarity with the victims, their families and loved ones. The fight against Islamist terrorism must be a top priority and we have the responsibility and the duty to give ourselves the means to wage this war that is being waged on us, and to win it. Mr President, since 1974, your country, Cyprus, has suffered a scandalous Turkish occupation over half of its territory. Yes, the invasion by the Turkish army and the ensuing occupation are scandalous, but who is still moved by it? The truth is that the European Union has never supported Cyprus against the Turks. On the contrary, it has been more than 30 years since Turkey entered into negotiations to join the European Union, having benefited from a particularly advantageous association agreement since 1963.  Each year, under the pre-accession appropriations, the European Union provides aid far in excess of those received by Member States such as Cyprus. Refusing any tussle with Erdogan, who dreams of a new Ottoman empire, the European institutions yield to all his demands, which are all whims of a spoiled child to whom one never knew how to say no. We swaggered when Turkey signed an agreement on migrants, but it was actually a new market of dupes. Turkey has pocketed a few billion from the generous Europeans, and the counterparties are obviously not up to scratch. That is clearly what we are seeing in Cyprus, by the way, at the moment. Just yesterday, we learned that more than half of the 8,000 asylum seekers you have in Cyprus had arrived quietly from the north of the island thanks to Turkish smugglers. 8,000, for a country of less than a million people, is a lot, and the migratory pressure has increased even more in recent weeks. But Turkey's dirty role should not absolve you of your own responsibilities. On Monday, after your country signed the ill-fated Global Compact on Migration in Marrakech, you celebrated International Human Rights Day. "With rights and freedoms for all," you said, but without duties or constraints. You are therefore well in tune with the authors of this suicidal text for the European nations. Yes, suicidal, since it is a question of removing the very concept of illegal immigration in order to create a kind of universal right to migration, for men without links, above ground, cut off from their roots. Some argue that this text would not be binding, but then why did the United States, Australia, Israel, so many European countries refuse to sign it? And why, then, did the government coalition in Belgium simply explode because of this text and the disagreements that concerned it? But I would also like to look back at the financial and banking crisis that hit your country in 2012 and 2013. The Cypriots served as guinea pigs for the austerity cures that the troika would soon impose on Greece of the very docile Alexis Tsipras, Mr Mélenchon's friend. The connivances between European leaders and the banks are no longer to be demonstrated, from Macron to Barroso, who went to slippers at Goldman Sachs, as soon as he finished his term as head of the European Commission.  Hence the custom creation - I dare not say on order - of the single resolution mechanism. As in Cyprus, in the event of a bank's bankruptcy, it is the savers who will have to pay the bill again, since their accounts could be automatically punctured. This is despite the cost of bailing out European banks in 2008. This is akin to a real racketeering in gangs organized, by the state and by the banks, and this is precisely what the yellow vests are revolting against in my country, France.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, after condemning the terrorist attack in Strasbourg and wishing condolences to the families of the dead and injured, I too welcome you to the European Parliament.  Mr President, you are well aware that all Greeks, especially nationalists, believe that Cyprus is not far but very close. It is here, in our hearts, and, because we are concerned about its future, I invite you to apologize for the following: Why do you not care about the decision of the Cypriot people, as expressed in the 2004 referendum, and promote as a solution of the Cyprus issue the bi-social bi-community federation, which legitimizes the illegal occupation of 37% of Cyprus and abolishes the status of the Republic of Cyprus?  Why, in this context, do you legitimise the presence of settlers in the occupied territories when you know that settlement is a war crime and that settlers are used as a means to change, to change the demographic composition of the country? Why, while Turkey does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus, do you not activate the right of veto to demand that the European Union immediately stop discussions on Turkey's accession and financing? Why do you not complain about the European Union's funding of Turkish Cypriots under the annual action programme of EUR 34.5 million? Why do you not protect the citizens of the Republic of Cyprus when the authorities, the illegal authorities of the pseudo-state, acting as legitimate, arrest and imprison them? Why do you allow the roadblocks to be opened when you know the economic consequences, smuggling, illegal work and the increase in crime that this entails? Above all, why did you allow the opening of the roadblock of Deryneia, which is interwoven with the murder of Isaac and Solomos? And finally, why didn't you prevent the sale of the German Leopard 2A4 tanks to the occupying forces in order to upgrade their fighting power?  Are you going to ask the European Union to impose an arms embargo on Turkey and the pseudo-state? Thank you very much and I look forward to your answers.

name: Νίκος Αναστασιάδης
text: President of Cyprus. Mr President, first of all I would like to express warm thanks both to the Vice-President and to the leaders of the various political groups in the European Parliament both for the kind words and possible criticisms that have been made. Criticism when it is in good faith, when based on evidence and evidence, is a guide for a government to adjust policies and adopt such decisions that create even better conditions for the living of its citizens. I would like to make a general reference to the Cyprus problem, the economy, the inequality that has been heard, political citizenship, policies concerning the granting of political citizenship, etc. With regard to the Cyprus issue, I must make it clear that the Greek Cypriot side has made major concessions for more than 44.5 years. We are talking about a state that was completely united with residents who lived in mixed communities. It consisted of mixed communities, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots.  As a result of the crime and the actions of the Greek junta against Makarios, with the excuse and pretext of protecting the Turkish Cypriots, Turkey invaded to restore constitutional order, despite the fact that no action was directed against the Turkish Cypriots, despite the fact that Makarios returned to Cyprus, the constitutional order was restored. Nevertheless, Turkey used the anachronistic right to intervene, invaded and divided the Republic of Cyprus, as has been its policy since 1956.  Since then, since the invasion, we have reached a historic but painful compromise: to accept the bi-social bi-community federation. We have made efforts, we have accepted political equality, we have accepted active, effective participation in the various institutions. However, every time we grant, in order to find a solution, some excessive – if you will – or excessive democracy-based rights, the Turkish Cypriots come back in Turkey's submission to demand more. Let me give you an example: The claim of the Turkish Cypriot community, which represents 20% of the population of Cyprus, to have a positive vote for every decision of the central state, whether it is the government or any other institution, tell me how it can be accepted? Nevertheless, and for the sake of finding a solution, we have said that we do not deny the right to a positive vote, if and when it will be exercised in order to protect the rights of the Turkish Cypriot community from any decisions that the majority can take against abuse of rights and to the detriment of the Turkish Cypriot community, since there is still of course an effective mechanism for resolving disputes. It wasn't accepted.  I come to Cran Medan, where we were very close and far away. We were indeed very close if the six positions of the parameters were adopted, as The Secretary-General of the United Nations put it, mr. Gutierrez for the creation of a normal state. What were these six conditions: the abolition of anachronistic guarantees, invasive rights, a vertical reduction of the occupying army limited to 650 and 950, i.e. the guarantee treaties and the treaty establishing the Republic of Cyprus, the way in which the Turkish Cypriots exercised their right to a positive vote, in which institutions, when and how it is exercised and how the smooth functioning of the State is ensured. , the issues of the territorial adjustments that were absolutely necessary, the issues of the property of the Greek Cypriots – the problem must be settled – but also an additional claim by Turkey for equal treatment of Greek nationals with Turkish nationals, as if Greek nationals were given preferential treatment. The Greeks are not given preferential treatment. The greeks are treated in the same way by the rest of the Europeans, but the claim was: for every Greek established under European law in Cyprus, we should have the presence of a Turkish national respectively.  And I ask you: We are only eight hundred thousand. If this were to be accepted, would we or would we not in no time alter the demographic character when this is already happening in the occupied area? Today there are more Turkish nationals than Turkish Cypriots. Therefore, what hindered the resolution of the Cyprus problem in Cran Medan was not that we do not care about the solution of the Cyprus problem. I should note that we had submitted answers on all six points of the Secretary-General, structured and comprehensive. Those who refused and insisted on guarantees, invasive rights, a military base, equal treatment, a positive vote were Turkey and the Turkish Cypriots. And I ask you: Which one of you would take on such a burden, give his consent and return home believing that it would be possible in a referendum to obtain the approval of such a solution? So it is obvious who led and how we were led to the impasse. Nevertheless, we insist and move forward and insist on starting a new dialogue from where we were, as long as there is good preparation, as the Secretary-General is asking for. I would like to say that within the next few days Mrs Lout, the Secretary-General's representative, will be in Cyprus. We are determined to work together. What we expect is for the other side to show the same good will. And I want to make one thing clear: that our aim, yes, is to find a peaceful solution, but – most importantly of all – not a solution for some days but a solution that is sustainable and, in order to be sustainable, must be functional and, in order to be operational, the conditions as set by Turkey or the Turkish Cypriot side cannot be accepted.  As far as the economy is concerned, I would like to say that not only do we not regret the decisions we have found ourselves obliged to accept, but we are also grateful, because, if we are not in the European Union, I do not know who would finance us so that the state does not go bankrupt, and I would remind you that in 2013, when we took over, we had cash available for civil servants' salaries of just one month and obligations until June that exceeded three billion.  Immediate action therefore had to be taken. Taken. There was also a proposal more favourable than the one that was finally adopted. Parliament did not accept it; But it must be said that by taking decisive and bold steps we have also achieved reforms and rationalisation of the economy and we are determined to continue in this way. The policy of nationalities: I want to say that somewhere there is a strong – if you will – targeting of Cyprus. I would like to inform you that in the last five years from 2013 to August 2018 the total number of nationalities granted by the Republic of Cyprus does not exceed 4,700, i.e. it represents 0.3% of the total nationalities granted by other States of the European Union. We have strict criteria in place. We've been audited by Moneyval. We have adopted policies that limit the number of people a year who can obtain Cypriot citizenship. We try and have decided to employ a foreign company in order to control the necessary procedures but also to exercise control over the financial resources of investors. We are very careful to avoid cases such as what I hear some people say, that some people are allowed to acquire European citizenship at the expense of the security of the European Union. But in Cyprus there has never been a terrorist attack! It's not in my country where the terrorist attacks take place. It is not in my country that most football teams belonging to oligarchs from other countries, third countries, or central points and large buildings and large real estate have passed into the hands of either Russian oligarchs, Arabs or others. That is not a bad thing, but a small country cannot be targeted because it has granted 0.3% of the nationalities granted by the other states of Europe, and I do not want to mention how many tens of thousands have been granted by the various countries. I'm stopping here. With regard to some phenomena on the issues of inequality and so on, I would just like to say that, when we took power, the economy was in the junks category. 22 downgrades. Today we have managed to overcome through upgrades all the problems and be back in the investment tier. We have a growth rate of 4% for the fourth year; we have been presenting budget surpluses of up to 3% for the last three years; unemployment has fallen from 16%, when we received the state, to 7%. And all this supposedly impoverished the Cypriots. Of course it is everyone's right to judge as they wish. What I want to say is that our ears are open to hear suggestions. We are ready to work with everyone to achieve better days for our country. And I conclude by reiterating that Cyprus is always ready to cooperate for the best possible and for a perspective and future of the European Union. Depending on our size, we are doing everything possible to consolidate regional peace, to establish strong regional cooperation, which is also in the interests of the European Union. So we will continue to be civilized in the belief that we can achieve much more together, as long as there is unity, as long as there is solidarity, as long as there is a common goal: the future of our common European home.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: – Mr President, President Anastasiades, allow me, first of all, to convey my solidarity to the Cypriot people in the wake of last week's torrential rains, which claimed the lives of at least four people in Kyrenia. Tragedies like this remind us of the importance of being able to guarantee the safety of all; the importance, in truth, of continuing to work towards reunification. Mr Anastasiades, you are demonstrating to the rest of the world that you are making every effort to bring Cyprus back together, and you demonstrated this in the Crans-Montana negotiations. As a European and as a Spaniard, I am confident that the national issue will be treated by all as a matter of state. And, of course, that's how you're doing it. That is why we must move towards a resumption of talks together. It is in the interests of all European citizens and especially those who live on both sides of the green line. So, President Anastasiades, move forward towards reunification. It has our recognition and also our support.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, welcome, Mr President of the Republic of Cyprus, even under these circumstances. For your presence here today to be of value, you must have made it clear that Turkey cannot have any European ambition if it does not fulfil all its obligations towards the European Union and the Republic of Cyprus, and that it is not conceivable to transfer German tanks to occupied Cyprus, so our partners indirectly support the occupation. In order for your presence to be of value today, it should also be stressed that the formula followed in Cyprus with the memoranda as in Greece has destroyed the social fabric. Indicators may prosper, but the people are still suffering. Young people see their dreams crushed and cannot hope, with the amount of rent, with the cost of living and with the low wages they receive. But these formulas, Mr President, have been imposed by your european right-wing peers. Of course, in order for your presence in relation to immigration to be of value, other policies must be followed. Cyprus is currently suffering from the flows coming from Turkey and we need to get into a burden-sharing logic... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I welcome you, Mr President, at a time when we are mourning the dead in Strasbourg and I think it is necessary to stress that tackling terrorism requires more European cooperation to defend peaceful democratic coexistence and not a return to nationalism.  Greece and Cyprus came out of the memorandums. Their economy is recovering and I am glad that there is a partnership between you and the Greek Prime Minister, Alexis Tsipras, even though you belong to different political families. I think it is necessary to restart, with the contribution of both the Commission and the European Parliament, the political dialogue on a just and sustainable solution to the Cyprus problem;

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, in this city of Strasbourg, La Marseillaus was composed one night. If I knew, what I'd do this morning is sing it. I want to show my solidarity and solidarity with the victims. Our support for the French authorities and our condemnation of terrorism. Last night this Parliament felt more the solidarity of the whole of Europe than the fear imposed by the terrorists.  We Spaniards know that terrorism is defeated with unity and democracy. Democracy kills terrorism. That's why we have to send the citizens the message that we're going to chase the terrorists to the last corner where they hide. They're not going to win.  Mr President, what do you think of a single defence system in Europe?

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, Mr Anastasiades, I belong to the opposition in Cyprus, I welcome you, we have differences, but I congratulate you on something: Today you made a very correct reference to the Cyprus issue: you raised it as a matter of invasion and occupation, and I realize, listening to my colleague, Mr Nart, that I could not imagine that anyone could be so out of reality, because quite rightly , Mr President, you referred to the refugees of Cyprus and some of us were children at the time and we have a personal understanding of the Turkish invasion and the ongoing occupation. But, Mr President, I have two very short questions to ask you: Firstly, from this European Parliament and the European Union we have taken so many decisions from European courts, resolutions; what else do we want in particular? Do we want sanctions on Turkey? Do we want an embargo? And the last one: I hope you will continue with vigour on the same line and know that German submarines are being used by Turkey against European interests in the Eastern Mediterranean.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: My dear president, I welcome you, too. We support a solution of a bi-social bi-community federation, because in the face of this solution it is not the unfortunately tolerated status quo; Because possession is a monster magnified by time. Fear, Mr President, is sometimes useful when one needs to bend over. But now we need stature. I understand, of course, that excessive courage is not always a good guide. We expect you to balance the concerns and the initiative. The answer to our concerns, Mr President, is this: it is not with the solution that we will bring what all Cypriots are entitled to; it is through the solution. I mean that the time that follows after the solution will prove whether we can – and can – Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots build a common home with a common homeland, with common power.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, Mr President Anastasiades, thank you for being with us. Many years ago, at the head of the high-level contact group with the Turkish Cypriots, I was able to touch the great suffering of the Greek and Turkish Cypriots because of the partition of the island. It is intolerable that a Member State of the European Union which must play a fundamental role south of this Mediterranean basin can still be invaded by Turkey. The biggest concern we had at the time was that the Turkish Cypriots were becoming a minority compared to the Turkish settlers and our fear was that the youth, that this new generation that knew only the partition of the island would get used to it and did not feel a sense of belonging to the European Union. Can you reassure me on this issue of youth?

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, fourteen years ago, with drumbeats, you announced accession to the European Union by discounting the resolution of the Cyprus problem. Today the situation is much worse. Turkey's aggression, intensifying rivalries make the situation in the wider region more dangerous. The European Union cannot guarantee the rights of peoples. She and her forerunners, along with NATO and the United States, have great responsibilities for the occupation, the perpetuation of the Cyprus issue.  We condemn the occupation of Cyprus. Euro-Atlantic staffs and energy monopolies are comfortable with a dichotomy solution, with NATO and EU troops on the island, which is a source of new risks, not security and stability. The Communist Party of Greece expresses its solidarity with the Cypriot people. By drawing on the experience of the rejection of the divisive imperialist annan project, the fight for Cyprus can be strengthened by a single, independent, single sovereignty, citizenship, international personality. One and not two states, without foreign bases, troops and guarantors, mastered by its people, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots!

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, welcome, my dear friend, President of the Republic of Cyprus, Nikos Anastasiades. I believe that today, at this moment, is particularly important in the European Parliament, because here is the President of the Republic of Cyprus, the only member country of the European Union, which continues to be divided and under Turkish occupation, fighting for national and natural survival with the support of the European Union. I think it is particularly important, because my dear friend Manfred Weber quite rightly and aptly mentioned that we may be a small country in size and population, but the European Union attaches particular importance and value to it, because this country is truly firmly committed to European principles and values.  Dear Friend President, as President of the Republic of Cyprus you have been at the forefront of supporting these principles and values, giving another and different displacement to the European Union. You are rightly given credit by all the political leaders here in the European Parliament for the truly excellent effort you have made to save Cyprus from bankruptcy and in doing so you have effectively given the message against populists and Eurosceptics. In conclusion, Mr President, I would like to say that the European Union must send its own strong message, that Cyprus must become a normal ... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, President Anastasiades, the Spaniards, like so many Europeans, have suffered and learned in the fight against terrorism and, therefore, all our infinite solidarity with the victims and our determination that terrorists will not be able to take our freedoms ahead of us. But we have also learned the value of the European Union in stimulating the reconciliation of historically divided communities. I have had the honour of being the rapporteur of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs for missing persons in Cyprus, an extremely sensitive and sensitive issue, on which the right of families to recover the remains of relatives who are victims of forced disappearances must take precedence; they must be assured of the commitment of the European institutions — of the Commission, but also of the European Parliament — to carry out the task until the remains of missing persons can be restored to relatives. And a greeting to the Committee on Missing Persons, a cross-cutting institution, respected and which deserves the full support of our European Parliament.

name: Νίκος Αναστασιάδης
text: President of Cyprus. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will be very brief. Most of the answers were given during my secondology. What I consider to be the first thing is to thank, among other things, the European Parliament and the Commission in particular for its support for the Missing in their efforts to ensure that another humanitarian problem, which is the verification of the fate of the missing, receives greater attention and under pressure to finally allow Turkey to open up 30 new sites located in military zones. , as they are called. I wish we could change geography and move either Turkey or us elsewhere, but as you can see we are doomed by geography to live side by side, which is why we prefer Turkey to be a European country rather than an uncontrolled country that can have expansive aspirations that often put security at risk.
