As regards the issues of German tanks, they are being investigated by both the German and Cypriot governments. What I want to reiterate in conclusion is to reaffirm my determination and willingness to work with determination and courage, as much as is necessary, in order to achieve a solution that will finally allow the peaceful coexistence of Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots in a state – and I want to stress this – that can function, be able to inspire, give duration, give perspective to all residents. , regardless of race, color, origin and so on, religion and so on. We can prove this in the future, as long as there are not those elements that give the right to overturn the desired objective, that is, a state where its citizens live and are guaranteed with all the privileges of other European citizens.  Thank you very much and I hope that the next debates in the European Council and of course in the European Parliament will always be aimed at the future of a strong Europe distinguished by the principles of solidarity and unity. Thank you very much. (applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you very much, President Anastasiades.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support the President's call for a stronger Europe. And the basis for this is unity and solidarity. Today, however, the focus is on a very different aspect: security and peace. I welcome the initiative of Cyprus to promote, together with Greece, close exchanges with countries such as Egypt and Israel. We need to cooperate with these countries so that we can guarantee peace and security in Europe.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – Let me, at first, express my regret at yesterday's terrorist attack in Strasbourg and extend my condolences to the families affected. You have spoken here, Mr President, about the need for a geographically, politically and economically united Europe. You also said that populism and terrorism are on the rise, I would say that euroscepticism and extremism are also on the rise. And because the theme is 'The Future of Europe', I would like to ask you, as a member of the European Council, what do you think of the Council's way of working? The Council holds back decisions, cancels Parliament's work many times, just because a head of state opposes it. You consider that it should be continued with the decision-making system on the 'principle of unanimity'. How can we talk about a united Europe if the Council breaks regulations and separates Europe into Schengen and the new Schengen, ignoring the Schengen Regulation for eight years? How can we talk about the single market if access to it is different for citizens and companies? Mr President, I would also like to ask you what you think of the asylum and migration system? Is the EU able to ensure the security of its citizens? I believe in a Europe that is indiscriminate and guarantees the safety of citizens.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. – According to a study by Transparency International and Global Witness, EU countries have sold 6 000 passports and almost 100 000 residence permits in the last ten years. Cyprus is one of these countries offering so-called 'golden visas'. The practice offered by Cyprus is one of the loosest in the EU countries. The country can redeem a passport for EUR 2 million after just six months of waiting. The person is then free to travel, work or engage in business activities within the EU as they wish. Golden visa schemes are very risky, for example, to money laundering and security threats if the backgrounds of applicants and the origin of their wealth are not thoroughly investigated. It is not right for other EU countries that, by selling passports and residence permits, Cyprus accepts the money but shares the risks posed by the system with all member states.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I greet the finalists and representatives of the other finalists, including Mrs Zoulikha Sihaddou and Mr Ahmed Zefzafi, who represent Mr Nasser Zefzafi. (Applause) I also greet Mrs Natalya Kaplan and Mr Dmitry Dinze, who represent the winner, Mr Oleg Sentsov. I want to call them to say hello and then to bring the session to life. Ladies and gentlemen, today, on a sad day for all of us, we pay tribute to Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian director and writer who has been detained for political reasons. He is the winner of this year's Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought. Sentsov is rewarded for his peaceful protest against Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, his homeland. He is also awarded the prize for his determination and commitment to the defence of human rights and dignity, democracy and the rule of law. The construction of Europe is based on these values, even more so today after yesterday's terrible attack. This Parliament will always be at the forefront of defending the freedom and dignity of the person, inside and outside the European Union. Oleg Sentsov, with his courage, hunger strikes and imprisonment, is a symbol of the struggle for freedom of political prisoners held in Russia and the rest of the world. I would like to extend a warm welcome to Natalya Kaplan and Dmitry Dinze, Sentsov's cousin and lawyer respectively, who are here today to represent him. Last July, the European Parliament called for the immediate and unreserved release of Oleg and all other Ukrainian citizens illegally detained in Russia and the Crimean peninsula. Today we want to make this request very strongly. I would also like to welcome Christophe Deloire, Secretary-General of Reporters Without Borders, winner of the 2005 Sakharov Prize, and the other finalists this year. I welcome the representatives of non-governmental organisations working to defend the rights of migrants and save lives in the Mediterranean. Then we greet, and I have already said goodbye, the parents of Nasser Zefzafi. (Applause) We also call for his immediate release. (Applause) You've seen the video that introduces us to this year's winner. Two days ago, we celebrated the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The European Parliament wanted to celebrate this anniversary by dedicating a whole week to human rights. Unfortunately, the battle for the defence of human rights is far from being won. Everywhere in the world men and women are persecuted for their ideas, for their beliefs, for their denunciations of authoritarian regimes. They are being suppressed for demanding freedom and justice alone. Thousands of journalists risk their lives every day. Many are killed or imprisoned to defend the truth and our freedom. All too often the powerful on duty trample underfoot the principles enshrined in this Declaration. This should not, however, discourage us but, on the contrary, make our efforts double, because our citizens are calling for a more effective Europe, one that provides the means to act and to promote the human rights of the world with determination. The Sakharov Prize was established thirty years ago to support individuals and organisations that are dedicated, body and soul, to the defence of justice, even at the risk of their own safety. Since then it has become the most followed human rights initiative in Europe. Five of our winners have been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, and just last Monday Dr Denis Mukwege and Nadia Murad received this important award. In May of this year, Oleg Sentsov began a hunger strike, calling for the release of Ukrainian political prisoners held in Russia. After 145 days he was forced to interrupt him due to his critical state of health and the threat of forced feeding. The Russian Human Rights Center "Memorial", winner of the Sakharov Prize in 2009, granted Sentsov political prisoner status. The European Film Academy and a large number of directors, associations and personalities have repeatedly called for his release.  This year's Sakharov Prize is being awarded in a climate of renewed tension between Russia and Ukraine. The recent incidents in the Sea of Azov and violations of international law have contributed to further aggravating the situation. We reiterate our call to avoid escalation and our firm condemnation of any action against ukraine's territorial integrity. I would like to conclude by thinking of all the winners of our prize who are facing serious difficulties today. I am thinking of Nasrin Sotoudeh, who was arrested in Iran in June. concerned about her situation and also for her we call for immediate release. Tomorrow, Parliament will also adopt an urgent resolution on your case.  I am also thinking of Raif Badawi, winner in 2015, who is still in prison for peacefully defending freedom of expression in Saudi Arabia. I am thinking of Leopoldo López, who is under house arrest in Venezuela, Razan Zaitouneh, who was kidnapped in Syria several years ago and whose fate, unfortunately, is still uncertain. I am thinking of the Chinese activist Hu Jia, who lives under constant surveillance, and the Las Damas de Blanco movement, whose members are constantly being intimidated in Cuba. Not forgetting Sentsov himself: we look forward to receiving him in Parliament to give him the Sakharov Prize in person, because this is not just a prize but a commitment we make to our winners. Today I want to say to all of you who are not alone in the struggle: this Parliament will always be at your side! (Applause)

name: Natalya Kaplan
text: Cousin of Oleg Sentsov. – Mr President, I am Natalya Kaplan and I am a cousin of the Ukrainian political prisoner Oleg Sentsov. First of all, he is a film director and a man with a capital ‘M’. He was an economist, but he never did any business. As a young man, he was enthusiastic about cybersports, and all the time he was reproached that computer games are not very serious and that he should start thinking about something else. But he started making his living playing games, bought a computer club and organised a team of cyber-sportsmen. But, slowly, he started retreating from this sport and watching more and more films. And then he understood that he had a lot to say and should start making movies. We became friends when Oleg was an adult. When we were both adults, his first short film, A Perfect Day for Bananafish, he filmed with his daughter Alina playing one of the characters. Oleg called this film educational: he just wanted to learn the process of making films and he showed it only to his inner circle.  He was a very goal-oriented person with an acute sense of justice. He made his first film without any education, experience, connections or budget, and his first film, Gamer, he financed himself. Funding was insufficient, but he succeeded in organising the whole process on the basis of enthusiasm. Many of his professional colleagues looked at him as yet another graphomaniac, and nobody believed that he would make a good movie. The result was, however, that he did a tour of the world and cinematographers perceived him as a fully-fledged colleague. In 2013, he started to work on his second film, Rhinoceros, the casting was done and he was planning to start filming, but the work was halted as a result of the events on Maidan. Practically from the first days of Maidan, he joined AutoMaidan – the activists who brought food, medical supplies and all necessary supplies to Maidan by car, and blocked the roads. Oleg was an office manager. He was in charge of the logistics of AutoMaidan, he coordinated people, directed everybody, and was perceived as a very good organiser by the people united by a common idea. At that time, we started communicating with Oleg much more often. He had no doubt in the victory of the activists. Then he went back to his native Crimea, but he couldn’t relax there. Little green men appeared on the Peninsula, and he once again joined the resistance. Oleg started bringing food, medical supplies and water to the Ukrainian resistance. When the little green men allowed the Ukrainian military to leave Crimea, he organised their leave.  In March 2014, Russia applauded Putin, praising him for the annexation of Crimea, and Ukraine was counting its dead and disappeared at the time. The repressive machine started operating in Crimea. It was well orchestrated and already worked well in all the occupied territories inside Russia, and especially in Chechnya. In April 2014, an anti-terrorist department was created in Crimea. Where there is a department, it is automatically thought that there should be terrorists, and Russian law—enforcement bodies started catching so-called ‘terrorists’ in order to earn new stars on their epaulettes. On 10 May, FSB people entered Oleg’s apartment; apart from him, only his 11—year-old daughter Alina was there. They searched his apartment in front of his daughter and confiscated train tickets from Simferopol and Kiev and back, along with a letter with a poem in Ukrainian, the computer, money saved for filming and some DVDs. They took two classic films from his collection: Fascism As It Is and a history of the Third Reich in colour. Thus they were trying to prove that Oleg had fascist and Nazis opinions. The FSB alleged that Oleg had been involved with the Ukrainian organisation ‘Right Sector’. It was this organisation that Russian propaganda used as a horror story for Crimeans, saying how they would destroy the Russians. The irony is that Oleg himself is a Russian speaker and considers himself as a Russian. In the same case, three more people were detained, historian Alexei Chirnii, the photographer and lawyer Gennadi Afanasiev, and a left-wing activist member of the environmental movement in the Crimea, anti-fascist Alexander Kolchenko. Chirnii and Afanasiev testified against Oleg. They were tortured, beaten and threatened with more violence. Oleg Sentsov was also tortured. The official documents indicated that he was detained on 11 May. It actually happened on 10 May. For a whole day, the FSB officers tried to beat a testimony out of him, against the Ukrainian authorities, against other people. When Oleg refused, he was told they would then make him the organiser of a terrorist cell and that he would go to a prison camp for 20 years. Oleg refused and that was the sentence he was given. At trial, Afanasiev recanted his testimony, stating that he had given it under torture, but the court did not investigate the statement, in fact ignoring the crime. This was also the case with Sentsov’s testimony. He repeatedly claimed that he had been tortured, and related what they had done to him. He had been beaten, choked and threatened with rape with a police baton, but the torture case was never opened. The answer came that Sentsov had traces of beatings as a result of sado-masochistic inclinations. After his arrest, the lawyers and consuls couldn’t find him anywhere. For two weeks, the hired lawyers tried to gain access to him, but they were hiding him, saying that he was in transit or in another pre-trial prison. And all the time he was in custody the Ukrainian consuls could not be allowed to visit him because he was a Russian citizen – allegedly, after the occupation he did not renounce his Russian citizenship under the official procedure and so automatically became a Russian citizen. Sentsov himself said: ‘I am not a serf. I cannot be transferred with the earth. I was, and remain, a citizen of Ukraine.’ There is no Russian passport in the criminal case, although Oleg was repeatedly forced to get one. It was only before he was sent to the colony in Yakutia, to the north of Russia, that the Ukrainian consuls were admitted to see Oleg. It happened just once. In Yakutia, which is 9 000 kilometres away from his native Crimea, he was kept for a year. He was hidden away from his relatives, from any possibility of their visiting him. Actually, Oleg did not want his relatives to visit him, because it would have been really difficult for him emotionally. After the Pussy Riot action held in Yakutia, Oleg was promptly transferred to the Arctic Circle, to the city of Labytnangi, and at the moment Oleg is in one of the northernmost prisons in the world. This is a strict regime colony on the Yamalo Peninsula. To send a southerner to the Arctic is a separate torture. Very soon, Oleg began to lose his hair and his teeth began to crumble, but Oleg is a person who cannot give up and just sit quietly. He is a fighter by nature, and the only method of fighting that he saw was a hunger strike.  On 14 May 2018, he declared a hunger strike. He agreed to stop it only when all the Ukrainian political prisoners were released from Russian prisons and prisons in the occupied Crimea, and by the most conservative estimates that amounted to 79 people. During his hunger strike, Oleg’s already undermined health began to deteriorate rapidly. His relatives feared for his life, and knowing who Oleg is, they understood that it was impossible to convince him. He would go to the very end – to the deadly end. All his internal organs suffered. The liver had enlarged, they removed a kidney stone, and he developed problems with his intestines and stomach. His internal organs did not receive enough oxygen, hypoxia began, and the effects reached the brain. In order to avoid force-feeding, Oleg agreed to medication maintenance, but his condition was still worsening every day. On 5 October, after 145 days of his hunger strike, Sentsov announced its termination. The reason was a statement by the officers that they would begin force—feeding him. Oleg understood the hunger strike would stop anyway, but he had a choice: to be tortured again, to lie fettered with a tube stuck up his nose, or to stop on his own. In order to avoid additional suffering, he chose the second option.  During all the 145 days, not a single Ukrainian political prisoner had been released, but this does not mean that Oleg lost. Thanks to his act, the whole world spoke about repression by Russia and Oleg drew great attention to the topic of Ukrainian political prisoners – and that is his victory. Especially for this occasion, he wrote an address to everyone here. I will now read it for you. ‘Ladies and gentlemen, I cannot be present in this room right now, but you can hear my words, even if someone else is saying them. The word is the main tool of a person, and often his only tool, especially when everything else has been taken from him. In a word you can cure, you can maim, you can save, and you can kill by commanding fire. There are people whose words mean a lot. There are people vested with power and opportunities, but they use the power of their words in different ways. You can call for acceptance and surrender, but on the contrary you can call for resistance and for fighting, even when there is no chance to survive but only a chance to die. But it is not so important how long you live, but how. No matter when you die, more important is how and for what. You can be a simple peasant, less than 18 years old, and then with your own words raise up a whole country to resist, accept humiliation and martyrdom, and then stay forever in history under the name of Joan. Or you can live as a bloody ruler to a ripe old age, tirelessly uttering a flood of false words that your people would supposedly admire, and world leaders would even shake hands with you, not wanting to quarrel with you, but after your death your name will be cursed right away, and the word ‘Bokassa’ will become a common word. Modernity is often not fair. History is always fair. Over time, everything falls into place and is called by its proper name. And someone rushes down to the garbage heap under the curses of the liberated people, along with the fragments of monuments to himself. And someone who was persecuted and almost despised by us, on the contrary, after death, takes a worthy place in world history, and his name is given to streets, ships and awards. To take an example: Andrei Sakharov is quite a person to be compared to. Being placed anywhere near him is too great an honour for me. He raised the bar so high for education and talent, intelligence and courtesy, dignity and humanism. But I hope that I will can still do something that will make me feel I have deserved this award. Thank you.’ (The House accorded Natalya Kaplan, cousin of the Sakharov Prize winner, a standing ovation)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, as I said at the beginning of this session this morning, Parliament defends democracy and democracy is the strongest. The power of democracy wins against the violence of crime. I ask you to stand up and observe a minute's silence in solidarity with the three European citizens who were killed last night and those who were injured by this criminal. It is also a message of solidarity with the French Republic and with all the families of yesterday's victims. Parliament stands with them, and we are moving forward to defend freedom and democracy.  (The standing assembly observes a minute's silence)

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: – Mr President, as chair of Quaestors, although I wasn’t personally caught up in it last night, I would like to thank on behalf of all of us in this House and our assistants, the staff of this House who stayed behind last night and helped us enormously. (Applause) I would especially like to thank the catering staff, who managed to remain calm and cheerful whilst finding food from somewhere that they didn’t know they had, whilst all the time wondering about their family and friends somewhere else in this city. Also the car drivers who returned to the Parliament in the wee small hours to make sure that we all returned to our hotels safe and sound and to the many others that we didn’t see but are working behind the scenes. To all of them we all say a very heartfelt, thank you very much for last night. (Sustained applause)

name: Franck PROUST
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me, on behalf of the French EPP delegation but also, more generally, on behalf of all the parliamentary colleagues here, to extend my deepest condolences to the victims and families of the victims of yesterday's terrorist attack in Strasbourg.  Like all my colleagues, I was in Strasbourg yesterday. I could feel this exceptional climate of tension. I could imagine the stress of the families without news of their loved ones, the suffering of the relatives of the victims. Despite the repetition of these vile terrorist acts, we will never get used to them and, moreover, we must not get used to them. It is with a heavy and saddened heart that I convey to them all my wishes of support, very modest, I agree, given the magnitude of the pain that must inhabit them. I would also like to pay a heartfelt tribute to the police, the military and the emergency services who responded yesterday, even though we know that they have already been under test in France for several weeks. They are the honor of our country. Our presence in the Chamber today also underlines that democracy continues, that France and Europe stand. It is not only Strasbourg that was attacked yesterday, it is France and, even more, Europe as a whole that has been targeted. It is a model of civilization that has been targeted, a certain notion of freedom that these barbarians are trying to muzzle. Let those who want to bring us to our knees hear our message: European democracy as a whole remains united, standing and dignified. Terrorism will not pass. (Applause)

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the After last night's heinous attack, let me express my sorrow and sympathy – for the victims, for the people who lost their lives, for the injured and for the many who can still see yesterday's impressions of yesterday, who have also had to spend a terrible evening in fear and terror under the terrible impressions. Let me express my deep gratitude to the rescue workers, to the police, to the many helpers in the city centre who have taken care of the people, and to all the colleagues here in the House who have maintained the order here, who have taken over the care. We are deeply indebted to them. Please understand, Mr President – that was the discussion last night – that we, the Members, have insisted that we go together with colleagues and not before. We, the family of the European Parliament, belong together, and even in a dangerous situation we go together, or we remain together. That was our wish. They have complied with this, and I thank you for that. Let me say: no violence, no attack ... No attack, no violence will be able to undermine our passion for freedom and democracy. This is the House of European democracy. This is the House that will always defend freedom and democracy. We will not be shaken but, on the contrary, will strengthen our fight for our European values, for the European society of the equal and of the free.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr I would like to draw attention to the fact that there has been a breach of the mandate of members of the European Parliament. A Member may not be deprived of his liberty and the closure of an MP in a building is a deprivation of liberty. A person cannot be deprived of his liberty without a court order, so if he wants to go out and risk his life, Then I think it is absolutely inexcusable to lock someone forcibly in prison, because there is a lunatic with a shotgun running in the wild, and honest people sit in prison in the building. This cannot be the case.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: At the opening of the sitting on Monday 10 December, decisions were announced by several committees to open interinstitutional negotiations under Rule 69c(1). I would like to inform you that I have received a request from the GUE/NGL and Verts/ALE Groups to put to the vote the decision of the ECON Committee to open interinstitutional negotiations on the basis of the report on minimum loss coverage on non-performing exposures. The vote will take place tomorrow. With regard to the other decisions to open interinstitutional negotiations of the REGI, ECON, ITRE, LIBE, JURI, IMCO and AFCO committees, I have not received any request for a vote. These committees can therefore start negotiations. ***

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last night two people, through no fault of their own, without any responsibility, lost their lives and we really cannot think of reducing everything to a minute's silence. There are responsibilities that some people want to keep not seeing, there are deep responsibilities. I really cannot accept this line of saying 'we must move forward': no, we cannot go on with mistakes, we cannot continue to make mistakes, we cannot really allow the mistakes of France, and often also of Europe, to go so far as to support the action of Islamic extremism which often, I repeat, unjustly takes the lives of citizens. I will leave Strasbourg after the votes, I will leave France. I invite Macron to come here to Strasbourg. I will return to Italy as a sign of protest. I say to everyone: wake up, wake up, wake up! I join the protest and say: wake up, wake up, wake up!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Ciocca, please, today is not the day to make propaganda demonstrations. (Applause and off-microphone protests) Let me talk like I made you talk! Sit down immediately! Sit down immediately! Mr Ciocca, sit down! (Voices not audible off microphone) Mr Ciocca, if you had been here this morning, you would have listened more and would know more. It's a matter of good manners: You are rude if you interrupt the speaker, learn education, and stay in your place. I repeat, this is not a circus, there are victims! Respect the victims, don't do propaganda. If you were here in the morning, when you talk... (Off-microphone protests) I believe that in democracy and freedom, in any Parliament, everyone must respect others. I've made everyone talk, and I pretend to be heard. The screams, the cries, the clown demonstrations, in this Parliament, as far as I am concerned, are not accepted. (Applause) Those who are absent have a duty to inquire.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: Like scavengers, you throw yourself at the remains of the victims not even cooled to make it a political act. Shame on you! Shame on you! (Applause)

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have raised my card to ask that, as you have done, the points of order should not become scenes of ridiculous propaganda which, I believe, are not acceptable at such a serious time. Thank you for what you said.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: Mr President, it is very nice that you are letting me speak. I fully agree with you that this danger is about respect for the victims, but there is only one way to respect the victims and that is to recognise where this danger comes from. And this danger, Mr President, comes from Islam. It's Islamic terror and we'll keep seeing it.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We are no longer debateed, we shall now proceed to the vote. These are very long votes, there is no point in polemics between us. This is the moment of solidarity: terrorism is fought with unity, as you have mentioned today. (Voices not audible off microphone) But why do you always scream? (Off-microphone protests)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I should like to say about the importance and value of this Fund that it is a solidarity fund which, thanks to the improvements made through the European Parliament, has begun to mobilise immediately, effectively and decisively to cover emergencies, to be close to the citizens. We believe that the Solidarity Fund is the same as the very idea of the European Union, solidarity.  Nevertheless, I would like to point out that there is still a great deal of bureaucracy, with the result that many countries expect emergencies and disasters to be met but which cannot be dealt with immediately and that European citizens feel that the Solidarity Fund is close to them. I believe that there is room for improvement and the European Parliament has the opportunity in future to improve it to strengthen it for the good of all of us.

name: Juliane Bogner-Strauss
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I congratulate you on concluding your vote on the budget of the European Union for the financial year 2019. The Council notes with satisfaction that the European Parliament has confirmed the agreement reached at the trilogue on 4 December. I shall take this opportunity to extend thanks once again – on behalf of Minister Löger, of course – to the Chair of the Committee on Budgets (BUDG), Jean Arthuis, and the rapporteurs, Daniele Viotti, Paul Rübig and Jens Geier, as well as to other Members of Parliament who participated in the budgetary procedure, for their constructive approach.

text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA

text: The agenda calls for the current debate (Article 153 bis of the internal regulation) on the following topic: "Associating workers and citizens in a transition just for a safer planet" (2018/2973 (RSP)). I draw your attention to the fact that this debate does not involve on-demand interventions and that there will also be no blue cards.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: representing the S&D Group. – Madam President, it’s a little bit of an awkward situation, I have to say, and I think we’re all a little bit taken aback by what’s happened, so we can have a good but respectful debate today on a topic that is clear. In the sense, we asked for this topic before the so—called gilets jaunes, but of course it is in connection with that. Last weekend, we had 75 000 people walking the streets of Brussels to ask for more ambition with regard to climate change. And on the other hand, you have the gilets jaunes in France but also in parts of Belgium. This could sound like a contradiction, two different manifestations, but actually it isn’t. It’s actually rather logical and understandable. People do understand the necessity and the urgency of fighting climate change, and they do demand urgent action of Europe and the Member States. But they cannot, they will not and they should not accept the fact that they are the only ones that will have to pay the bill for that: bad air quality, health risk, diminishing purchase power, job losses, unaffordable bills when it comes to energy, bad housing conditions. Think about our polluting cars and, at the same time, the new electric cars unaffordable for so many people. These people are not climate sceptics, but maybe they will become climate sceptics if we do not make sure that we make a just transition. Yes, we need a transition, but it will only be a good one when it is a just one. And for us, the S&D Group, it is not just a necessity or a purely economic process of changing business sectors and securing competition. No, for us the social dimension is absolutely clear. Yes, coal mines: they need to be shut down. And yes, we will have to get rid of the combustion engine. But not while at the same time making all these things unaffordable for families and putting territories or families into uncertainty or even poverty. And in that sense, I think we need coordinated action to make that a just transition. Let me give you a few examples. First of all, just transition should be a key concept in all policy processes at all levels. Second, we need a radical change in the governance of the European Union. Broadening the European semester with social and ecological indicators which have the same weight as the economic, the fiscal and the debt indicators –that is also key. Investing in clean and sustainable industries and technologies and keeping these investments off the balance sheet, because otherwise we will not have enough room to make these investments. Creating new specific funds for just transition and dedicating money in existing funds and programmes within the Multiannual Financial Framework. And also making sure no investments go against these just transition principles. And to make a just transition successful, we need a profound social dialogue in this case. This should involve governments at all different levels, workers and their unions, employers, businesses and NGOs to work and cooperate together. We have no alternative. We have to make this transition, but by making sure we do this in a just way, putting people and social values at the core of our sustainable agenda, we will be able to get everybody on board and turn this transition into a successful Europe. The two most important challenges – and that’s my final word – that we are all facing are climate change and rising inequalities. Let’s pull them together and make sure that we come into a concept of sustainable equality.

name: Juliane Bogner-Strauss
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank Parliament for raising this very important topic and for giving me the chance to take the floor on behalf of the Council. The timing of this debate is apt, given that international climate negotiators are currently gathered at COP24 in Katowice in Poland, discussing, inter alia, solidarity and ‘just transition’. The topic was immediately brought to the fore when, on 3 December 2018, at the leaders’ summit taking place during the conference, the Polish Presidency of COP24 announced the adoption of the Solidarity and Just Transition Silesia Declaration. The European Union joined the representatives of 45 states in giving its full support to the declaration, which remains open for others to join it. The Silesia Declaration underlines that a just transition of the workforce and the safeguarding and creation of sustainable employment and decent work are crucial to ensuring public support for long—term emission reductions. The EU’s support for the declaration, alongside that of its Member States, is an important signal to the international community, showing our commitment to the implementation of the Paris Agreement.  You are all aware of the enormous scale and urgency of the challenge that climate change poses to humankind. If left unconstrained, climate change will lead to large-scale and irreversible negative consequences for our environment and ecosystems, and for our economies. Action against climate change is more urgent than ever. The Paris Agreement sets the goal of achieving net—zero greenhouse gas emissions globally in the second half of this century. The EU has long been at the forefront of the global response to climate change. It already has in place a legislative framework for reducing its greenhouse gas emissions up to 2030 and it has managed successfully to decouple greenhouse gas emissions from economic growth since the 1990s. However, we know that, even though they are among the most ambitious in the international context, the policies the EU has in place today will not be enough to contribute in a sufficient manner to the achievement of the Paris Agreement’s temperature goals. According to the Paris Agreement, all parties are to present long-term, low-greenhouse-gas-emission development strategies by 2020. On 28 November, responding to calls by the Council and Parliament to present a long-term strategy for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, the Commission published a communication on a long—term strategy for the European Union. It outlines a vision of the economic and societal transformations required, while also seeking to ensure that the transition to net—zero greenhouse gas emissions is socially fair. Discussions of the long-term strategy within the Council have already started and, before the end of our Presidency, it will be debated by Ministers responsible for energy at the Council meeting scheduled for 19 December, and by those responsible for the environment on 20 December. The challenges posed by global climate change will require huge economic and societal transformation, which includes the continuing modernisation of European industries and economies with, notably, a transition to clean energy systems. Just transition is an imperative that was included in the Paris Agreement to ensure that the consequences for the workforce of climate change measures in regions and communities which stand to be particularly affected by them are taken into account. Some regions, globally and in Europe, are more dependent than others on carbon-intensive industries or on coal mining. Today, 41 regions in 12 EU countries are actively mining coal, and many face significant economic and social challenges. The transition towards low—carbon and climate—resilient economies and societies should ensure a just transition of the workforce, with the creation of decent work and quality jobs for all. While many sectors, cities and regions which are highly reliant on fossil fuels and high-emitting industries face undeniable challenges, the transition to climate—resilient economies also has the potential to create additional employment opportunities. According to a report published by the International Labour Organisation (ILO), this year, jobs created in renewable energy, building efficiency and other low—carbon industries can more than offset job losses in other sectors. However, policies will be needed to protect workers in the sectors where there will be fewer jobs in the future. The Silesia Declaration mentions the importance of the ILO guidelines for a just transition towards environmentally sustainable economies and societies for all, and emphasises that the UN 2030 Agenda and its Sustainable Development Goals confirm the need to tackle environmental, social and economic problems in a coherent and creative manner. Ensuring a just transition for the workers and communities concerned requires a participatory and progressive representative process of social dialogue, involving all social partners. Just transition is finding its way into important pieces of EU legislation on climate and energy policy. With the inclusion of just transition as one of the investment priorities of the new Modernisation Fund, the revised Emissions Trading System (ETS) Directive will play an important role in supporting regions in 10 low-income Member States, which are dependent on carbon-intensive industries, during their move towards a low—carbon economy. Projects financed under the Modernisation Fund should support the redeployment, reskilling and upskilling of workers, education, jobseeking initiatives and start-ups, in dialogue with the social partners. In addition, the revised directive highlights the use of auction revenues by Member States for the purpose of promoting skills formation and the reallocation of labour in order to contribute to a just transition to a low—carbon economy, in particular in regions most affected by the jobs transition. In both cases, Member States are responsible for designing and implementing the relevant support schemes. It is to be noted that support is also available from a number of existing EU programmes and funding instruments. It is a very positive sign that the international community, governments, businesses and trade unions are increasingly paying attention to the just transition agenda. This is a conversation which needs to continue and to be as inclusive and participatory as possible.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the honourable Members for tabling this important and topical debate. We can only have a clean transition if it is also a just transition, and we can only have a safer planet if we involve our workers and our citizens.  This is a tale of two cities. While we are debating the issue today in Strasbourg, the UN Climate Conference – the COP24 – is taking place in Katowice. Katowice is a city in Poland’s region of Silesia, one of Europe’s most coal-intensive regions and, as such, Silesia perfectly illustrates the social economic challenges, but also opportunities, of transition to a low—carbon economy. This is why COP24 started last week by signing the Silesia Declaration on Solidarity and Just Transition, a declaration endorsed by the European Union as a whole and 20 EU Member States individually, a declaration which stresses that environmental and social developments must go hand—in—hand.  Our European climate policy is the most forward-looking in the world. We aim to reduce our emissions by at least 40% by 2030, but the Paris Agreement requires us to look further into the future. Two weeks ago, we published our proposal for the European Union’s long-term strategy, a long—term strategy on the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, and the proposal shows how Europe can lead the way to climate neutrality by 2050 by investing in technological solutions, by empowering citizens, by taking action in industrial policy finance and research, and by ensuring social fairness.  We need to decisively tackle climate change, and there are more benefits besides those clearly related to environment and health. Already today the transformation is creating growth – green growth. In Europe, the clean energy sector has created roughly four million jobs; investments into industrial modernisation, energy transformation, the circular economy and clean mobility will create more and better jobs.  But change will come with its challenges and costs. These challenges might not be equally distributed between regions, sectors and between people. Emission-heavy industries need to rethink their industrial processes, and if they don’t, there are job losses, social exclusion and depopulation in the region. The labour market will change. Just like in the digital transition, some jobs will disappear, others will be created, and many jobs will change. Workers in declining sectors need guidance and re-skilling, and we have to realise that some people won’t be able to upskill or re-skill – they need social protection, and that means adequate social protection. Lastly, transition may affect most those who can afford it least – those who can’t invest in energy efficiency or low-carbon solutions. The success of the transition to the low-carbon economy depends on the support of our citizens; it should be seen not as a pet project of the elites. Our policy should be progressive and should not punish the poorest. To avoid polarisation, to avoid inequality, we must base our policies on solidarity. Social fairness should be part of all our climate policies, right from the start. We should not think about corrective actions post factum in order to remedy the consequences. Instead, we should include social and fairness considerations at the outset from the moment we design our policy responses. Also, therefore, we are putting a premium on investment. Our proposal for the new MFF has a strong focus on investment and innovation, with programmes such as Horizon Europe, the Invest Europe Fund, the European Regional and Development Fund, and the dedicated modernisation and innovation funds under the EU Emissions Trading System. We can anticipate skills needs and help workers change jobs by funding retraining and upskilling from the European Social Fund. Our proposal for the post-2020 European Globalisation Adjustment Fund helps workers who risk losing their jobs because of decarbonisation by funding retraining and activation measures. And with the European Pillar of Social Rights, we direct policy attention to support for individual transition through investing in skills and lifelong learning and upskilling and re-skilling, but also through investment and adequate social protection. And we base our approach on partnership. For example, last year we launched the Coal Regions in Transition initiative to facilitate green transition in 41 coal— and carbon—intensive regions located in 12 Member States. Climate change is a fact, and that’s why we are ambitious in our goals, and that’s why we are planning for the long term. The Paris Agreement is good for the planet and for the people, but it can only be made a reality and a success with the people on board.

name: Franck PROUST
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have been very hesitant to speak at this debate, wondering if the time is right. I want to tell you that the continuation of our debates today is the victory of democracy over terror, the victory of freedom over those who try to muzzle it, so let me speak on the topic on the agenda today, as I originally planned. Six months ago, Emmanuel Macron was received by this assembly as the head of state to whom everything succeeded. He was promised a great destiny and, even then, remember, I intervened to ask you to be vigilant. Eight months later, the cards seem to be being replayed. Indeed, France has been facing a social challenge rare enough to be highlighted for several weeks. Employees, retirees, anonymous people who tighten their belts to make ends meet have united to be heard.  The cause of their anger is simple: the President of the Republic and his fiscal policy, which favours raising taxes and reducing public spending, was a miscalculation. I understand this social grumbling and exasperation of the middle classes and let me tell you that they have nothing to do with the problems of energy transition. Nevertheless, if I support the peaceful demonstration, I do not tolerate the violence that has raged several weekends in a row in Paris and in the provinces, and I want to thank the police and gendarmerie for their exceptional mobilization. After several weeks of total silence, Emmanuel Macron intervened on Monday to try to give pledges in order to stop a protest that he himself has spawned, but the president has been too late and, although the concessions are interesting, although not all, they cost 10 billion euros. Who will fund them? We cannot make promises on credit. Emmanuel Macron has divided the French instead of bringing them together. It is now our duty to make the opposite movement: let us not let France fracture because this silent majority, this France that works deserves our full attention.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. Madam President, at this painful moment that is reaching all of us, I would like to return to the major subject that we are dealing with at the moment: that of the just transition. What do the yellow vests tell us? The yellow vests tell us, the policies: reinvest the sense of politics, do not limit politics to the simple economy, to simple growth, to the simple indicator of gross domestic product. They tell us: take care of your function, that of organizing the living together, that of making society together. They think that's the right transition, it's the transition from one development model to another model of development for a fairer planet, but not just for a few, a fairer planet for the many. Stop pitting economics, social, environmental, and take as a new political matrix a set of these elements in relation to the Sustainable Development Goals, which were voted in 2015 in the United Nations. This is certainly the new development model. For 40 years, Madam President, the neoliberal model has been developing here and elsewhere in the world. What is the result? A concentration of indecent wealth, a growing impoverishment of the greatest number, worrying human health, shattered biodiversity and unprecedented global warming. Yes, we must act, but act urgently and globally in the interests of the greatest number. That is the concept of the right transition that we are dealing with right now.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Minister, Commissioner. Unfortunately, the transformation, including the one that is taking place in Europe, is mainly at the expense of ordinary people, which is why they reject this transformation, which is why the streets of French cities, where 'yellow vests' are protesting, look like this. After all, this protest did not come only from the increase in fuel prices. He came from the conviction that we are dealing with a profound injustice and the detachment of European elites from the fate of ordinary people. President Macron, in a nervous first reflex when these protests came, said that if someone can't afford more expensive fuel, let them buy an electric car, and yet he knows perfectly well that this car is twice as expensive as the standard one. This is reminiscent of the situation of the eighteenth century, and the statement, moreover, of the French Queen Marie Antoinette, who, on the news that peasants are starving in the countryside because they do not have bread, suggested that they eat biscuits. This detachment of European elites from the fate of ordinary people ends badly, and this can be seen not only on the streets of French cities, but also in many other western European countries. The situation is very different in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, in a country like mine, Poland, where, as you have rightly pointed out, a climate summit is taking place. This climate summit can produce positive results under two conditions – the first being if the REDUCTION OF CO2 is adapted to the level of development of individual countries, secondly, if the balance of emissions and removals is taken into account.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, a safer planet is one where violence, especially terrorism, especially more extreme violence such as terrorism, is fought mainly with preventive political measures and not only with repressive police measures. A safer planet is one where more schools are built today for tomorrow, not having to build more prisons.  A safer planet is one where poverty is combated with policies based on solidarity and this political imperative is not left to the random growth of the economy and the unpredictable expansion of markets.  A safer planet is one where citizens trust their political representatives because they always respect their will and place the interests of their constituents above their own personal interests and personal amenities.  A safer planet is one where citizens rely on the veracity of the news read and heard in the media, because they are sure that journalists produce information subordinated only to the dictates of truth and public interest of the facts and not to the propagandistic or advertising interests of media agencies clients.  A safer planet is one where citizens trust judges who judge and decide in the courts, because they know that they always do so subordinate to the values of law and justice and not to hidden agendas of personal and/or corporate political interests. A safer planet will always have to be a fairer and less unequal planet. Absolute equality will never be achieved among human beings, but the abysses that still divide men and women and especially the rich and the poor on this planet can already be reduced. A safer planet, in short, is one in which we know how to preserve its biological diversity, as well as its tenuous environmental balances.

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, I would like to begin by saying that today we all have strasbourgers, the victims and their families in our minds. For the past month, yellow vests have been an unprecedented social mobilization that calls for unprecedented responses. The trigger was the increase of a tax on diesel, but the cause comes from further afield: a massive transfer of wealth to the wealthiest in the country, which has been strengthened exponentially since the election of Emmanuel Macron, his choice of "first ropes" and the social contempt they display. This reality is particularly felt in rural areas, which are exposed to gender disruptions, whether in terms of transport, access to care or school, and a degraded employment situation. The enemy is therefore not climate policy but neoliberalism, starting with the 100 companies responsible for 71% of global greenhouse gas emissions. If there are punitive measures, they should be exercised on them first. According to the latest IPCC report, we have only 12 years to reduce these emissions, and produce an ambitious climate policy and social justice.  For example, the International Labour Organization estimates that a rapid transition to clean energy could create an additional 18 million jobs worldwide by 2030. There is no shortage of proposals: taxing the 10 billion annual profits of oil companies, taxing aircraft kerosene and heavy fuel from container ships, allocating all environmental taxes to the ecological transition, mobilising bank credit to the European Central Bank, developing real taxation. On 14 December, I wanted to add it, I will be at the day of action in France, alongside the yellow vests and trade unionists.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, how can we dare to divide society between successful people and people who are nothing? Many of you have written to me, especially from France, since the beginning of the yellow vest movement. In often poignant words, you have told me your anger at being seen as nothing, your displeasure with our democratic institutions, your revolt against injustice in all its forms, especially fiscal, which these institutions perpetuate. You can't stand being taken for fools anymore.  No, enriching the rich - sorry, not throwing stones at the first of ropes - does not benefit everyone. No, strengthening the power of multinationals - sorry, defending our great national champions - is not defending the public interest. None of you condone the violence of the breakers, but, all of you, are speechless in the face of repression. And if the spark of revolt is the taxation of fuels, I know that you have at heart the need for our societies to respect the limits set by nature. Colleagues, the IPCC urges us to embark on a profound ecological transition without delay: we need our planet to become or remain habitable for all. But this transition can only be in solidarity. Let everyone take their share of the effort to the extent of their abilities and that it benefits everyone according to their needs. We know that half of all emissions are produced by the richest 10%. This ecological and solidarity transition must also be fully democratic, because no single individual has the plan of the ideal, just and united society, nor the GPS for that matter. Finding a way for it requires us to mobilize our collective intelligence and creativity. So I would like to say that those who would like to oppose the citizens mobilized against injustice to those who are mobilizing to save our planet have understood absolutely nothing. Between the end of the month and the end of the world, we do not have to choose, these two fights are two sides of the same coin, that of the struggle for human dignity, that of all humans present and to come.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we know how urgent it is to avoid climate change, and I will cite the latest IPCC report but also, of course, the daily weather bulletins. It is not only the climate, there is also the need, however, to achieve the so-called ecological 'budget balance'. We know that mankind consumes, in just seven months, the renewable resources that nature is able to regenerate, and not always, over the course of a whole year. If we compare the Earth to an ATM, from August to December 31, mankind makes debt withdrawals, creating an ecological debt that we will bequeath to children and grandchildren. Ecological budget balance is infinitely more important than balancing the budget. In order to achieve a balanced ecological budget, it is therefore necessary to move to a development model based on the circular economy and, in order to avoid climate damage, we need a shift to a society based on renewable energies. But these two transformations are not free, they have an economic cost. We cannot simply dump them on the citizens in the form of taxes on polluting fuels and the like in the name of a balanced budget. The Eu ropean Union and the Member States must be able to spend to finance the ecological transition, which will create jobs through the circular economy and renewable energies. Above all, the decarbonised European economy needs a carbon tax at the border in order to avoid unfair competition from companies abroad, from this kind of social and climate dumping. This is the change that europe and the rest of the world need.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, I would like to say above all that all my thoughts today are with the victims, and their families, of the Islamist attack that bereaved Strasbourg last night. The debate today requires an important focus: citizens and workers are as aware as we are and you of the need to protect our environment. No one wants to jeopardize the future of their children and future generations.  You are talking about ecological transition and environmental protection to avoid global warming, but for this to be sincere, it would have been more honest to denounce, for example, the free trade treaties which are constantly negotiated with everyone by a European Commission more concerned with the future of free trade than with that of the planet. A supertanker that criss-crosses the world's seas pollutes in one year more than 50 million cars, the equivalent of the French car fleet. Challenging this absurd economic model of globalization would be the first truly ecological step to take.  Quite the opposite of punitive ecology, which consists only of taxing taxpayers a little more and making them feel guilty with permanent moral lessons. The healthy anger of the honest people who parade today in the streets of Paris and France with yellow vests on the back may soon burst in your face.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I too share the thoughts of the victims, the sympathy with the relatives who, after the attack here in Strasbourg, have to fear for loved ones so shortly before Christmas.  Such an attack also makes it clear to us what we have to defend here. We have nothing less to defend than our freedom and peace, and that is where we have to stand together. That is why I think it is right that this fundamental issue of social upheaval in many parts of Europe should be negotiated here in the European Parliament today. I also think it is a strong sign that it is women – ladies – who are taking this initiative in the European Parliament, that Mrs Van Brempt has initiated the fact that The Federal Minister Bogner-Strauß is there for the Council, Commissioner Thyssen: a strong sign from Europe to the world under the chairmanship of a lady!  We defend our freedom and we must guarantee security for the citizens; this is the first step in overcoming dislocations. We must make education possible, but not only at university level, but also where specialist work and crafts are at stake.  In the age of digitalisation in particular, it is important for Europe to make progress on this, and of course in a sustainable sense. I am pleased that so many speeches today have referred to the fact that digitisation and sustainability are compatible and that sustainability must be broad for the labour market, for society and, of course, for the environment.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we would all have liked to have had this debate in another political climate. However, as other Members have said, it is right that democracy and this Parliament should continue their work, as is their duty. Today – as we have experienced, France is experiencing it at this time – our democracies are under enormous pressure of a different kind, threatening its very nature and a future that we have too often taken for granted. The double grip caused, on the one hand, by the negative effects of globalisation and, on the other, by the increasingly powerful upheavals resulting from climate change, is proving untenable. I believe that it is possible to respond to the climate challenge by taking together the social dimension, in order to protect all citizens, but especially the weakest, who are also the ones most affected by globalisation, those who have suffered most over time from the pollutions and difficulties caused by the environmental crisis and who today rightly present us with the account of their anger and frustration. We cannot put the ecological transition on the shoulders of the weakest. I believe, however, that it is possible, if we so wish, to achieve a just transition, as our request for a debate also states. We need to address the debate and our programme, the one that the Commissioner has presented to us, being always able to assess together the environmental aspects, the economic aspects and the social aspects.  If we succeed in doing this, and it is our duty to future generations, I believe that we will be able to implement the right policies, and that is why we, as Socialists and Democrats, have presented to the citizens with strength and conviction a model, the result of years of work, which is of fairness that I would call sustainable, and will be the basis of all our action at European level. , because neither citizens nor the planet can wait any longer.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, when I see this title, for the involvement of workers and citizens for a planet, let us say sustainable, I think that we have a good example in France, where the taxation of fuels has triggered a popular insurrection called yellow vests. Make no mistake because it is a real social movement. An investigation by Le Monde showed that more than half of it was made up by employees and workers. And what are they asking for? They express a desire for social and fiscal justice for the losers of globalization, an aspiration of the people to be heard in the face of the perceived contempt of the elites. So, more democracy, more participatory and direct democracy. This must still ask us about the Europe we want to build, because there is still a fiscal and social harmonisation for an ecological and solidarity transition of the continent. It is often the European Union that is rejected in its neoliberal logic, made up of deregulation and deregulation. It is therefore essential that fiscal and environmental justice become our new creed if we are to succeed and if we want to involve citizens and workers.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Madam President, first of all, of course, I have a very cordial thought for all the victims of the attacks. Our century faces an unprecedented challenge, that of adapting to a natural climate cycle that is that of warming after a small glaciation, but also of wiping out 200 years of globalization, of blind and outrageous industrialization. This was done by not respecting men or their environment. Today, there is an action to be taken and a price to pay, but it is not up to citizens who are jostled and impoverished to pay for all these excesses. It is up to these large companies, which are certainly job-generating, but whose goal is rather to make unbridled profits and which are all fiscally domiciled in the cloud. It's making fun of people to talk about energy transition when you put the cart before the oxen. Untenable goals and emergency constraints are new sources of poverty, that's what the yellow vests tell us. Let's start by sharing energy storage technology, sustainable power grids, especially in Africa- this will clearly limit immigration and the importation of indiscriminate terrorists. Let's give everyone an energy that allows us to stay and move around at affordable prices and that is not a luxury that, if you heat up, you no longer pay your rent. It has been going on for so long that the street explains it to us. Let us finally be responsible, let us listen to our fellow citizens and not cenacles...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for This is the right debate at the right time. I spent the first two days of this week at COP24 in Katowice, my home region, and yesterday, among other things, we talked about it in the Pavilion of the European Union. How to convince all citizens that our energy transition makes sense, and that makes sense to them. The point is that all our actions must be done for them and with them, not against them, because sometimes they do not take it well, and you have to keep that in mind. Such a good example, which we spoke about yesterday at COP24 in Katowice, is the establishment of this new fair transition fund for regions that are transforming from mining to regions with modern industry. It is very important to create such an opportunity for citizens from these regions, that is, as many as forty-one regions in the twelve countries of the European Union. I have proposed five billion euros of additional money in the budget, additional money, not combined from other sources, for such a fund, and it is worth it for the European Commission to make a legislative proposal and it is worth appealing to the Member States.  We must have citizens with us if we want to win the fight for climate protection, and the European Union is, after all, at the forefront.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on this day of mourning in Strasbourg and in Europe, our thoughts are with the victims and their loved ones and our thanks to the police and health services. Nevertheless, we must continue our mission. We are at a turning point in the future of the European Union and the just transition must be the new common thread in the future of the European project. To work for a just transition is to design an ecological transition in all its dimensions: social, fiscal, economic and environmental. What is happening in France shows us that there will be no ecological transition without social justice. The transition to cleaner mobility can only be made if it is not done against the working classes. We must accompany, not punish, we must redistribute rather than tax blindly. The people protesting are not against the ecological transition, they are not against the climate goals that we have adopted, but they are against the social injustice that results from liberal policies that undermine the acceptability of the ecological transition.  Nor will there be an ecological transition without fiscal justice. It is a strong and clear message sent by the citizens, the big multinationals must pay their taxes, they demand no more or less. It is an absolute necessity and we must take responsibility to make it a reality.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: –Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Allow you, the first general reflection, I am a bit surprised by the very title of the debate, which is 'involving workers and citizens'. We oppose, or exude, workers – citizens. I would have preferred this to sound like 'involving citizens' – citizens as producers and citizens as consumers because we are in these two basic functions, and if there are negative effects of even price and cost increases, citizens as consumers rebel, the 'yellow vests' that we are talking about, that is, the revolt of consumer citizens, not of producer citizens. At the same time, this approach to these two categories means that there is a higher class that is more aware, that is, the managerial class, or perhaps the political class, of rich people, because the citizen usually simply means a citizen, an employee as a worker, that is, from this point of view, I believe that our debate should generally go in this direction.  A safer planet: if people understand that a safer planet is safer than my city, a safer planet is my family's safer future, a safe planet is something that together will benefit us, then it seems that our goal will be achieved. And the transition itself - what we are guaranteed to do is change: there is an old transition period, people's awareness that this change in the right direction is needed.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is very clear that transition to a climate-neutral economy is the only possible way forward. Inaction is not an option. We owe it to ourselves, our children and the generations to come. We remain committed to involving workers and citizens in order to achieve a just transition. This means an effective transition in terms of emission cuts, as well as increasing renewable energy and energy efficiency. It also means a transition that leaves no region and no citizen behind. This transition is a clear opportunity for Europe to take leadership in innovative, sustainable solutions that will boost our long-term competitiveness and create jobs. It is an opportunity for green growth, which we should capture. However, to be accepted by the public this transition should bring benefits and opportunities to everyone – those in the cities and those in rural areas. We need a transition that is sustainable, in line with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and that provides a cushion and a safety net for those most affected. We should have the courage to acknowledge that this change will come at a cost, a cost which, in the short to medium term, might not be equally distributed between regions, between sectors or, most importantly, between people. That is why, in designing our policy response, social policy considerations should be included from the start in order to limit the deepening of inequalities. We also need sound data and evidence to underpin our policies. I am working with Eurostat to see how this can best be supported. Also, the next edition of our Employment and Social Developments in Europe (ESDE) report will provide an analysis of social and green investment and their role in growth, sustainability and resilience. The report will be published next July. Moreover, following methodology discussions, Eurostat, together with the European Investment Bank, has issued guidance on how to treat energy performance contracts in national accounts, so that they can have a favourable impact on investment in energy-efficiency measures. The European Union cannot achieve its ambitious climate agenda and fair transition alone: we need the support of the Member States and the cooperation of the social partners’ representatives. And we need buy-in because, through their daily consumer lifestyle and their daily choices, everyone can contribute to the greening of the economy. The Commission communication on long-term strategy on greenhouse gas emissions, adopted just two weeks ago, outlines a comprehensive cross-policy response that will guide us in the next steps.

name: Juliane Bogner-Strauss
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, as mentioned before, the transition to low-carbon economies will be challenging for certain sectors, regions and also for communities, but it will also be a chance and it will present new opportunities. It is important to find a way to match the opportunities to the challenges, as well as to ensure an adequate level of support for those who really need it. The process will need to look at the environmental, social and the economic aspects together as part of a whole and ensure the broad involvement of all stakeholders.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The transition to a low-carbon economy within a few decades is a challenge for all countries. The decarbonisation of an economy that remains heavily dependent on fossil fuels entails, among other things, far-reaching industrial and technological changes. It forces the development of new energy patterns, new business models and the need for circular generation and consumption. There is therefore a consensus that the implementation of the Paris Agreement requires a profound and rapid change in the way we produce, transport and consume.  From the point of view of workers, the transformation will profoundly transform the labour market, creating both new risks and opportunities. The sectors and regions most dependent on coal may be affected more than others. It is therefore crucial to ensure a 'just transition'. The lack of inclusion of workers and citizens in the debate on the transition of the economy towards a low-carbon m.in may result in social m.in, as we are currently seeing in France. It is becoming increasingly clear that poorer citizens are the most burdened by the costs of climate policy. They are the ones who are experiencing increases in fuel and energy prices, because they cannot afford to buy green cars or increase the energy efficiency of homes and apartments. The costs of ecological transformation must be distributed fairly and the implementation process must include dialogue with employers, workers and citizens.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Written. – Tackling climate change is at the top of our European agenda. This will only succeed if it goes hand in hand with the fight against poverty and social exclusion. It is important that the sustainable transition is done in a social way, so that people with a smaller grant do not unilaterally foot the bill for our climate ambitions. I do not accept the price tag attached to the action on climate change, the unfair distribution of the burden. Many people are willing to contribute to a sustainable transition, but not if that has to be paid for with higher taxes on daily groceries, higher energy bills for people in rental housing and subsidies for solar panels for people with detached houses for sale. This is bad for the support for the energy transition.  We are calling for a European transition fund from which vulnerable regions can draw on the social costs of climate change. Then a green and fair transition can be successful in Europe. Sustainable development must become a social project of which compensation for poor people is a part. We must leave this world healthy for generations to come. At the same time, we are also responsible for improving the lives of those who now foot the bill.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for a joint discussion on: - Paul Tang's report, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Council's proposed directive on the common digital services tax system for products derived from the crazing of certain digital services (COM (2018)0148 - C8-0137/2018 - 2018/0073 (CNS)) (A8-0428/2018), and - Dariusz Rosati's report, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Council's proposed directive establishing the tax rules for companies with a significant digital presence (COM(2018)0147 - C8-0138/2018 - 2018/0072 (CNS)) (A8-0426/2018).

name: Paul TANG
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, the current situation is a slap in the face to people who want basic justice, namely that everyone pays a fair contribution, including the multinationals and the millionaires. It's a slap in the face to people who want us to contribute to children's schools, care for the elderly, neighborhood safety. The proposal to tax certain turnover of tech giants is a temporary but therefore necessary intervention. It is sometimes the largest companies in the world that pay the least tax: Amazon, Google, Facebook, but also Uber and Airbnb. In addition to the problems they cause, for example the distribution of fake news, they also fail to pay taxes, contribute to the collective provisions of and for everyone.  At the same time, public support for change is overwhelming. 720 000 people have signed avaaz's petition supporting the DigiTax proposal. More than 80% of the inhabitants of countries where governments are opposed, such as Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands and Sweden, say they support the proposal. The same more than 80% say that we should not wait for an international agreement. We must not give in to American threats. We should not limit the scope of taxes, but rather expand it with Netflix and similar digital content providers.  That is precisely the proposal of the ECON Committee. Netflix also has to pay taxes for its digital sales. In fact, I would like to make a case for increasing the rate from 3% to 5%. Only then will there be a level playing field between the digital company and the traditional large company. Because it is the digital giants that can pretend that they are not present in a country in order to avoid tax. Therefore, increase the rate.  The intervention is therefore necessary, public support is high and yet European countries are in doubt and refusing to reach an agreement. Incomprehensible. In a mutual agreement, France and Germany threaten to undress the proposal. Incomprehensible. Liberals and conservatives want a low rate. Incomprehensible.  The tax on revenue from digital services is temporary. I've already said that. It must be a prelude to a structural solution. A definition of digital presence, so that digital companies will pay income tax where they operate. To this end, the European Parliament has already called for the reports on the common and consolidated income tax. Dariusz Rosati's report is welcome and good, because that confirms that.
