We must be aware that the current income tax systems are completely dated and are not suitable in a time of globalisation and digitisation. Finally, the road to an international agreement. There is a very lopsided situation.  Currently, Google pays 86% of the income tax in the United States and only 14% elsewhere. So we do not have to count on the United States to come to our aid to rectify this skewed situation. We'll have to do it ourselves. On the contrary, a European initiative is needed to ensure that the American negotiators come to the table. This is precisely what is needed to ensure that the OECD talks actually have a chance of success. This is necessary to prevent each European country from doing its own business and introducing a DigiTax itself. The plans for this are already in the balance, but will only splinter the labour market. In short, a digital tax is needed for basic justice, a level playing field between companies. That can't wait. It's now and not never.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the package we are discussing today aims at filling an important gap that exists in the taxation system of the European Union, and especially in the Member States: namely, a large proportion of revenues produced by Internet companies, digital companies, are not taxed where the value is created. This principle that taxes should be paid where the value is created has been a long-established principle in the second half of the 20th century in all developed countries, and it was aimed at reflecting the traditional system of industry where companies were physically present in individual countries, and that was the reason for them to pay taxes. However, the emergence of the digital market and digital services poses important challenges to this traditional model of taxation, because it turns out that digital companies can provide digital services actually with very little or no physical presence in the country of destination. For this reason, the Commission and many experts from the Member States rightly noted that a large part of revenues created by Internet international giants who provide digital services in Europe is simply not taxed.  The report on the Council directive laying down rules relating to the corporate taxation of a significant digital presence is devised as a permanent solution, given the fact that international efforts to establish a global solution for digital taxation being conducted under the auspices of the OECD are not progressing at a satisfactory pace. In this situation, even though we are all – and the European Commission of course as well –interested in developing a common global solution and are prepared to work in the framework of the OECD to achieve such a solution because the prospects for getting this global solution are very slim and this task is difficult (it will take much more time than expected), the EU decided to come up with its own proposal. This proposal is, first of all, focused on the definition of the digital services. These services differ from the traditional provision of services in three important aspects. First of all, these digital businesses are allowed to provide services in the country without any physical presence. Secondly, they rely heavily on intangible assets such as user data. Third, the value in those services is created because of the users’ use of respective digital Internet networks.  So these are the three characteristics that distinguish digital services from the traditional services. As a result, the Commission proposes that, instead of using a physical presence, there should be a definition of a significant digital presence, which is defined in the draft directive by three criteria which are well explained in the document, and on the basis of these three criteria the countries will be able to define the revenues that accrue to that country and these revenues will be taxed as regular corporate taxes.

name: Juliane Bogner-Strauss
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for the opportunity to contribute to this debate.  Let me start with digital taxation: I would like to give you a brief overview of the work of the Austrian Presidency, and I would like to summarise the Ecofin Council outcome and the next steps, as we see it. All Member States agreed that the fair taxation of the digital economy is very topical. We also all agreed that, in the long term, this requires a global solution. It becomes more and more evident that global changes in economic models might require a larger overhaul of agreed international tax rules. If we design specific rules targeting only some of the digital business models, we risk not capturing all and not making the rules future—proof. International rules have to be adapted and this has to be done – preferably in an orderly way – by reaching international agreements with a wide scope, both in terms of ambition and in terms of the number of economies adhering thereto. There are discussions currently ongoing at the level of G20 and the OECD. The European Union is actively contributing to these discussions. The G20 has set the OECD the deadline of 2020. I believe this is a realistic deadline, and the OECD should be given a fair chance to negotiate and implement revisions to the international tax framework by that date. Keeping in mind the wider global context, it is our firm belief that, when it comes to interim levies, a common EU approach is preferable to unilateral national measures. Until now, 11 Member States have announced that they have, or shortly will have, a national digital service tax in place. We are convinced that, if we do not reach agreement on the EU interim measure, even more Member States might consider taking this path. We could see a proliferation of different national taxes with different rates and scopes. This could lead to the fragmentation of the Single Market and could harm the competitiveness and growth of the EU economy. In this context, the Austrian Presidency devoted considerable efforts to the Digital Service Tax Directive. All technical and legal aspects of the proposal were examined in great detail. Numerous meetings took place at technical, as well as at political levels – most notably at Ecofin Council meetings on 6 November and 4 December 2018. For the meeting of the Ecofin Council last week, we prepared the compromise text, which had the broad support of Member States. In our view, that compromise was balanced and legally sound, representing elements with the most support. Unfortunately, before the Ecofin meeting, we could see that we would not have unanimity on the text. During the meeting, two delegations – Germany and France – in an effort to constructively contribute to the discussions, suggested that we should continue discussing the directive, but with a narrower scope. We have not yet had in—depth discussions of this new suggestion, since delegations need to study it in their capitals. However, many delegations confirmed their willingness to discuss it. Therefore, as the Presidency, we will try to take discussions forward on that basis. The incoming Romanian Presidency is closely associated with these discussions and will be ready to seamlessly take over as from 1 January 2019. Last but not least, on the topic of digital taxation, I would also like to thank the honourable rapporteurs, Mr Tang and Mr Rosati, for their work on this and we welcome the fact that you will very soon adopt the two reports. On the second topic that you have proposed to discuss today – the need for a majority rule for taxation – I can be very brief. As the Treaties currently stand, taxation is subject to unanimity. I am aware of the passerelle clause in the Treaty on European Union. Should there be such an initiative on the table, it would be examined in accordance with the procedure foreseen by the Treaties.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is my task to represent my colleague Mr Moscovici, who is due to meet the Prime Minister of Italy in Brussels this afternoon for the current occasion. I would like to thank, with great respect, the two rapporteurs, Mr Tang and Mr Rosati, for two competent and, I believe, comprehensive reports which facilitate the work at European level also for the Commission and with which I can largely agree. That is why the Commission presented an initiative to this end in March this year. We are convinced that, in the digital age, the corporate taxation procedure in the Member States is no longer completely up-to-date in the European and world. In the analogue age, decomposition works very, very well for products and services, and thus also the fair allocation of sales, revenues and thus possible taxes. But in the case of digital services, this is increasingly difficult to do if there is no physical presence and when data derived from Europeans and European events leads to sales and revenues, but then also taxes outside Europe. This development will intensify. The share of global GDP through digital services and big data is increasing. There is therefore a need to analyse the situation and also to act to ensure the fairness of taxation and the stabilisation of revenue for public funds. We have therefore made two proposals to ensure fair and efficient taxation. I would like to start by saying that we are prepared to optimise and develop our proposals. We have made a mark-up and are always able to work flexibly on further development with the aim of reaching an agreement. One is the reform of the corporate tax rules in order to secure adequate profit shares and share of turnover for Europe. And it is a provisional tax – a provisional one – targeting the main digital activities that are currently missing out on an increasing volume of sales in Europe. I am pleased to see that Here and on other issues, Parliament and the Commission are allies. I would also like to thank the Presidency of the Council for a dedicated moderation of the debate in the Council, which I believe can be effective. The two reports , as I have mentioned, show a high degree of competence and broadly support the Commission's proposals. By deciding on these two reports here tomorrow, you are sending a clear signal to even more hesitant Member States to speed up the debate in the Council as well. We think that the Franco-German initiative can be helpful here. Paris and Berlin have proposed to limit the scope to advertising revenue in order to reach an agreement here by spring next year, with the aim of bringing a corresponding digital tax into force on 1 January 2021, but to do everything possible in time to reach international solutions at OECD-plus level. The digital tax, if there is no solution at international level, would come into force in January 2021 and would expire in 2025. The likelihood of an OECD agreement is to be left out, but since the US is a major OECD partner and has so far disproportionately participated in sales and revenues, I do not think a solution at this level is very likely. The other argument that needs to be seen is that the trade dispute with the United States, which we want to avoid and have so far avoided, could become a little more likely. We will have to weigh this up in the coming months. The Paris and Berlin proposals are not quite as ambitious as those of the Commission, but a chance to reach an agreement. We have agreed that the tax should be temporary. We agree that the optimal solution should be structural and global – hence the OECD level as the next level of discussion. And we must agree that the absence of an agreement would lead to a disorderly approach, with 10, 11 or 12 or more national solutions. This would be a fragmentation of the European, especially the European Digital Single Market. The digital tax dossier shows once again that it is extremely difficult to resolve tax problems within the framework of the unanimity principle. That is why, at the beginning of next year, as announced by President Juncker, we will propose to this House, in the State of the Union address, the decision-making process for a qualified majority in the tax field. This would enable us to act, and we could also be able to act more quickly and with a high probability of results are coming. Examples where the majority principle would be useful are the proposed common consolidated corporate tax base, the reform of VAT law to create a single VAT area and the reform of digital taxation. A transition to qualified majority voting would also broaden the scope of tax policy in Europe. We believe that taxation can help to achieve general policy objectives – in environmental protection or in the field of energy policy, in the rural sector, and financial transaction tax, energy taxes or climate taxes are examples of this. It would also be democratic progress. In a Union of 28 or 27, unanimity is not really practicable; it has become cumbersome and counterproductive. That is why we are asking the House to respond with benevolent interest to our proposal at the beginning of next year.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, the design of a stable and modern fiscal framework is essential to open up digital opportunities for individuals and businesses in a market of more than 500 million consumers, that of the European Union. The objective we wanted to defend in this report is for each company to pay its dues and, moreover, where it belongs. What we can in no way allow is for digital companies to pay on average less than half the corporation tax than traditional companies. This is an injustice to our SMEs and it is an injustice to all citizens.  The proposal put to us by the Commission , which we support , imposed a 3% tax on the revenues of large technology companies, with the aim of establishing rules of fair play between the digital sector and the traditional sector. We reached good agreement in the Committee on Economic and Economic Affairs, with a series of commitments to keep the tax at 3%, while extending the scope so that more companies in the digital sector would be subject to this tax.  But once again, the Socialist Group is again in breach of its agreements and, unfortunately, has decided to break the compromise we made just over a week ago at the last meeting of shadow rapporteurs. He's worth his word and believe me, I'm sorry.  In the proposal we wanted to ensure that this is a temporary measure and I think the important thing is to work on a long-term solution – I am confident that not only at European level, but at OECD level – it guarantees the same rules of the game for all companies and not SMEs that suffer a competitive disadvantage.  Our role as a Parliament must be to contribute constructively to this debate, being aware of the complications that the Council is having. However, we must ensure that this measure strengthens our digital single market and not allow some Member States to decide to implement their own measures, while others freeze the proposal.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I say it directly: I am disappointed. Facebook shows 0% corporation tax in Austria, the international internet companies in Europe on average 10%. We must finally tax Europe fairly, and for that we need the whole package: tax transparency, the EU corporation tax and the digital permanent establishment. The Austrian Presidency has not made a single progress on taxation. Tax transparency: no interest. EU corporation tax: not a priority. Not even the minimum version of the digital tax was enforced. That, of course, makes me disappointed and angry. This is politics at the back of taxpayers. This is simply unfair, and we should not allow ourselves to do so any more. The unanimity of the Member States on tax matters must be abolished, and then we can finally put an end to this dangerous policy of blockade.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which This proposal is a bad proposal, and it is ill-conceived and does not get any better by the fact that the Social Democrats, in particular, are arguing here with very strong populist prejudices, which can all be refuted if you think about it in more detail. Each of us is in favour of a fair and fair tax regime, and each of us is against tax evasion and tax avoidance. But we must first of all state that tax evasion and tax avoidance are, of course, a much more important phenomenon than limited to the digital economy. In other words, a digital tax is certainly not the right instrument to combat tax evasion and tax avoidance. We have other instruments for this, and we should use them to do so. However, the question also arises as to whether the starting point that taxation is currently unfair is correct at all. After all, what is taxed for? After all, it is taxed for companies to use a country's infrastructure – a country's public services. If digital companies do not have a physical presence in a country, one has to ask the question: is it not natural that they use less public infrastructure than companies with a physical presence?  Is there really a distortion here, an unfairness, as everyone in this House is so recklessly talking about? In any event, the Commission has failed to prove that there is unfairness. She did not say how we should measure fairness in this case at all. What is being proposed is something that would be very complicated, very expensive and very bureaucratic. And it is not clear that we are improving in any way. In fact, the profits from digital activity are, of course, taxed, but perhaps not at company level, but only after distribution to shareholders. But taxation is, of course, taking place within the framework of personal income taxation.  It must therefore be said that this is actually a distribution albattle. It is a struggle for distribution between different states. It is difficult for the European Union, on the one hand, to brand unilateral measures by Mr Trump in the context of protectionism and, on the other, to call for unilateral measures itself.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, we can see that digital companies can easily be taxed where they want, regardless of where the value and profits are created. The current tax framework does not match the developing business models in this era. We must, therefore, change the current system and make taxation fairer. There were two proposals on digital taxation, which were overwhelmingly supported by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs last Monday. The first proposal for a digital service tax, which is meant as an interim measure, will ensure that the revenues generated by user activity on certain digital services are taxed in a fair, efficient and transparent way before a comprehensive solution can be reached. The second proposal offers the comprehensive solution to reform corporate tax rules, so that profits are registered and taxed where businesses have significant interaction with users through digital channels. It is, therefore, hard to believe that the Council was unable to reach an agreement and has been watering down the proposals, including the scope, and has postponed the decision. The Council Presidency spectacularly failed. We can also see that it is mainly those Member States who benefit from profit-shifting schemes which are the ones who are against these proposals. In this area the European Union is clearly paralysed and will regret it dearly. As the European Parliament, it’s crucial that we send a strong message to the Council and to all European citizens that we care about fair taxation. Fair taxation is one of the ways through which we can broaden the benefits of globalisation by reducing its negative impact.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the When I meet in Germany, people always ask me: Yes, when will the digital tax finally come? Because the European public expects politicians to do their part to improve tax justice. For example, in 2014, Apple had to pay 50 euros in taxes in Ireland on a €1 million profit, or 0.005%. Every bakery and hairdresser on the corner pays more, and people rightly feel that this is unfair.  It is finally time for the internet giants such as Google and Facebook to make their fair share of tax revenue. It is up to politicians to make these companies accountable. The European Parliament has once, in rare unanimity, gone down the road to the introduction of a digital tax. Clearly, there are different positions as regards the specific design of the tax, the tax base, the amount, etc. In the end, however, a solid agreement was reached, until – yes, until the Council announced that it would postpone the rollout until the last day of the year and then only to levy it on the advertising revenues of digital companies.  Yes, where do we live? That is where the German and French and other finance ministers come along and pull the European Parliament by the nose through the European Council. Who else is to be able to explain this to people? Let us send a strong signal to the European public tomorrow that the European Parliament wants the digital tax! But let us also send a strong signal to the national governments that tax justice is a must and that they must abandon their blockade!

name: Eva JOLY
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, how much longer will citizens have to wait before Europe puts an end to tax evasion and Google and Amazon pay their fair share of taxes? While the feeling of fiscal injustice reaches its climax, the immobility is unbearable. But the solutions are there. For years, I have been fighting for the adoption of unitary taxation of multinationals, a real revolution to stop the fiscal hemorrhage. I am told that nothing can be done because of unanimity. But it is not inevitable to let a few states take the public interest hostage. Those behind this argument are the useful idiots of those who engage in tax evasion. For, with political courage, it is possible to circumvent unanimity without changing the treaties. Section 116 allows, when there is a distortion of competition, to pass by a majority. Mr Juncker and Mr Moscovici, what are you waiting for? The credibility of the European Union in this fight is in your hands. When digital giants pay less than 10% in taxes, compared to 23% for traditional businesses, when some states improperly recover tax revenues from neighbouring states, there is distortion of competition. By dint of wanting to achieve unanimity at all costs, Europe is making a fool of itself...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is undeniable that in recent years the large digital multinationals have taken advantage of very favourable, sometimes even scandalous, tax mechanisms, if we compare them, for example, with other economic and productive sectors. I therefore welcome action to redress the balance of the system, but always paying attention to two strong points. Firstly, it must be absolutely not the case that these companies dump these burdens on to final consumers. Furthermore, I am very sceptical about initiatives imposed from above by Brussels: business taxation must remain a national competence and it has become clear that, in the Council, the various countries rightly defend these prerogatives. I believe, in any case, that a global agreement in this area at G20 level is desirable, but, if this is not possible, I would like it to be the individual countries that intervene, perhaps in a coordinated way, but without any imposition decided in these European for a.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, the internet giants, GAFA as they say, are also giants of market capitalisation as well as aggressive tax optimisation. However, all companies should pay their fair tax contribution in the countries where they make a profit. The dematerialization of their activities therefore requires a new definition of the territoriality of the tax, whatever the name it is given. We must free ourselves from a definition of stable establishment which is now totally obsolete and inadequate. To get around the deadlocks, my colleagues - some of them at least - are calling for an end to unanimity in the Council. I think the problem is the other way around: it is the expectation of a hypothetical European text that is holding back the adoption of national laws. The European Union is an obstacle here. European tax havens, including the country of the President of the Commission, will do everything in their power to kill or distort the text. This is on a very good track, if I believe the Franco-German compromise on the table. Italy and the United Kingdom did not wait and passed their own legislation. The others, especially France, would have to do it quickly. I would also like to add that all the policies that have been carried out so far, including by the majority of this Parliament, have contributed to the manufacture of captive taxpayers, notably normal citizens, small and medium-sized enterprises, on whom taxes have continued to accumulate to the point of becoming unbearable. You also have your share of responsibility for the ongoing tax revolt...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, the European Union devotes a lot of energy to fighting tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering, and I guess this is the right policy because these are among the most important economic topics today, and we have achieved many successes. We have approved the Anti-Tax-Avoidance Package, we have improved administrative cooperation, we have reviewed anti-money-laundering legislation, and so on. At the same time, however, as the Commissioner mentioned, we have failed to move forward on big issues such as a common corporate tax base and VAT reform, and I’m afraid the digital tax may become one of these failures. The so-called digital tax does not deal with the problems of tax evasion, fraud or money laundering: it simply addresses the problem of the inadequacy of our tax regimes, which are not suited to providing governments with revenues in the 21st century. Economically speaking, we are talking about instability and erosion of the tax base. This is not just a problem of the digital economy, this is a problem involving so-called distance sales, intellectual property and global companies. To find a globally sound solution will be difficult, and the fact of negotiation does not mean that we have the solution. We have just two options: either we go for something that will be reasonably good and functional, or we give up and leave it to the Member States to devise their own solutions – probably with the end result of fragmentation and of smaller states being disadvantaged.  I am definitely for the first solution, even though it is not an optimal one.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their excellent work. What we can see now is that we have a corporate system in Europe and in the world that doesn’t fit the realities of the 21st century. The fact of the digital giants we are discussing today paying no, or very little, tax on their income in Europe is a disgrace vis-à-vis our citizens and our welfare states. It has always been our aim to have fair taxation, putting the burden not only on citizens but on all of the participants in society, which are benefiting from society. The digital giants benefit a lot when they do business in our single European market, and therefore it’s high time that we stopped the big hole of their paying no tax or very little tax in Europe. The digital services tax is just an interim proposal until we have a better global solution, that’s clear: but the governments that are now turning their backs on this proposal are, in a way, lobbyists for the big tech giants. They are not on the side of the people who are, of course, demanding that these tech giants also pay their fair share of tax. Recently, in the TAX3 Committee, we had Google, one of the big tech giants, at our hearing, and they told us bluntly that they pay 85% of their global income tax in their home market, as they call it, the USA. But you all know that there are more users of Google in Europe than in the USA, and worldwide the discrepancy is even bigger. What we see here is a big problem, and what we are doing with this digital services tax, and with the permanent establishment rule is to solve some of the problems in the shorter term. We need an overhaul of the whole corporate tax system. We need to show citizens that, in the European Parliament, we are standing up for them and we also need to point out – to name and shame – governments who are on the side of the big corporates instead of the side of the citizens. That’s why we need to support this proposal and put maximum pressure on the Council.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: Mr President, dear people, it is not possible for internet giants, often American giants, to come here in Europe to make huge profits from our data, without paying enough taxes. So I agree that now is the time to modernize our tax rules, to adapt them to the digital age. But this can best be done on the largest possible scale. If Europe wants to tackle this on its own, then our competitiveness can suffer, and that is why we must look first and foremost at the OECD.  Now, if an international solution proves really impossible, then we must make joint agreements on this in Europe. These reports that we are voting on today have some good ideas, but also some of the things we simply disagree with or need more research to see what the impact will be on our economy.  Let me conclude to be very clear. I do not want this issue to be misused to further fund the European Union itself. I do not want the European Union to collect taxes itself. It is the Member States that are responsible for their fiscal policy.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, the social market economy model is based on the following trilogy: investment, labour, consumption. Only investment creates jobs, only employment increases consumption, only consumption growth increases production, thus generating new investments, new jobs and new consumption. This is the trilogy of economic development and social progress.  The State should not intervene in the market that works like this, except to correct some of its deviations or excesses or to address some of its shortcomings. One of these deviations is the possibility for some economic operators to obtain high profits and income, often due only to the cunning use of certain market constraints. It is precisely here that the State can intervene through the taxation mechanism.  I therefore support the Commission's proposal and welcome the work of the rapporteurs to create a tax on digital companies operating within the European Union and making scandalously disproportionate profits from their investments and job creation.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Mr President, the digital economy has been one of the most dynamic sectors of the economy and has provided enormous benefits to consumers in terms of diversity, quality and price of the most varied services and products. However, it must be recognised that part of this dynamism and competitiveness is based on profound tax inequality in relation to companies selling equivalent products and services. The big companies in the digital economy have been living in a kind of virtual offshore that allows them to pay very few taxes in the places where they are based and none in the countries where they do business. I am in favour of introducing a digital tax on the basis of equality in corporate taxation, a tax that is indispensable for the financing of the social and economic functions of states. I also hope that this will be the beginning of the movement for the taxation of all companies benefiting from tax privilege schemes, whether in the European Union or outside.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This digital tax has jumped as a tiger and landed as a bedsheet. Originally, the tax was supposed to apply to 180 digital companies, and now the big players, such as .B. Amazon and Apple, are to be spared. A digital tax that does not apply to Amazon and Apple is a bad joke. The federal government's delaying and watering down the digital tax is a serious and costly mistake.  But even this poor minimum compromise has now failed in the Council. This is the real problem: unanimity is paralysing European tax policy. Let us therefore overcome this unanimity! Even today, the Treaties make it possible to decide in the majority procedure in the event of serious market distortions under Article 116. So let's not wait any longer! Let us introduce the majority procedure in the field of taxation! Mr Juncker, Mr Oettinger, Mr Moscovici: it is up to you to finally clear the way for this.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Mr President, the fiscal hemorrhage of multinationals is an economic crime against nations. The shortfall in tax revenues for France has amounted to 100 billion euros per year for the past ten years. This tax plunder is greater than France's annual budget deficit. This public money that does not fit into the state coffers must be compensated by the bosses of small and medium-sized enterprises and the middle and working classes. European Union rules are directly responsible for multinational tax evasion. Before freedom of movement of capital and harmonization of corporate law, this problem did not exist. And the absurdity of the unanimous vote on tax matters allows rogue states like Luxembourg and Ireland to hack into the public finances of their European neighbours, with the complicity of the European Commission and its president. For all these reasons, as a Euro-reformist patriot, I am strongly in favour of the changeover to qualified majority in the Council on tax matters. Against this impotence of the European Union, it is imperative for our European countries to impose the digital giants as a matter of urgency, through a tax on the turnover of multinationals such as the digital services tax. We must free our citizens from the unfair tax yoke that strangles them...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr President, in the run-up to the European elections, a wave of panic is spreading among The Europeanists. Our European governments promised social Europe; whole sectors are sacrificed on the altar of the single market and full free trade, the European peoples on that of fiscal austerity.  They promised us the Europe that protects; we are experiencing an unprecedented migration invasion and Commissioner Avramopoulos has gone to sign the Marrakesh Pact. They promised a Europe of defence; our armies are subject to NATO. And now we are promised fiscal Europe but, once again, the European machine has become enthrlyer. Germany fears retaliation against its car industry, Ireland losing its digital attractiveness. Minister Bruno Le Maire has learned this at his expense and the mountain will give birth to a mouse, despite the good intentions contained in the reports we are debating.  Once again, the European Union is showing its impotence on a major issue. While GAFA make delusional profits that escape decent taxation, making a handful of billionaires happy, the yellow vests have no choice but to shout their anger at the tax injustices they are the victims of.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, no one can dispute the fact that a reality has developed around the taxation of digital-selling enterprises where states are unable to effectively tax the activities of these companies, resulting in both tax avoidance on their part and the creation of unfair competition for traditional businesses. But the solutions proposed, I believe, are wrong and at the same time impractical. There is no way that all the countries in the world will agree on a single taxation of the digital economy and they will quite rightly not agree, as taxation is, among other things, one of the pillars of national and state sovereignty.  On the contrary, I believe that the appropriate solution is to introduce a physical presence obligation for those companies wishing to sell digitally in a particular State where transactions will normally be taxed, as is the case for traditional companies. This is a serious issue and we must address it immediately, in response to the fair dissatisfaction of small companies and citizens who also bear the bulk of the tax burden.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, with regard to the taxation of digital enterprises, I am now hesitating between dismay and fury. To end the massive tax evasion of the digital giants, two approaches were possible. The first is to deal with the problem at the bottom. Using the instrument that was already on the table, the plan to harmonize the taxation of corporate profits in all sectors in all Member States and, to this Commission proposal, Parliament had added the concrete way of taxing digital multinationals. If your country, Commissioner, and mine had made this text their top priority, no other Member State would have been politically able to oppose it. Unfortunately, this is the second approach that has been chosen: the invention of a provisional indirect tax at a paltry rate. We were told that this solution would have the merit of being simpler and quicker to get adopted. A year later, the project is in a coma. And the worst part is that the window of opportunity that had been opened by the LuxLeaks and other scandals is closing.  Our citizens do not like taxes, we are aware of this in all countries, but no subject is as popular in Europe as the taxation of multinationals and, sorry, this cynicism, especially american and Chinese multinationals. This opportunity has been lost, we are all in danger of paying dearly for it in the next election.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, by voting on the two reports on the taxation of large digital companies, the European Parliament is taking the measure of the challenge we face. We know that digital businesses are under-taxed, and our citizens know that as well. The Commission's figures speak for themselves: 9.5% in corporate taxes last year, while the average European business figure was 23%. Multinationals in particular evade tax by positioning their head office where the tax is least tax-free.  As these large companies have a comprehensive strategy, we need to develop a comprehensive tax strategy. That is the proposal we are making and that is what citizens ask us to do when they speak out; I invite you all to look at the number of them who have been brought to sign Avaaz's online petition. The result is impressive. So when the Member States hide behind each other's difficulties, they do not listen enough to the noise that is rising in our Member States. The Commission has proposed a rapid response to these expectations, with a tax on digital services. Mr. Lamassoure finds it unrealistic because it is modest. It was a possible initiative, this European Parliament, in any case, played the game to make it credible, including by widening the field, even if, in this house, some thought that it was necessary to cover only half the field and leave Amazon and Apple or Netflix outside this field. We hope that this can eventually be changed.  Finally, on the rate, the Commission's rate was actually modest, 3%. We propose to you, we give you the chance, Mr Lamassoure, if you find this proposal too modest, to vote tomorrow with us on the amendment to raise this rate to 5%. Meanwhile, in the Council, under the ill-inspired influence of the Franco-German compromise, we see that nothing is moving forward and we believe that this is a serious fault. We believe that the Council's setback...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, revolts and revolutions often arise from indignation at the distressing spectacle of fiscal injustice. We in France know something about this, since at the moment the yellow vest movement is a testament to this acute sense of fiscal inequity and the mobilizations that this generates. But if there is indeed a scandal in the world today, it is the total impunity enjoyed by multinationals that pay almost no taxes, who are champions of tax evasion or tax evasion and this threatens our social pact. I add an argument to our discussion is that we are all algorithms, we work for GAFA, we work for free for GAFA because they use our data to make money and make a profit. Of course, it is time to act, it is urgent to act, and when I see the cowardice of some Member States, the hypocrisy, the slowness, the immobility of the processes, I tell myself that, decidedly, we are not up to the aspirations of our fellow citizens, so we must move fast, we must go strong.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by You do not understand that taxes are pass-on. All taxes imposed on bakers are paid by bread eaters and taxes imposed on digital service providers will ultimately be paid by consumers of these services. We are seeing at the moment how they are deploying cars and buildings angered by the "yellow vests" in France because of too high taxes on fuel. Do you want to do the same on the internet? Do you want people, as they get caught, to come here and turn over these blue stools to you and throw you out of those blue stools? Keep doing it. You want to collect again where you haven't sown, impose taxes where it's unnecessary. Taxes need to be lowered for others. If there's any inequality in taxation, let's lower it for the others, not raise what's wrong with someone making money. What is wrong with the fact that we have so many free services on the internet, precisely because they do not reach there is your regulation.  What you want to do is step by step turn the internet into what we have in the real world, into the bureaucratic, taxed and inefficient economy that you have funded for Europeans.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Parliament is once again making progress. As early as March this year, the report on the common consolidated corporate tax base provided us with a response to the challenges of digital taxation. Tomorrow we will adopt two reports: the transitional solution of a digital tax on online revenues and the long-term preferred solution of a digital permanent establishment. We are doing this because, firstly, we are concerned with fairness, fairness within the EU and fairness by the European Union, fairness within the internal market. Secondly, we are concerned with justice, with justice between young and old. On average, the big internet giants pay 1% corporate tax, and a small and medium-sized company pays an average of 26%. This injustice must be eliminated. Thirdly, we are concerned with the European Union's ability to act. We can only achieve the ability to act if taxes are paid where the added value is made. On the one hand, the debate shows that only together can we stand up for tax havens, tax evasion and tax justice. We need an elimination of unanimity in all ....  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, my view differs from that of most of my colleagues here and from my own Group. First of all, to tax American companies in Europe, just because they are currently taxed in the USA and not in the European Union, is not a good argument. It turns international logic upside down, it risks reprisals against Europe and it will not help the very difficult relations we have with the USA today. However, to change the logic and tax the turnover instead of the profits is a way of hindering the emergence of new companies. This has nothing to do with digital or non-digital. Moreover, trying to identify specifically ‘digital’ companies at a time when everything is digitalised – when the car industry is producing computerised vehicles, for example – is trying to draw an artificial line that will hinder development in Europe. But also, and this is serious, if we change the logic of international taxation to require that companies pay tax where they have their sales and turnover, this will damage the export-orientated economy and it will damage all European companies exporting to other parts of the world. It will, in the end, lead increasingly to taxation – digital or not – of European companies in China, in India and in the USA, rather than helping European taxpayers.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: – Chairman, colleagues, Google, Amazon, Microsoft, Facebook: they all have a market capitalization of over $400 billion. Apple even exceeded the $1 trillion mark this summer. A thousand billion dollars, that is almost double the GDP of my country, Belgium. Digital companies, colleagues, provide informative services. They create huge revenues, without having to employ many employees. Walmart, for example, employs 100 times more people than Facebook, but is only worth half as much. And who creates those huge profits? Those innovative companies, sure, but at least all of us. We provide these companies with their most valuable production factor, namely data. In our completely outdated tax system, this is not taken into account.  So it is only logical, ladies and gentlemen, that we should also tax them correctly, and the only way to do that is that we would do it together. How much longer are we going to let Europeans play apart? If we can be united with the British, why can't we be united towards Google, for example? Are our SMEs worth so little that we tax them on average almost twice as much as those multinationals? I'm not naïve. I also understand the considerations of many countries, including my own, but I firmly believe that if we really want to answer all those people who come out on the streets to claim their share of the cake, injustices like this must be put out of the world, and rather today than tomorrow.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Commission can well understand the expectations and also the annoyance of many Members present here. Our strategy, supported by you, has three objectives. Objective number one: to reach an international agreement, but not only on the next two years, but within the next two years. In order to build pressure on this and to have our own solution in case there is no agreement at world level, we have made our proposal and we are working to get it adopted unanimously. In the beginning there were 10, 12, 14 Member States, but in last week's discussions there were 24 of the 28 Member States. There are still four Member States missing on the road to unanimity. My colleague Mr Moscovici will do everything possible to reach an amicable solution here with all the Member States in the coming weeks. Thirdly, the principle of unanimity is a general problem. That is why, with the communication at the beginning of next year, we want to show ways in which the majority principle in tax law can be introduced at European level. I take this very much into note Mr Giegold's thoughts.

name: Juliane Bogner-Strauss
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, as regards digital taxation I would like to reiterate that for the Presidency this is not the end of the road. There was, unfortunately, no unanimity, but there is enough support to continue work. A meeting at technical level will take place next week. In preparing the meeting we are maintaining close contact with the incoming Presidency to ensure a smooth hand over of this work. As regards majority voting, as I’ve said before, if there was an initiative on the table it would be examined in the European Council, in accordance with the procedure foreseen by the Treaties.

name: Paul TANG
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, yes, there have been missed opportunities for those that say that we should wait for an international solution. Remember that, in 2015, the OECD started a discussion on taxing the digital economy, and it was blocked by the United States. We need a European initiative to bring the Americans to the table and discuss taxing the digital economy. To those that say this is not a good tax measure – yes, I am very grateful to Othmar Karas and Alain Lamassoure – we have a structural solution that has been put forward by the European Commission, that has been supported by the European Parliament: a common corporate consolidated tax base, which allows countries to determine where companies make their profits and where they pay taxes. So this is the only thing we are left to the table to bring forward tax justice, not in 2020 or 2021– no, in 2019. So that we have tax justice in which everyone pays their fair share, everyone pays – also the multinationals, also the millionaires, and most certainly the tech giants like Google and Facebook. Let’s give a clear signal from the European Parliament and support an ambitious digital service tax.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, I know this is a very difficult time to make a summary of the discussion, but let me but just raise two or three points. First, there is a lot of misunderstanding in this debate because we have two different proposals on the table – two completely different Commission proposals and some of the speakers have completely mixed them up and discussed them as one. This is not the proper approach.  Second, to all those who question the rationale behind the need to tax digital companies, let me give you just one example. Google representatives admitted at the hearing before the TAX 3 Committee that they pay tax, profit tax, corporate profit tax in the US to the amount of USD 6.5 billion, and for the same number of users in Europe they pay only USD 200 million a year. That means they pay USD 32 per user in the US and USD 0.4 but user in Europe. This is, of course, a question of fairness. Why should Europe give up such a large proportion of the tax due here? On the point as to whether we should go ahead of the OECD, I see no conflict between us working on a solution – a permanent solution – and the OECD making some progress. Of course, if there is a global solution, we are going to wind up our proposal. There is no question about that; we have to remember that.  And finally, let me tell you that this is not against American companies. This is only because the American companies are definitely on top of all digital companies. They are on the top because they make most of their profits outside the US, which is not taxed. That’s why they are so heavily capitalised. We want to restore elementary fairness and transparency in the taxing system and this is our main goal.  (Applause)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 13 December 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Alyn SMITH
text: in writing. – It is right that digital business, especially that conducted by GAFA, be taxed on the same lines as businesses in other economic sectors, in the place where they conduct business. Given the nature of digital activity, where value is being added, costs assumed and profits made constitute matters lacking the clarity found in other economic activities. This makes it possible for GAFA and others to fudge their income statements and avoid having so as to pay taxes on their profits. In these circumstances it is legitimate to introduce a tax on their sales, where these occur, to curtail and eliminate such tax avoidance.  While this report supports the introduction of such a tax, it does so as part of a strategy by which, on a European scale, we move towards a harmonisation of taxation, not least by putting in place the tools that would make such harmonisation easily possible. On the grounds that taxation should remain part of each Member State’s sovereignty, I therefore voted against the resolution as a matter of non—negotiable principle. Also, I doubt whether taxation of sales of digital business need be contemplated on a European – as contrasted to national – scale.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is Voting Time.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This has just been corrected. Until now, it was Amendment No 1 cp, so that there were no errors. Amendment No 20 is now on standby.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would kindly like to see a check on 30D, as we have asked for in several colleagues. Thank you.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
