name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the basis of statements by the Council and the Commission on conflict of interest and protection of the Union budget in the Czech Republic (2018/2975 (RSP)).

name: Juliane Bogner-Strauss
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, let me assure you that we agree that it is of the utmost importance to apply strong mechanisms to protect the Union’s financial interests. Where the Council agrees to finance research, infrastructure or small and medium-sized enterprises, we do so on the understanding that this will improve the living conditions of our citizens and the competitiveness of our companies. We cannot allow money to be spent in an inappropriate way. The Council is therefore a strong supporter of legal initiatives that strengthen the protection of the Union’s financial interests, such as the recent creation of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) or the Directive on the fight against fraud to the Union’s financial interests by means of criminal law. The investigation into individual incidents and allegations is, however, the task of either national prosecutors and judges or the European Anti-Fraud Office and, in future, as already mentioned, of EPPO. I cannot therefore formulate any Council views on specific cases of fraud or corruption allegations. I will however listen to your debate attentively.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The debate gives the Commission an opportunity to inform you of the state of play that interests you are about possible abuse of European programmes in a Member State and a possible conflict of interest here. We are taking a comprehensive and unbiased approach to the matter. Let me briefly briefly present the various periods: the most important current period is that of 2 August this year. Since then, the new Financial Regulation adopted by this House and the Council and the new Article 61, which has strengthened, or could say, strengthened the definition of a conflict of interest have been strengthened. It concerns the direct, indirect and shared management of European budgetary resources.  As far as this period, since 2 August, is concerned, we have made clear to the government and the head of government of the country concerned our legal opinion, touching article 61 of conflicts of interest, by writing to the government and the head of government. We have received an initial reply and will now evaluate it further. Importantly, during the period of the new Financial Regulation, no European funds have been disbursed to the Member State concerned and/or to projects in the Member State concerned. In other words, since 2 August we have not seen any budgetary relevance in the implementation of the 2018 budget. We have also made it clear in a letter that, until the legal situation is satisfactory from our point of view and the conflict of interest has not been resolved, we have no intention of elaborating. Secondly, in our letter, we also made it clear whether and, if necessary, the obligation of the person concerned to remedy and resolve the conflict of interest can be complied with.  A conflict of interest under the Financial Regulation means that that person concerned must refrain from any act which may conflict with those of the Union of his or her own interests. The person must take appropriate measures to prevent a conflict of interest from arising with regard to the tasks falling within his or her remit and measures must be taken to remedy situations that could objectively be perceived as a conflict of interest. The new rules will also apply in the case of shared management, and they are, first and all, a matter for the national authorities. According to the Financial Regulation, their task is to establish, maintain and take measures to prevent conflicts of interest. This obligation concerns the Member States as a whole. We have therefore also taken measures to inform you accordingly, to give you advice, and we are monitoring the measures that are and have been taken.  It is also clear, however, that this is not just a matter for the national authorities, but the Commission – our services – is responsible for protecting the Financial Interests of the European Union and therefore also has the power to take appropriate action in this area. This is done in the Commission by the Directorates-General REGIO, AGRI, Employment in contact with the Legal Service and the General Secretariat, as well as DG Budget, the authority that is my responsibility. We have received a number of official complaints for the period since 2 August, including from a Czech parliamentarian, Transparency International, and the Prime Minister concerned also addressed the matter in a letter to us. We will fully clarify the issue with the aim of resolving conflicts of interest and not making any payment from the 2018 or 2019 budgets by then. The second period is that before 2 August, which I would like to divide into the time when people concerned were not yet members of the government, and the time when they were ministers in government or were also prime ministers. We divide these periods very precisely. We have arranged through our services for a comprehensive audit to be carried out, which our officials will also carry out on the ground on several working days in January.  What is it about, if you look at the volumes, if you take into account the two budget periods 2007 to 2013 on the one hand and 2014 to 2 August 2018 on the other? We are talking about several programmes, we are talking about the second pillar of our agricultural policy, we are talking about the ERDF in our coalition policy, and it is about the ESF, the European social policy, to the smallest extent. AGRI – our Rural Development Programme – when adding both periods, involves 115 projects with a total volume of European funds, i.e. our co-financing size, of total of EUR 12.4 million in both budget periods. These are 115 projects for which we have co-financed. A further 26 projects have been approved, but not yet paid. If you look at the projects co-financed from erDF – regional policy – and from employment, from ESF, a total of 76 projects with 44.3 million – added – total payments from the European budget are involved in the 2007-2013 budget period.  For the current budget period 2014 to 2020, again REGIO and Employment, there are 26 projects with a total volume of currently just under 3 million euros.  As I said, for the period after 2 August, we will work to ensure that, in our legal opinion, the conflict of interest is eliminated, avoided and no payments are made until then. We will review the entire period – from 2007 to the end of 2013 and from 2014 to August 2018 – through comprehensive audits by the above-mentioned Directorates-General in January, and then provide you with a comprehensive progress report and an overall assessment. We have overseen my letter to the Prime Minister at the end of November, Mrs Gräßle and Mrs Ayala Sender, and we are also happy to forward it, within the limits of the agreed confidentiality, to all other ordinary and deputy members of the Committee on Budgetary Control, if desired. We would like to draw attention to the necessary confidentiality, which has been agreed. What I could also offer you would be to make our announcement to the services in Prague – that we and how we and when we and how far we carry out audits – in the coming days.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Thank you very much, Commissioner, we are happy to accept all these text announcements. I have not yet made the letter available to colleagues because we were expecting a response from the Commission. Therefore, the letter can of course be viewed from afterwards under the agreed confidentiality conditions. This is an item on the agenda on which we must show our colours. I would like to say that, in budgetary control, we are following developments in the Czech Republic with growing concern. We have been dealing with this conflict of interest since 2014 and have already put down resolutions here on several occasions, and have written passages in the respective discharge reports. It's time for something to happen. That is why, Commissioner, thank you very much for taking up this matter and for letting clear words follow. We can see that we now have a payment to the companies of the former Finance Minister and Prime Minister. These payments increased from EUR 42 million to EUR 82 million. There is a saying in Germany, a beautiful song: the boy sat at the source. The Finance Minister was head of the audit authority for EU funds and has been shown to have interfered in the work of these authorities. The Prime Minister now chairs the Structural Funds project body and is thus sitting at the source himself. In my Member State, we would also have a criminal assessment for this: it would be infidelity. That is why the Czech authorities really must ensure that they do the work that all of us, the whole of Europe, expects of them. It would be very important for us to follow the financial side, but the Czech authorities should also pursue the criminal aspect. I have a very good impression of the state of the Czech authorities and also of the Czech press. We have seen for three years – Commissioner, I have told you – a rather lacklustre European Commission. However, we are now pleased that the current last amendment to the Financial Regulation really does lead to something. And, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, it would be up to you to take this debate forward in the Council as well. I know it is a difficult dossier. However, precisely because the credibility of the whole of the European Union is at stake here, you are called upon to take action. We welcome the study by the Legal Service and your letter, Commissioner, to the Czech Prime Minister. But we are also calling for action now. And the deed is this: no more money to Agrofert as long as this construction continues, where, firstly, equal opportunities are massively damaged, secondly, competition is undermined, thirdly, self-service is operated on EU taxpayers' money and, fourthly, the suspicion of tax evasion and infidelity that hovers above everything has not been dispelled. I am also talking about the tax-free crown bonds of 2011 and 2012. What shocks me is the way we are danced around on our noses. There have been many lies. Yes, I met the Prime Minister as Finance Minister at the time, and I believed him. And that was a mistake, because then we also stopped the work over a very long time. But he has announced and delivered nothing of what he promised. And now, I fear, it will be the same again. I am disappointed with the ALDE Group. Mr Verhofstadt stands here and rails with a big bohei against Hungary, and rightly against Hungary. But I would have expected Mr Verhofstadt to sit down here and call his friend, his Czech friend, to order. We expect something to happen here – not out of partisan activity, but because it is a question of the hygiene of this House.  (Applause) We meet the whole world with our index finger raised. The rule of law is important to us, and the rule of law is a test, especially in the Czech Republic. Something has to happen here! I am campaigning for the adoption of the decision tomorrow and I am asking for a broad majority.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, it is clear that we need to establish a more ambitious strategy to combat potential conflicts of interest, which are not massive, but very worrying, and so we have seen them for direct management. And there you have some example of commissioner of the People's Group, which is there and which has even appeared in the roles of Panama, Mrs Grule. You each time you say to me, "I'm going to do it, I'm going to do it." But the thing is, he doesn't. In shared management: regional governments, local governments and the Government also of Mr. Babis, of course. In indirect management: the day before yesterday we were clearly told that the internal audit of the European Investment Bank, headed by Mr Hoyer, also had potential and serious conflicts of interest.  Not to mention other institutions. The Court of Auditors. There we have Mr Pinxten, in which case we have also had problems of conflict of interest. Not to mention emblematic companies such as Volkswagen, also with some conflict of interest and with European funds and aids.  Then it is clear, Commissioner, that we need a strong and modern comprehensive strategy adapted to the fight, to the prevention and management of conflict of interest, in order to also regain the confidence of citizens.  More than a case-by-case basis, as is the case with Mr Babis, who only exasperating Euroscepticism and populism, what we need is a sound strategy with maximum transparency and which certainly complements the rule of the rule of law.  And in this case it must also be acknowledged that the Czechs of Transparency International complained to OLAF that OLAF did its job, and that the project has been withdrawn – which I am afraid will fall on the backs of the Czech citizens – and the rest is under-iudice. That must be acknowledged, too. And I thank you, Mr Oettinger, for explaining this to us in your responses to discharge for 2017.  (She agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. –Mrs Sender, may I ask you: Do you therefore think that we should not therefore address this conflict of interest of one of the politicians? Is that what you're saying to us here that we're not actually "dealing with anything and dealing with something else"? Is that why S&D may not have supported this resolution? And can you explain to me why even the Socialists of Malta are in the Panama Papers and why you don't want to deal with it?

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Zdechovsk, I think you have spoken without hearing me and that worries me, because what I have said has been the opposite: that what concerns me is that we do a case on a case-by-case basis, a cherry picking, which only does it appear in the newspapers once in your favour, again in my favour. That is not the point, it is precisely a question of offering a solution to all the conflicts of interest that are appearing as mushrooms and which, in the end, end up rotting the trust of our citizens. That's what we're demanding and that's what we're trying to accomplish. And a casuistic resolution from time to time, well, it seems very well to me: I support it, there is no problem. We are going to table our amendments and we are going to support it, but with that we will not fix the situation, maybe we will have some more vote in your favour. That's what I want, to be understanding, to be able to deal with all the cases, those of your opponents and those of my opponents.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: on the ecr group. – Mr President, I will speak Czech here because I will primarily address the Czech audience. I apologize in advance to the interpreters that some deadlines may be difficult for them to translate.  First of all, I would like to say that we, opposition Members from opposition parties, have not brought this issue to the European Parliament. It was brought in by a group that does not even have any Czech members, and I think that this is clear evidence that this is not a reflection of the Czech internal political struggle, but that there is indeed a suspicion of a conflict of interest on European soil concerning the use of funds from the European budget. Unfortunately, it resonates from the highest places, that is, mainly from the place of prime minister of the Czech Republic. What's going on? The Prime Minister was one of the key economic players, he managed a large group that had a significant position on the Czech market in terms of agricultural production, food industry, chemical production, and this group was also a big beneficiary of subsidies from the European budget and these were really gigantic amounts. Although the Prime Minister, formerly as Finance Minister, has formally and legally cut himself off from this business in the form of a trust fund, it does have close associates, family members, so there are some doubts as to whether he is continuing to influence this concern. Of course, as Commissioner Oettinger said, there are also stricter rules that have been in place since 2 August this year, and therefore the matter needs to be properly investigated. If I can appeal from this place to supporters or voters or the Prime Minister's fan club, it's really not a campaign at the moment, it's not a purpose-based one, it's not a conspiracy. The point is simply that it is necessary to investigate whether someone is playing "small houses" here, or rather in this case a "big home". I think that you, too, the voters and supporters of the Prime Minister, should be interested in the economic side of things, because there was a time when politicians in the Czech Republic resigned on far less suspicion. The second thing that needs to be addressed is the subsidy system at all. What is the purpose of subsidies, whether cohesive policies or the common agricultural policy? It's economic convergence. If we have countries that have 130% of gross domestic product per capita, and at the other end of the country that are below 50%, then we have to try to compare them a little with those European policies. I am afraid that if the system is set up in such a way that large groups, such as Agrofert, can be the beneficiaries of European subsidies, then we will never achieve this goal. This is therefore an appeal to the Commission to think a little about the way subsidies are allocated in preparation for the Multiannual Financial Framework for the next period and to think more about SMEs, small and medium-sized enterprises.  I'm not happy that we're discussing the Czech Republic here. I am of the opinion that dirty laundry should be washed at home, but on the other hand, the whole issue concerns European money, so the European Parliament is the place where we have to talk about it and we have to. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I agree in part with my colleague Zahradil that dirty laundry should be washed mainly at home. I would just like to ask, because he was the representative of the party in charge of the Czech Presidency and wanted to sweeten it for Europe, if he still insists that we should weaken Europe.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr Colleague, First of all, I think that dirty laundry really should be washed at home, and that when the prime minister discussed a possible conflict of interest or influence on the media, I was very strongly opposed to it, and I said that this is exactly the issue that we are supposed to resolve at home. But here, in this case, it is about money from the European budget, so it just concerns the European Union. With regard to sweetening, as you mentioned, I just think that every country should have the right to express its opinion on the future direction of the European Union as it sees fit. You can call it sweetening, seasoning or using any other metaphor, but I would certainly insist on that right.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, we are discussing here today a serious issue. The Commission is in communication with one of the Member States, examining a potential conflict of interests which involves the Prime Minister and concerns the use of EU Structural Funds. I do believe that in such a situation it is critically important that we carefully look at the facts at hand. The Commission’s legal analysis concludes that the Prime Minister, Mr Andrej Babiš, is in a situation which occurred and may objectively be perceived as a conflict of interests. This is based on the financial regulation that applies since August this year. Commissioner Oettinger, when questioned by the Committee on Budgetary Control, made it clear that it is now up to the Czech authorities to address the situation, based on written guidance from the Commission. From the perspective of my Group, it is important that solutions are swiftly found and systemic measures taken so that the situation is brought fully into line with EU legislation. We have a first written reply from the Czech government that signals that the authorities, and the Prime Minister personally, are aware of the gravity of the situation and conducting an analysis. This analysis should obviously be followed by the necessary steps to solve the situation. It is now up to the Czech authorities to do so and to take measures to remove all concerns and doubts. To my EPP and Green colleagues, I would like to ask you not to fall too quickly into the trap of painting all the European countries with the same brush. We obviously need to have all facts on the table and take actions based on that. Do not jump straight to conclusions where we put an equal sign between systematic undermining of the judiciary as in Poland and Hungary and what we are seeing in the Czech Republic at the moment. By jumping too quickly to conclusions, you risk both diverting attention away from the real issue and in the long run do the European project a great disservice. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr Torvalds, you are an experienced politician I want to ask you: you said it was up to the Czech authorities to deal with this situation. But the Legal Service of the European Commission has made it clear that the Prime Minister has a conflict of interest in relation to European Union legislation. Shouldn't the Prime Minister and the owner of Agrofert address this situation?

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: blue-card answer. – You have probably also read the letter Prime Minister Babis sent. In this letter, he clearly states that he is aware of the situation and therefore he is part of the Czech authorities. So, with a calm approach to the problem, I think we could actually find a solution which is not a double standard solution as we have seen in some of the other cases.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, in this House we often talk about money, money from the European Union, financial interests of the European Union. These discussions affect people, because that european Union money is, of course, taxpayers' money. Whether it comes to the European Union through VAT or national payments, citizens in the European Union all contribute to the European budget. Often it is people who find it difficult to make ends meet.  That is why reports of conflicts of interest or fraud are getting extra hard. We are right to make tougher demands for respect for the rule of law when european funds are spent. We want the public to be able to trust that their money is being spent properly. In the case of the Czech Republic, irregularities have previously been detected in connection with the Stork's Nest case. And now there are renewed indications that there could be a conflict of interest and that the Czech Prime Minister is personally benefiting from EU funds.  No one is guilty until proven guilty, but we must be confident that investigations are taking place both in the Czech Republic itself and through OLAF which are independent and thorough. We have a right to have Parliament well informed. I would ask the Commission and the Council to do so.  Finally, one general call to the Commission. After 2015, no anti-corruption report on the Member States and on the European institutions has been published. Parliament has repeatedly asked for this, and this issue shows once again that this practice must be resumed. I ask the Commissioner to take that up again.

name: Bart STAES
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, european citizens expect politicians to behave as responsible directors, because citizens want good and transparent and good governance. Citizens want an active fight against corruption. Citizens want transparent governance in full independence. Citizens want a government separate from conflicts of interest. Citizens do not want their political leaders to see the European Union as an ATM machine, as an ATM where money can be taken away, where business and political friends can be enriched.  That is the context, ladies and gentlemen, against which this debate is taking place. How do we protect the Financial Interests of the European Union in the Czech Republic? How is conflicts of interest dealt with in the Czech Republic? And how is it avoided unfairly stealing European money through their business empire?  This is not the first debate. As Mrs Grässle said, we have adopted several resolutions in the context of the discharge procedure. Commissioner Oettinger, I thank you for your reassuring words from the other day. It is a good thing that no funds have been paid to the Member State concerned since August 2018. I am also pleased that you are saying that there is an audit for the funds from 2007-2013, 2013 to August 2018 and that you will work there with your services to see what needs to be done. An audit is one thing. Once that audit is in January, what's the timing? How will you act quickly? How will you ensure that action is indeed taken and will it continue before the 2019 elections?  Commissioner, you also say that the Czech authorities have to solve everything ourselves in the first place, but we have mr Babiš' letter in response to your letter, and in it, Mr Babiš says: we had a cabinet council on 3 December and we have seen that Czech and European legislation are not being violated and I will behave towards European legislation, but the Cabinet says that there is no problem. How are you going to fix this? This isn't normal, is it?

name: Jiří PAYNE
text: on the efdd group. – Mr President, subsidies are wrong and unfair. Subsidies attract crime, there is even a strong suspicion that there are no subsidies that are not related to crime. Good deeds are to be done for private money, not public money. If someone wants to do a good deed and public money, then as a donor, they are fully responsible for all the criminal consequences that this causes. I find it very unfair for the Commissioner here to say that the Czech authorities have to deal with this matter. This situation was caused by the European Union granting subsidies and by not checking the conflict of interest in advance before granting the subsidies. This means that he cannot now blame the situation on the Czech authorities. The European Union is guilty and the European Union must resolve this. If we are to look at how subsidies are granted and how they are managed in the European Union, I would like to recall that years ago a group of Members dealt with the management of the European Union and concluded that around EUR 5 billion is lost annually in the European budget without a trace, without any accounting records, without any information on what happened to the money. This is how the European Union manages. So let's not be surprised that a similar situation occurs in the Member States.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the Czech Prime Minister, Andrej Babia, is accused of a conflict of interest by the European Union. Owner of a group of companies specialising in agri-food, chemicals and media, he is said to have paid his companies around 100 million euros in European funds allocated to the Czech Republic. This charge is very suspicious. I have several reasons to believe that it is driven by a desire for political persecution. A shrewd businessman, Mr. Babio knows the world of finance and business, which is why he is well placed to describe the euro as a bankrupt currency. This assessment is all the more a sham for the European Union as it leads to the Czech Republic's refusal to join the euro area. Even more serious in the eyes of the Brussels Commission, on 27 June 2018, Mr Babio made the fight against illegal migration the priority of his government. To President Macron, who blamed him, he replied this, and I quote: "No one will dictate to us who will live and work with us." As we know, for Jean-Claude Juncker, Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron, denying immigration is an unforgivable sin. As if all this were not enough, Mr. Babio finally has the audacity to define himself as a populist. The international press also calls him the Czech Trump and his party, which is called "The Action of Disgruntled Citizens", evokes a desire to revolt against the pseudo-elite that irresistibly reminds us of the French yellow vest movement. It is for all these reasons that I accuse the European Union of trying to persecute Mr Babio and the Czech Republic. Instead of trying to lecture the whole world, the Union should instead question its own practices and ask itself, for example, why it put at the head of the Brussels Commission, a man, Jean-Claude Juncker, who illegally deprived several European states of billions of euros of tax revenue for the benefit of his country, Luxembourg.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, conflicts of interest are one of the most serious systemic defects in financial operations within the budget. If, on the one hand, the Czech Prime Minister co-rules on the form of the European budget, if he can target European subsidies for large agrarian companies, and on the other hand, this Prime Minister is also the beneficiary of these financial gains, I think that this is an unquestionable situation of conflict of interest. Then something really doesn't add up. I dare say that such a huge conflict of interest with the Prime Minister of a Member State of the European Union has not yet known this level of ours.  This is not a matter of questionable interpretation of the regulation, as the Czech Prime Minister is trying to excuse. The interpretation is fairly clear. If it draws European subsidies, it must comply with European rules, which really hit each of us. We Members must insist on compliance with the established rules, the Guardian of these rules is the Commission. It is primarily the Member States that have responsibility for carrying out the checks, but the Czech Republic is failing completely in this control. Although a number of non-profit organizations draw attention to this conflict of interest of the Czech Prime Minister. The Commission must therefore take action. This undoubtedly has our full support, and At the same time I would like to call on it to proceed with a truly 'fall to whom'. We must protect European taxpayers' money, and I do not know how to explain that cohesion funds to eliminate disadvantages in support of weaker regions end up with a billionaire who is countless times richer than the average French or Swedish taxpayer. I expect that the interests of European taxpayers will be protected by the European Commission, and I just wish that this situation would not lead to a blanket cessation of the use of European funds in the Czech Republic.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Presidency, I would like to thank you for your comments Admittedly, I have listened with great satisfaction to Commissioner Oettinger's explanations on procedural matters, namely this stage until 1 August 2018 and from 2 August 2018. I understand that this has created very good grounds for expecting the Commission to simply proceed with its activities without any hesitation, and this has sounded very clear in the statements made by Mrs Gräßle, as well as by Mrs Inés Ayala Sender. However, I am, I must admit, quite confused by the statement made by Minister Bogner-Strauß, which means that the Council wants to recognise – not our case, the neighbouring Prime Minister, the Chancellor will not touch a fellow Prime Minister, we will see what you will figure out here. I would take a very clear position: this is our common interest: and the Commission, and Parliament, and the European Council, so understood solidarity, I will not say too much, it is not the best thing.  It is good that here too are not stigmatized Czechs, the state as such, just specific people called by name, I think this is a positive thing. I would expect a real response very quickly, Commissioner, and at the same time to show what will happen to these events that took place before 1 August 2018.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: – Mr President, it is time for some clear facts to be said here. Commissioner Oettinger, in the Committee on Budgetary Control, of which I am Vice-President, has repeatedly confirmed that the Czech Republic and the European Commission are working together to clarify the situation. The same words were spoken in our committee by Commissioner Creţu and Commissioner Hogan. The European Commission always stresses that it is following the set rules, and its conclusions certainly cannot be expected before all the facts are verified. If we do not have complete information in the Committee on Budgetary Control, how can we adopt a resolution in plenary on this matter? Why don't we let the institutions work? After all, we must also care that they present an impartial and objective position that will remove all concerns and ensure compliance with European law.  We should also leave room for the Czech authorities to find a solution. The legal situation, after the Commission has taken a position on the interpretation of the new Financial Regulation, needs to be assessed and a path should be found that works from the point of view of both Czech and European law. This, too, requires time and patience, notwithstanding the fact that the Financial Regulation applies to all Member States in general. The Czech Republic fully respects the legislative competence of the European Union as well as its obligations arising from its membership. The czech prime minister's letter to Commissioner Oettinger, who is talking about this, is also a document. It assures that the Prime Minister will "personally take all necessary measures to ensure full compliance with European Union law." All of us sitting here know that more information and concrete action cannot be obtained at this stage. And it's not going to help us with the leaks to the media or the messages we send through the media, or the shouting here in plenary. Is chasing cheap political points really the only thing we care about? Ladies and gentlemen, I think that, on the one hand, we are calling for strict compliance by the Member States, but on the other hand, we ourselves in the European Parliament are not setting an example by ignoring the facts and resigning ourselves to the rules and regulations that we are committed to following. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that you are so optimistic about this case. We are concerned here in the European Parliament. So let me just ask you one question: do you really believe that the Czech authorities can somehow resolve the situation when this is a potential clash between the prime minister of the country? See your Minister of Justice's opinion and other opinions issued by your ministers from your movement. I think that the European level is the only possible objective platform.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague, I am an optimist by nature. But for sure: I am not giving up on the European Commission having a say, I am just saying that we must respect the procedures and processes and we must wait for the official position of the European Commission. On the contrary, I am assured that both the European Commission and the Czech Republic are communicating intensively and are looking together and not at all for the interpretation of the new Financial Regulation. So that's what I'm optimistic about.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, the time of Christmas is approaching and therefore the period during which wishes should be fulfilled. My wish is that you take this from today's debate: the Czech Republic is not Andrej Babiš, Agrofert is not the Czech police, and the Czech courts are not the Stork's Nest. I am not going to stand up for Andrej Babiš, but for the Czech Republic, which does not deserve to be pillioned. The cases connected with our Prime Minister are being dealt with both by the Czech police and by the competent authorities of the European Union, as we heard today. Do you really feel the need to put political pressure on the Commission and OLAF? After all, at the beginning of the whole conflict of interest debate, there was an internal analysis of the lawyers of the European Commission and OLAF of Andrej Babiš. If the Commission decides that action needs to be taken, it will act. If OLAF decides to act, it will act. The Czech police, prosecutor's office and courts are also independent and will act if they provide evidence of criminal activity. So why the pressure from MEPs who cannot know the overall background to these cases? Political declarations are not to be commissioned by independent experts. The judiciary must be independent, and political pressure will certainly not help this independence, as it has never done in the past.

name: Julia REDA
text: – Mr President, it is good to see you Commissioner Oettinger facing our questions tonight, because the conflict of interest of Prime Minister Babiš cannot be ignored any longer. Mr Babiš became Minister of Finance already in 2014 at the time when he already owned Agrofert.  Agrofert is today the biggest receiver of EU subsidies in the Czech Republic and operates in several other EU countries. There are still some uncertainties about the relation of Mr Babiš towards the Czech legislation on conflict of interest, so the reasons to adopt new European financial regulations are clear: to definitely avoid these types of conflict of interests.  Today, thanks to the Czech Pirate Party, who was the first to notify the Commission, there is no doubt that Czech Prime Minister Babiš and Czech Minister of Agriculture Toman are seriously violating the Financial Regulation. National authorities of Member States are obliged to secure preparatory measures, audit and control of financial resources from the EU budget, but we can’t expect the authorities in the Czech Republic to be able to properly comply with such rules in a situation where both the Prime Minister and the Agriculture Minister have confirmed relations to companies drawing agricultural subsidies. This is why I call upon you to take swift and strict measures to control the flow of EU financial resources to the Czech Republic and to implement the necessary corrective measures to end this illegal conduct.  Such shameful conflict of interests of executive powers, who will actually participate in the European Council this week, have to be solved urgently in order to avoid further damage to the Czech Republic and to its people, as well as to the European Union.  (Applause)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, what a wonderfully nightmarish vision this whole debate is putting forward. You soak up billions of pounds— or euros—worth of taxpayers’ money into the centre, you then take that money and, politically motivated, redirect it into projects in countries you think it should be redistributed to. You then find out – because there’s such a huge amount, and it always would be the case with such a huge state, with such huge money – that sometimes it goes in directions you don’t like. Sometimes, it breaks the rules. On this occasion, apparently, allegedly, it would appear the Czech Prime Minister has been using it in a somewhat dubious way. All of this is then judged from this esteemed senate building and looked on. You decide what to do to the Czechs. You have a super—powered Commissioner, a powerful accountant, a real Superman of accountants, who’s going to rip open a nation state’s books to check through them. Having been in small business myself, this is a little bit like having the auditors turn up. It’s very frightening, I can assure you. Well you are doing that on a grand scale.  It boggles the mind as to what might happen, for example, if we had a ‘remain’ UK. What would happen? Would we one day have Theresa May’s successor dragged in front of the super—accountant who says ‘you’ve not spent the money the way we think you should’ – although most of the money actually goes the other way. It’s nightmarish to think a nation state could be in this situation, and to think that a supranational governance like you could throw money like this – millions upon millions – into something that you then afterwards realise might well be going to friends and family and being completely misused.  Then the whole point: conflict of interest. Well, I understand it in business terms but I can give you some more conflicts of interest that EU money is often used in, and it doesn’t get investigated. What about the conflict of interest of the EU funding of the BBC, who then publicised propaganda on behalf of the EU during the Brexit campaign and discussion and continued to do it? Surely that’s a conflict of interest. What about the conflict of interest of British political figures who’ve made money, employed legally, working within the Commission and other things? People like the Kinnocks, Lord Mandelson, who then engage in British debate about whether or not we stay in the EU? This is about what you think is a conflict of interest and what isn’t. If you can pay someone and you allow them to go forward to spread your propaganda, you think that’s okay. But if you’re paying someone randomly millions like this and then they do things with it in a way that most likely does seem unethical, you then want to clamp down with super—accountant. It is hypocrisy.  The truth is that when you have such a massive amount of money slushing around, even the greatest of organisations – which maybe this might one day be – cannot possibly run it effectively, efficiently without corruption. You can’t even get your own accounts signed off. So how can you then come down like this when you’re throwing money around at a government that may be corrupt? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague, do you consider it a conflict of interest if you are paid by an institution and an organisation and then 100% engaged in work against that institution and organisation?

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card answer. – If you believe in democracy and you pretend that this is a democratic building, and I assume you’re complaining about people like me campaigning for independence for our country, then I would say we’re actually elected in European elections, just the same as you and everyone else here, and we put forward a legitimate point of view that we wanted to leave. Guess what? We got a referendum which we won, and then people like you and others here and back in the UK are trying to undermine that. Hence the problem that we have the no—confidence vote tonight in the Prime Minister. If you don’t like democracy and you don’t like paying someone to do the same job as you, don’t have elections, and be honest and do what you really are: be an authoritarian state.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, paradoxically, this debate is not just about one person, it is about principles. And it's about the principles on which the democratic and rule of law is to be based. I would like to say that the Committee on Budgetary Control, of which I am a member, deals thoroughly with all suspicions. "Fall to whom" whether it's Orbán from the EPP or whoever it is. Paradoxically, this debate is also not intended to settle our problems with each other or to settle accounts before the election. This debate is supposed to open up the issue of conflicts of interest, and if I'm a politician once, I have to respect the fact that I can't decide how I'm going to hold benefits in a company or company, I think that's very clear. Andrej Babiš is not a victim in this debate. Andrej Babiš is the master's master in this debate. If it wasn't for his conflict of interest, this debate wouldn't be. I think that we have seen many times here that we simply have to open up these debates, otherwise these things will not move forward. Commissioner, the only thing I want from you is for you to act neutrally. Don't take anyone away, be neutral and finish this thing. Ladies and gentlemen, the only thing I want from you is for you to think about what we will do in the event of a conflict of interest. Honourable Representatives of the Council, I want you to be in the same way and unambiguous in other conflicts of interest. I think that is the only way we can restore the creditability of the European Union.  The last thing you can say is that it is a pity that Mr Verhofstadt is not here. Personally, I think that this is a man who is fighting for transparency and fighting for a better Europe. And if he wants to fight for her, he should be here. A blind man is not one who can't see, but a blind man is one who doesn't want to see.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: – Mr President, it is strange to talk about my country and a government in which my political party also participates. On the other hand, the second option that Andrej Babiš had was a government based on the far left – the Communists – and the far right. This is the sad reality of the Czech Republic and it also shows the pofidérnosti of Liberalism by Andrej Babiš. In my opinion, this debate should not come until sometime in January or February next year, when the Commission presents the conclusions of the analysis and when Andrej Babiš finds time to visit the European Parliament, because he cancelled his January trip. I think it is clear from the documents we have that Andrej Babiš is either still in a conflict of interest or he has solved the problem only "for show". This also applies to the media group that he previously owned and which is now being investigated by the Czech administrative authorities. You know, it's not just a conflict of interest, it's the Stork's Nest, the prosecution of the prime minister, his entanglement with communist state security. These are all problems of one person, which then cast a very bad light on the Czech Republic and de facto puts it in a very bad light even in terms of drawing on European Union funds.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, frankly, I do not know what the purpose of this debate is. Certainly, and I agree with you on this, we need to look at how we are legally interpreting the new regulation and how it is to be applied by all Member States. This is also in the interest of the Czech Republic. Therefore, standard communication between the European Commission and the Czech Republic takes the official route, which, as we have now learned, is not available to the management of the Committee on Budgetary Control. I will therefore not forgive myself for commenting on those who have made enormous efforts to move this issue to the plenary of the European Parliament. It cost some a lot of political effort. These are games that damage the Czech Republic itself in the first place, but do not contribute to the good reputation of the European Union in the Czech Republic.  So I wish everyone a peaceful Advent.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the If a member of the ENF Group defends Mr Babis by arguing that he is, after all, an xenophobic populist, so he must be right against the EU, then I can put that aside and say with Shakespeare: if it is madness, it has method. When the Czech Communists hypocritically defend a billionaire in their country whose anti-European sentiment they share, even though they can only move over big business, the same verdict applies.  What really shocks me, however, is when I listen to my colleagues in the Liberal Group. A colleague of the Liberal Group, whom I personally value, said that we should look at the real problems. If that is not a real problem, then we have all misunderstood something. And a colleague from the Liberal Group has just said that the Czech Republic is being damaged.  Should we really believe this totalitarian nonsense that a leader is being identified with the whole country? Is this liberal thinking? (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Perhaps before a colleague shouts at us here, he should clarify and find out what the situation is in the Czech Republic. Czech communists are fighting to make it easier for citizens to live better, to have higher wages, to finally abolish or at least tax shameful church restitution, not to sell property into not only German hands, and to have our own right to water and mineral resources. That is why the Czech Communists support Andrej Babiš, we stand by him and look no else for it.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: blue-card answer. – It might have been more decent if you had started with that little propaganda speech in the first place, because what you said before really destroyed any credibility that you might have had – even in the eyes of your own voters, because you punted for a corrupt person and you laid your credibility on the table for that. (Applause)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this evening we are debating a subject with which we Italians are unfortunately very familiar.  We are well aware of the harmful effects that conflicts of interest can have on a country's economy and democratic system. In Italy, they have caused enormous damage, killing competition and seriously influencing public opinion and the democratic process. Czech Prime Minister Babiš appears to be the controller, in fact, of the Agrofert Group, which has received and receives large sums of the EU budget. The same company also controls Mafra, publisher of two of the most read newspapers in the Czech Republic, thus extending the conflict of interest to the media as well. We know that OLAF's investigations should have been ongoing since 2014, but on 18 July, I would like to remind you, Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 entered into force, expressly prohibiting the award of European funds in cases of conflict of interest. We therefore call on the Commission to examine the facts thoroughly, to take action to enforce these rules – which are fighting a real democratic scourge – with the same speed and severity that it uses to address other issues. We do not want our Czech friends to suffer the same disastrous effects that we have had to endure in recent decades.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, I am sorry that I cannot share the speeches of some of my colleagues in the faction, but I regret much more that we have to discuss this matter here in plenary today, because it is damaging to the Czech Republic, its interests. But it is not their own, as the Czech Prime Minister said today in the Czech Parliament, that Czech MEPs are to be responsible. It is not even the fault of members of the European Parliament, it is not the Fault of the European Union, but it is the real situation in this matter in the Czech Republic, it is the inaction of the Czech Government and the Czech Prime Minister, and unfortunately the Prime Minister's comments about the Lying Analysis of the European Commission or his respect for Czech law do not contribute to this. I think that Commissioner Oettinger has been very clear today, and I think that at the moment the Prime Minister of the Czech Republic must act if he does not want to further harm the interests of his own country, and that the letter that the Prime Minister has sent on the basis of the government's actions is not convincing as to the content. I think that every voter who has analysed legislation and this letter sees that this is not a responsible approach. Last remark, Commissioner, I would like to invite you, even with the narrowed room for manoeuvre in dealing with this issue that you have, to look for solutions that have the lowest possible impact on the Czech Republic but, on the contrary, address the state of a particular entity.

name: Eva JOLY
text: Mr President, for our fellow citizens, the added value of the European Union is not always noticeable. However, there is one achievement of this mandate which we can welcome: the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office to protect the financial interests of the Union.  Unfortunately, we will have to wait until 2020 to see it work. I say unfortunately because, at the conclusions of the commission's legal services on conflicts of interest, the Czech Prime Minister could have succeeded an independent investigation by the European Public Prosecutor's Office, to find out precisely how the subsidies in question were awarded and spent. By diverting European funds from their primary objective, Mr Babio is not only depriving his country of much-needed funding, but is playing with all European citizens. Pending the implementation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, it is therefore up to the Czech authorities to conduct an independent investigation, it is the only way to recover this money and the trust of the citizens. It is a question of credibility, it is also a question of democracy.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I did not deliberately enter this debate because the Prime Minister is attacking us, the other politicians of the Czech Republic, that this is a political game. However, the debate today has clearly shown that this is a real problem described by the Representative of the Commission, described by Mrs Gräßle and other MEPs who are not from the Czech Republic. This is very important to make this clear today. This is a real problem in which European money is at issue, which is why the European institutions have the right to discuss this and, according to their legal possibilities, to solve the problem. As a person who has been Minister of Justice of the Czech Republic for five years, I am convinced that the Czech authorities simply will not solve this. If Andrej Babiš is prime minister, the Czech authorities have no chance of resolving this. I am very much begging you, Mr Oettinger, as a representative of the Commission, to do everything possible to resolve and investigate the problem impartially. Otherwise, it will be a major challenge for the Czech Republic to be an active and important country in the European Union in the future.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Mr President, we recently debated in the European Parliament about the situation of the media in the Czech Republic, today these are issues around the absorption of European Union funds. Both cases de facto concern the same – as measured by the election results – of the successful economic and political project of the election winner and the ruling party in the Czech Republic.  Its founder, with his huge multidisciplinary business empire, became a hegemon of Czech politics within a few years. In both cases, we get to the land of the law in force at that time in the Czech Republic. The question is whether this finding is sufficient and thus the matter is resolved. The traditional understanding of conflict of interest was so unacceptable that the intermingling of economic, media, and political power was so unacceptable that it was not necessary to emphasize them in any particular way. But what if the unwritten rules don't apply? We have lawyers for the one s written here, and the election winner has a mandate to set the rules. In the Czech Republic today, we may see a trend in politics, and elsewhere in Europe and in the world, whatever the lawyers decide on this particular matter.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I am not at all pleased that the reputation of the Czech Republic has come into the debate today, because there is no Czech Republic in the conflict of interest, but there is a prime minister in a conflict of interest. It's a conflict between the owner of Agrofert, it's a personal conflict. Here, neither the Czech Republic nor the European Union has failed, the one who has political influence on the distribution of funds from which it makes considerable financial gain. This is where the person who distributes these funds in the Czech Republic, who influences them at European Union level as a member of the Council, and who must also control them at The Level of the Czech Republic, has failed. I am very sorry that we have to have this debate here, but the European Parliament must act and the European Commission must also act. We can't look idle at violations. I thank Commissioner Oettinger for settling this case in a consistent way.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Mr President, I would also like to appeal to Commissioner Oettinger for the Commission to act impartially and objectively. As for some media cries about a lying European Union or something like that, it must be taken into account that the current Prime Minister Babiš recorded one sad record in the last parliamentary term, when he was Finance Minister, namely that the Czech Parliament at one point adopted a resolution on the Stork's Nest case, an explicit resolution that the then Finance Minister had lied to him. Parliament's resolution that the Minister is lying is, I fear, very sad.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am grateful for this intensive debate, which shows me how seriously Members from various positions take the matter and thus also have a high expectation of the Commission – for me, for my colleagues and for the Commission's services. I want to continue to meet this high expectation comprehensively in the coming weeks. We were asked why the anti-corruption report is no longer being presented. Freedom from corruption is an important factor in the state of administrations, governments and Member States. That is why we have made anti-corruption and the fight against corruption our own section in the European Semester and want to expand this further there. The rule of law, freedom of corruption, quality of administration in general are factors that should play an important role in country specific recommendations and before that in the semester. You will find out how we assess the state of corruption in the Member States, Member State by Member State. Secondly, it is, of course, a joint responsibility of the Commission. But Let me point out that our possibilities are limited in the operational business. Unlike national governments, we have no underpout. Our support for budget implementation is the Member States, the regions, their authorities, and this is all the more true when resources are shared. In other words, we take special action when we have reasons, suspicions, indications that things are not right. As a rule, we assume an orderly administration, a performance of tasks on the basis of European national law.  I would like to point out that Article 36 and Article 63(4) of the financial regulations state exactly that. I can read this here in English: [...] applied to shared management requiring Member State authorities to put in place effective internal control including the avoidance of conflicts of interest. In other words, it is a primary responsibility of the Member States, the regions, their administrations, and we are responsible when we have reason to be suspicious. That is why, because of this mistrust and the complaints, I now see every reason for the Commission to dig in– I will say so. That is what we are doing. I was asked: when will the audits take place? The Directorate-General for Employment will be in Prague from 8 to 11 January with a team of experts, DG AGRI from 14 to 18 January, DG REGIO from 28 January to 1 February and from 11 to 15 February. I then expect our services, after having full access to all the necessary documents, to report in Brussels to me and my colleagues.  And I can promise on the basis of the relevant question – Bart Staes asked this: I want to give this Parliament a comprehensive report by mid-April at the latest, that is, before the last plenary session here in Strasbourg, which you can then use for a debate and evaluation and commentary, if necessary. The Storchennest case has been raised. This was a project – I believe 1.8 million co-financing was requested. Following olaf investigations, the Czech Government withdrew the co-financing. My final point is that I want to do everything I can to ensure that my person, my colleagues and our authorities are extremely objective and do not engage in any form of domestic issues or even different positions, but that they try to win the trust of all Members from this country, but not only from this country but from the whole House. Thank you very much for today. In the new year, I am happy to answer your questions bilaterally, perhaps to respond to them again during the discharge, but, as I said, to report fully to this Parliament before mid-April. (Applause)

name: Juliane Bogner-Strauss
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, as I already said at the outset of this debate, it is indeed of the utmost importance that strong mechanisms are in place to protect the Union’s financial interests and that they are applied. I listened carefully to your debate and to the concerns you expressed. I also took note of the comprehensive explanations provided by Commissioner Oettinger. We will follow in particular the further steps that the Commission announced.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Four motions for resolutions have been submitted to close the debate in accordance with Article 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: – The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report with recommendations to the Commission of Tadeusz Zwiefka, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the accelerated resolution of commercial disputes (2018/2079(INL)) (A8-0396/2018).

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I would like to start by noting that the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs has consistently worked at all times to prepare and implement legal instruments for the functioning of European companies on the European market. This is an extremely important issue in the context of the various problems that arise during this interdependence and cross-border interaction. Why is it important to prepare an appropriate legal instrument at Community level? The differences between national legal systems and the resulting intricacies, particularly when disputes arise between counterparties, mean that such processes can take up to years. It is therefore important to give EU businesses the opportunity to resolve these disputes more easily and equally safely. A few years ago, the Committee on Legal Affairs launched this initiative to prepare European sales law, which had great potential in this context to help EU entrepreneurs. Unfortunately, this proposal was not welcomed by the Member States and the work was frozen for several years. However, we have made another effort to tackle these problems, particularly in the context of the changes taking place in the European Union in our market, especially in the context of the changes that will take place after Brexit.  In my report, which I am submitting to the House, I ask the European Commission to consider and prepare a legislative proposal for a new instrument in the form of a European accelerated civil procedure. The idea is that these disputes between traders can be conducted more easily and in a cheaper way. This procedure is modelled on the existing and introduced small dispute procedure. However, this amounts to eur 5 000, while the one we are proposing would go beyond that amount of EUR 5 000 and introduce the possibility of resolving disputes more speedily. What would this higher speed be? The fact that that procedure could be carried out in part at least in writing, that procedural action, in particular the hearing of parties or witnesses, could be introduced by the courts using the latest technology, that is to say, without having to go to the place where the case is conducted. Of course, we are not changing substantive law here in any way, then the cases would be conducted by the national court of the State competent to pursue the case. The small claims procedure has also been designed to enable European entrepreneurs to make a choice. This is a voluntary procedure. The parties could agree to it at the time when the dispute would arise, of course it can only be implemented if all the parties to the dispute agree to such a procedure. Of course, we know perfectly well that the key to doing business is its predictability, its security, thus legal certainty, and therefore we are turning to the European Commission, but also to the Member States, to consider making some kind of change.  It is for the European Commission, in particular, to consider whether it would be appropriate to make changes to the provisions of The Rome I, Rome II and Brussels I Regulations, on the basis of which disputes are currently taking place. It is also up to the European Commission, the Member States, to ask and ask them to consider some kind of action that would be complementary to this legal procedure, because the accelerated dispute resolution instrument alone would obviously not be sufficient.  The point is that the Member States should consider the establishment of chambers or commercial divisions in their courts, since the conduct of such cases by specialised judges, firstly, speeds up the procedure, improves the quality of the decisions delivered. It would also be a matter of involved in the continuous training of judges and lawyers in the field of commercial law. Focus on education in the areas of international law, private law and commercial law, but also on increasing funding for academic research on these issues. Consideration should also be given to member states reviewing the current procedures for commercial disputes. I hope that the European Commission will fully consider this proposal, which we are putting forward in the report on which we are currently starting discussions. I am, of course, open to all kinds of comments leading to an even greater and better improvement in the functioning of European companies in the single market.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Zwiefka, and the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) for their commitment to an efficient system for commercial litigation in the EU and for their work on this legislative initiative report. Indeed, there are a number of ideas which the Commission will consider and which we shall use in our future work because I can confirm today that the Commission shares the same objective.  Efficient and high-quality justice is an important pillar of the European Union. It is an indispensable element of a business-friendly environment which enables prosperity and jobs in the internal market.  In our work, in the justice scoreboard, data shows important differences in the length of court procedures between the Member States, and there is room to stimulate improvements. We share the view that well designed court procedures are one of the key factors of efficient justice. This is why we propose to modernise the rules on cross-border cooperation in taking of evidence and serving of documents which – once adopted – will shorten court proceedings and reduce their costs. I thank the JURI Committee for taking up these files and look forward to the first reading position of Parliament. We will look diligently at the proposals contained in the report. The recommendations contained in your report concern a number of actions, both legislative and non-legislative. Some of them seem to be designed for a longer—term perspective, like the creation of the EU commercial court. We will examine thoroughly their feasibility.  We certainly concur with this report which highlights the importance of judicial training. The future Justice Programme will continue to support the training of the judiciary and judicial staff as a tool to improve judicial cooperation in the EU and a specific objective of the programme will be dedicated to this. This will contribute to the building of the European area of justice by creating a common judiciary culture among justice professionals of the Member States. This is also important to ensure the correct and coherent application of law in the Union and mutual trust between justice professionals in cross-border proceedings.  Overall, I would like to stress that in commercial matters we need to hear the opinions of stakeholders who will be potentially directly affected by the proposed measures. Support, and even demand, from the part of businesses is necessary for success of the proposed measures.  Although we have achieved a lot in our work to strengthen commercial procedures in the EU, there is – as I said before – room for improvement. At the conference on the effectiveness of justice systems organised by the Presidency in Vienna two weeks ago, I stressed the need to improve access to justice, to modernise justice and thus to increase the trust of people in the justice systems. Ideas were put forward about how we can use digitalisation for the benefit of faster procedures and in the interests of both legal practitioners and citizens when claiming remedies.  I believe that the Commission’s work on effective justice systems, particularly on the EU justice scoreboard and the monitoring through the European semester, will help us to achieve these goals. I look forward to the debate.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, i would like to begin by thanking my fellow rapporteur, Mr Zwiefka, for drafting this good report. I am pleased with it, among other things, that this is not about any effort to regulate from above, but, on the contrary, it is about responding to demands from below, and i therefore believe that this proposal, if implemented, will show other European citizens the added value of European integration. If we create a European accelerated procedure for cross-border trade disputes, we will speed them up and thus respond to the basic complaint that entrepreneurs have. We want the solution to be faster and therefore cheaper. We want this procedure to be based on the principle of thorough pre-trial preparation of the parties, so that it takes place primarily in writing, so that the procedural time limits are as short as possible. I am aware that the ultimate success also lies in mastering technical details, such as uniform quality forms. However, we believe that this can be done and can be inspired, for example, by the already approved small claims procedure. I would like to ask the Commissioner that the European Commission take up this proposal with all its strength and determination, as the Commissioner has indicated, so that European entrepreneurs and traders are relieved as soon as possible.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work he has done and I would like to say to the Commissioner that in the JURI Committee we managed to have a debate that we consider important and effective, thanks to a political climate – which it would always be useful to have – of mutual respect, listening and research convinced of the necessary points of mediation. , of compromise, as they say in our language. The reasons why we have dealt with this issue are known to all those present here. The settlement of trade disputes in the European Union is still too slow, it needs to be speeded up and it needs to be based on the harmonisation of a matter, that of cooperation, for which civil measures are still very far apart in European countries. An accelerated civil measure for Europe has undoubted advantages: it not only removes the elements of conflict and potential conflict, but also becomes an opportunity for great resource savings, which companies can then use and reinvest in their own interests and in the interests of the people with whom they have a relationship, of all stakeholdes, starting with those who work in these companies. We are therefore talking about a procedure, as we know, which should only apply to disputes relating to relations between undertakings, that is to say, all those which have no consequences or aspects linked to the rights or conditions of other undertakings or workers. What is fundamental to us is that any procedure for the accelerated resolution of trade disputes established at European level ensures full respect for the rights of the parties, including the possibility, subsequently, of being able to activate a judicial process. We have defined that the character will be exclusively voluntary as far as the procedure is concerned and, therefore, we need the consent of both contractors. The choice of a procedure cannot be allowed before any dispute begins: this is important for contractual clauses or in commercial agreements between undertakings, because there would be a risk that one of the parties could influence the others by its decision, and the party influencing it is necessarily and objectively always the strongest, to the detriment of small businesses. We must therefore ensure that the solution we are proposing does not contain any risk of penalising the weakest in trade relations. This element is justice, it is democracy, and we are particularly committed to this, as we have shown with the proposals we have made and with the nature of the debate we have had.

So, once again, a very inspiring report. We will work with it; I will summarise for my followers all the knowledge and the things which should be covered by possible future legislation.
