name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report of Eleonora Evi, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the Annual Report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2017 (2018/2105(INI)) (A8-0411/2018).

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to err humanum est, to persevere with autem diabolicum, which literally translates as 'making mistakes is human, but persevering is diabolical'. How many cases of maladministration are afflicting Europe? So many, too many. In my experience as an MEP, this is the fifth year that I find myself commenting on the work of the European Ombudsman, this year as rapporteur for the European Parliament's report. This work, that of the Mediator, which is not only carried out with great care and rigour, but which is becoming increasingly crucial in guaranteeing the highest levels of protection of citizens' democratic rights, for which I thank you. Yet, as every year, we find ourselves here debating the new cases of maladministration that overwhelm the European institutions, without the mistakes of the past being used by this Europe to learn its lesson. Conflicts of interest, lack of transparency, 'revolving doors', lobbies and lobbying without effective controls, decisions taken behind closed doors are just some of the problems that this Europe still does not want to tackle in practice, increasing that sense of mistrust towards it and, consequently, the gap between citizens and institutions. The European Mediator's approach and the recommendations made have always been high-profile and constructive. Unfortunately, however, all too often the leaders of the European institutions have been indifferent to what they were asked to do and unwillingness to make substantial improvements on central issues on which the Union's credibility and image are at stake. The image of the 'glass palace' should be the beacon to be followed in order to remove all barriers between those inside and outside the palaces of power, in order to build a European Union that is truly based on respect for the principles of ethics, moral integrity and transparency. It is for this reason that in the report, in addition to retracing some of the most serious cases that marked 2017, I wanted to openly support the recommendations made by the Mediator, giving them further prominence and strength. We now need stricter rules on the integrity obligations that European Commissioners must comply with, both during and at the end of their term of office. It was a shock to the whole of the European Union that Mr Barroso, President of the Commission in the years of the worst economic crisis, took on goldman sachs, the business bank that was most involved in the very outbreak of that crisis. Therefore, the recent meeting, in October 2017, that the current Vice-President Katainen has made with Barroso himself and recorded as a meeting with Goldman Sachs is therefore also highly objectionable. This further gesture has made it clear that Mr Barroso, despite what he had done and his commitment not to lobby the EU institutions, has always managed to find open doors with the highest institutional leaders, ready to welcome him. The Barroso case is perhaps the most striking, but Transparency International, in its investigations, as early as 2017 indicated that 50 % of commissioners passed to work for very powerful private sector lobbies, including Bank of America and Volkswagen. If we also consider that there is a register of transparency on lobbying at EU level, which is burdened with very serious shortcomings and to which it adheres only on a voluntary basis, we can see how opaque lobbying activities are in the EU institutions and how unhindered the private sector can affect decision-making processes unhindered. In relation to this, the report called for a legislative act leading to the adoption of a compulsory and legally binding transparency register for all EU lobbyists and institutions and agencies. Stricter rules are also being demanded of the European Central Bank, in order to protect the integrity, reputation and independence of the institution from private financial interests, given that its President, Mario Draghi, persists in wanting to be a member of a club, the so-called G30, which operates in complete darkness and collects the gotha of the private financial and banking world, including the heads of banks under the supervision of the ECB itself. With regard to the Legislative Process of the European Union, the report calls for full protection of citizens' right to know the choices made throughout the decision-making process. There is still a serious lack of transparency in the trialogues, which are still completely inaccessible to the public, as well as in the procedures followed by the Council, where the positions adopted by the Member States on legislative dossiers are still not registered and citizens' requests for access to documents are rejected on time. The choice, which I consider shameful, to extend the use of glyphosate until December 2022 and the use of scientific data provided by the same manufacturer, Monsanto, in the procedures adopted at EU level for the assessment of human health risks led to the request of the Mediator for the immediate launch of an investigation, also extending to the EU procedures for the collection and evaluation of scientific data on GMOs , plant protection products and medicinal products. These cases are just some of those addressed in the report, which give us an insight into a highly deficient situation that needs timely remedies. Citizens must enjoy a European Union in which the duty of moral integrity is guaranteed in the behaviour of all its representatives, where a truly transparent administration is ensured and protected from conflicts of interest with the private sector. The citizens of Europe deserve a completely different European Union from what it is at present. Finally, allow me to make one final point: it is with regret that I welcome the many amendments tabled by the Group of the European People's Party, aimed at weakening the text and deleting and putting under the carpet many of these cases that we have talked about. I would like to thank the Mediator once again for her hard work, I thank all my colleagues for their contributions to this report, I thank my staff and I await the Commissioner's comment.

name: Emyli O'Reilly
text: Ombudsman. – Mr President, good evening and thank you, Madame Evi and all of the shadow rapporteurs, for your work on this report. Let me of course first express my deep condolences to the families of those killed last night in Strasbourg and send my best wishes to those who were injured. Our thoughts are with them and their families tonight and also with all the members of the army, police and emergency services who so often put their own lives on the line to protect ours. Thank you also to DG SAFE and the staff of this Parliament for their work in alerting us last night and for protecting our security. Honourable Members, as Ombudsman I help Europeans in their interactions with the administration of the EU institutions. Over the last five years, I’ve been able to do so only because of the engagement and cross-party support of this House. I also very much welcome the presence of Commissioner Jourová at this debate. As in previous years, accountability and transparency-related inquiries have accounted for the highest percentage of my office’s work. The EU administration has some of the highest standards of administration in the world, but as a comparatively young system the EU also faces challenges which makes it vital for its institutions, bodies and agencies to be as accountable and transparent about their decisions as possible. For example, while the Parliament is proactively transparent in its legislative work, the Council of the EU falls short of the appropriate requirements of transparency and participatory democracy that the Treaties demand. In an inquiry opened in 2017, I therefore called on the Council to improve the recording and publication of legislative documents so that citizens and indeed national parliaments can be better informed and hold their national governments to account. I subsequently sent a special report to Parliament to ask for its support for my recommendations, and Parliament is now working on a report on this subject to be tabled for plenary in January.  I thank the two rapporteurs, Ms Toom and Mr Leinen, and all other members of the two committees involved, who supported my report. This is a good example of Parliament’s ability to find common ground and work together when it comes to supporting my work and the accountability of the EU system. The draft Toom/Leinen report states that ‘greater openness on the positions taken by national governments may serve to alleviate the ‘blame Brussels’ phenomenon, which distorts the reality of how EU legislation is agreed, fomenting euro scepticism and anti-EU sentiment’.  The challenge that public administrations face in a time of widespread disinformation is also an issue that my office has touched on. In 2017 I hosted an event on EU agencies, how to manage the risk of reputational damage with the directors of EFSA and ECHA. These agencies are vital in the protection of our health and it is important that the important factual messages they send out have widespread acceptance. My work naturally requires me to highlight administrative issues which need attention, but I also witness all of the good work of EU officials and their willingness to learn and evolve following my recommendations and suggestions. Sometimes a gentle reminder can achieve more than a formal inquiry can.  In 2017 I published a practical dos and don’ts guide for EU officials on how they should interact with lobbyists and how they can protect their institution and the public interest. The guide is now being used by the Commission in its training for new staff and I want to thank the Commission for its support.  Honourable Members, to acknowledge the excellent work of EU officials, in 2017 I launched the award for good administration with more than 90 projects nominated. The overall award went to DG SANTE for its promotion of EU collaboration in helping millions of Europeans suffering from rare diseases.  A few weeks ago I launched the 2018 awards, which will be presented in spring 2019, and I look forward to even more entries so that best practice can be shared and citizens can be made more aware of the positive impact of the EU administration on their daily lives. Last March I hosted our annual European Network of Ombudsmen conference in Brussels, with the topic ‘Future of the EU – Ensuring an inclusive and fair society for citizens’. The annual event brings together over 90 European, national and regional ombudsmen to share good practice and to have the opportunity personally to interact with MEPs and with Commission officials at the heart of the EU itself. Dealing with complaints to my office, of course, is, and always will remain, the core work of my office. 2017 saw an increase in overall complaints to my office. 2 200 complaints in total and this strong upward trend has continued in 2018. While we have introduced new efficiencies, my office will, in the near future, require a modest increase in budget to hire more case handlers so that the expectations of our complainants can be met. As your report on my activities recognises, further examples of issues we have worked on in 2017 include: (i) our inquiry with the EEAS to stop unpaid internships. This was supported by the Budget Committee, and this means that the EU is now an example around the world, as it now pays its trainees; (ii) our inquiry into how the European Medicines Agency handles meetings with the pharmaceutical industry and before they submit applications for drug authorisations; (iii) our year-long inquiry into the ECB President’s continued membership of the Group of 30, a private group of senior bankers; and (iv) our ongoing work with the UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities.  Finally, I would like to thank everyone involved in working on the annual report for their work. The rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs, their staff and the secretariats. And thank you, the Members of Parliament, for supporting my office in its efforts to maintain the high standards of public administration in the EU. When so many standards and democratic norms are under pressure and are being actively undermined in many parts of the world, it is now more important than ever for the EU to continue to shine as an example of good administration.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Evi, for her work on the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2017. The European Ombudsman has been an essential part of the EU institutional architecture since 1995 and I would like to thank Ms Emily O’Reilly for her work to help citizens make the EU administration a better administration.  European citizens are entitled to high administrative standards from EU institutions and bodies. This is why the work of the Ombudsman in fighting maladministration is so important. Often, the Ombudsman acts as a facilitator or go-between to help solve concrete problems. The Commission is always ready to find solutions whenever it can. The figures speak for themselves. Only 5% of the Ombudsman’s inquiries end in a closing decision of maladministration. The compliance rate of EU institutions and bodies in general with the Ombudsman’s recommendation is also high, at around 80%, showing how effective the work of the Ombudsman is. The Commission takes swift action to address cases of maladministration and complies with the Ombudsman’s recommendations whenever possible.  Every administration can get better. There is a high willingness on the side of the EU administration to correct mistakes, to improve where necessary but also to take new initiatives in the general interest of the Union and the citizens. This also deserves to be said and acknowledged. This is why the Commission particularly appreciates the Ombudsman’s initiative for an award for good administration that she launched in 2016. As we already heard, the Ombudsman conferred the overall award to a Commission service, namely DG Health, and four out of seven specific awards to other Commission services. Please also allow me to say a word about transparency and ethical standards, since these topics are addressed in your report as well. I would like to emphasise that, in these areas, the Commission lives up to very high standards, often higher than in many other administrations. In the area of lobbying transparency, the Commission has led by example. To meet a Commissioner, Cabinet Member or Director-General, lobbyists must first sign up to the transparency register. In our proposal for an interinstitutional agreement, we have suggested to extend this principle to the Parliament and the Council. This would represent a major step forward towards greater transparency at EU level, as the register would become de facto mandatory for lobbyists.  The Commission’s ethical rules, enshrined in the Staff Regulations, prevent the risk of conflict of interest and ensure that Commission staff act impartially and for the public good. This was reinforced last June by a new decision on officials’ outside activities and activities after leaving the service. The new Code of Conduct adopted in January sets clearer rules and higher ethical standards for Members of the Commission, while also increasing transparency.  The Commission will continue to work with the Ombudsman to ensure good administration and maintain the highest possible standards of public service.

text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner and, above all, Mrs O'Reilly, Mrs O'Reilly, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for her excellent work. I say this so clearly because the figures reflect what is being done here, and because it should also be a sign to us as a Parliament that we are - yes - responsible for legislation and, yes, also for the control of the authorities of the European Commission, and specifically that we, as parliamentarians, are also called upon to represent citizens' concerns. , especially as a representative of the citizens in relation to the state sector. In this sense, Madam Ombudswoman, you can really serve as a model for parliamentarians. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her cooperation. She has mentioned that she is not pleased that we in the European People's Party have tabled a number of additional amendments – that is part of the parliamentary process. But I am particularly grateful that we were able to include the issue of anti-Semitism.

The Ombudsman will continue to play a key role in the democratic stability of the institutions and in the construction of Europe and in identifying the major issues that have a negative impact on the lives of European citizens. Only in this way will we be able to give real answers to the 500 million citizens who are watching us.

text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I wanted to pay tribute to the work of the Ombudsman. European citizens see how they vote here, and this is worse for them. The worse spectacle is the hasty vote of 450, 500 amendments in an hour, without counting the votes of MPs, sometimes contrary to the opinion of the Chamber, as we have even had an example today when the President insisted that he would not repeat the vote electronically. After a few, a dozen protests, he finally repeated them and it turned out that he was wrong. How many such cases have gone against the real sentence of the Chamber, something that has become European law in violation of democratic standards? The House, which instructs the whole world on what democracy should look like, uses voting techniques as if it were from some tribal gathering. I therefore call for this issue to be dealt with seriously by the citizens of the Union in order to be able to take this issue seriously.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Madam Ombudsman, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear colleagues, This is perhaps an unusual occasion in that Parliament is nearing the end of its five-year mandate, so we can look back not only on the one-year activity, but also on the whole period. I would like to make it clear to everyone that the European People's Party has a positive view of the activities of the European Ombudsman's office. I would like to thank the Ombudsman and her staff for their consistent work. Where there is a difference between us, the difference between the different factions – we have heard some criticism from two factions here towards the European People's Party – is that if there are problems in the European Union, and there are some, then we may not all have to criticise the Office of the European Ombudsman. We know that, and we need to know, that the European Ombudsman does not work in an easy environment, that he does not always find suitable cooperating partners, and we also see, unfortunately, that not everyone is meeting the Ombudsman's recommendations at the level we would like, but this is not the Ombudsman's office. This is probably a more serious, systemic problem. I would like to ask colleagues to try to take advantage of other channels and other opportunities to reduce these perversions, which colleagues have also been talking about in this room. And I assure everyone that the European People's Party will be a positive partner in this. I would also like to say that it is very important that we support the Ombudsman's institution politically, so the European People's Party will also support the report and support the further activities of the Office. And it is very important for citizens to see that the Ombudsman sees and deals with problems, and members of Parliament support this activity.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Madam Spokesperson, i would like to thank you very much May I make such a personal reflection, I have the pleasure of working with Mrs O'Reilly for many years, in the past as a quaestor in this House, now as Vice-President, and I have the utmost respect for the work that you and your team have done. The rapporteur has expressed this view, errare humanum est, that is, errare humanum est, that is, wandering is a human thing, and I must admit that it is the errare and mistakes that the Ombudsman points out to us, and it is human to err again, but not to repeat the same mistakes.  Thanks to you, thanks to your observation, we often avoid repeating the same mistakes, but there are, of course, new mistakes to be made. I would like to thank the Ombudsman for your initial remark on the sense of security in Parliament on this difficult night last night. The right of the citizen is to have access to the European Parliament and the right of the citizen is to be protected in this European Parliament. I am vice-president of the European Parliament responsible for security, among other things. Thank you very much for your assessment, which you have expressed here, I take this as such a very practical confirmation and, with a second and a half left. Lobbying: your recommendations have been implemented by the Bureau of the European Parliament and at the same time I am opposed to banning any contact with lobbyists – registered, official contact is needed.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Ombudsman's 2017 annual report is always an interesting reading. This will help you find out which bottlenecks are at European level. Topics such as transparency, accountability and public access to information and documents, the culture of service and respect for procedural rights are at the top of the list. Other issues covered included ethical issues, public participation in the EU decision-making process, the proper use of discretion including infringement procedures, sound financial management of EU procurement, grants and contracts, recruitment and proper management of issues relating to EU staff.  In particular, I would like to congratulate the Ombudsman on its investigation into the treatment of people with disabilities under the Commission's Common Health Insurance Scheme and the accessibility of the Commission's web pages and online tools for people with disabilities. Of course, the Ombudsman must make every effort to ensure the full and consistent implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities by the EU Administration.  I also fully agree that citizens should be able to participate more directly in the EU's democratic system, monitor the decision-making process within the EU institutions in detail and have access to all relevant information in order to fully exercise their democratic rights. That is the core of democracy.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, I recognise and commend the work of Ms Emily O’Reilly, the Ombudsman, as she has attempted to increase the transparency of the Council and the Commission. However, Emily, as you would know, much, much more needs to be done.  In the north of Ireland, the Committee on the Administration of Justice (CAJ) launched a complaint with you that the Commission failed to fully and faithfully translate their commitments that they made in December in the Joint Brexit Report. Before complaining, the CAJ wrote a letter to President Juncker that has been acknowledged but not yet answered. These are administrative errors and fall within your remit. Whilst it took a year to get sight of the mapping exercise of north-south cooperation, it was only released by the Brits after your call. In February, we were told that Annex I of the backstop would be extensively outlined in the list of directives that we in the north would be able to avail of to uphold our rights. However, it ultimately only contained six anti-discrimination directives. Indeed, we were guaranteed that the people of the north would be able to access and exercise our rights where we reside. However, the wording ‘where we reside’ was not inserted into the Brexit withdrawal agreement. Undoubtedly, the backstop is the least worst option for Ireland, yet the British negotiation tactics have contaminated politics and practices, creating an insidious environment resulting in maladministration. Emily, you should not have to wait for complaints to materialise. You should be able to use your remit to ensure that the Commission’s Brexit commitments are fully and faithfully implemented.  Mr President, on this night I would ask you to allow me just a few more seconds, because as mayhem is unfolding in the Tory party, it is without doubt evident that the people in the north of Ireland should have their say what Union they want to be a part of, and the test has been met in the Good Friday Agreement for a unity poll to be triggered. I know that it’s not within your remit, but I thought it was necessary to say that this evening.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Mrs O'Reilly, I should like to begin by thanking Mrs Evi for her excellent work on the European Ombudsman's 2017 report, which stresses that transparency and good administration are two fundamental principles which, in accordance with the Treaties and the European Charter of Fundamental Rights, must always support the European Union's action in all areas. Once again this year, the European Ombudsman has played an important role in ensuring that these principles are up to the European institutions, dealing with more than 2 000 complaints from citizens and launching more than 447 inquiries into the various aspects of the right to good administration, from access to documents to respect for procedural guarantees in the administrative procedure, passing through several sensitive issues of institutional ethics. In this respect, I would like to express my support for the european Ombudsman's call, and also taken up in Parliament's report, for the proposal to establish a European register for the transparency of stakeholders' activities, so-called lobbying. The representation of special interests must take place in the open, ensuring that the legitimate interactions between the representatives of the institutions and the representatives of those interests are traceable and take place with the utmost transparency. In conclusion, I would like once again to stress that the European Ombudsman plays an essential role in strengthening public confidence in the process of European integration, especially at a time like this, when confidence in the European institutions is under pressure from many quarters.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, the more power there is, the more responsibility there should be. We politicians should always remember that the people are our employers and wage payers, not lobbyists for big business and banks. I am astonished to see how much is said about the transparency of decision-making in the European Parliament and also in the home Parliament, but in practical work there is a feeling that there is no desire to promote transparency. One concrete example is the transparency register, the reform of which is a step in the making.  If public confidence in political decision-making is to be increased, lobbying must be more transparent. Advocacy is, of course, a legitimate activity, but citizens have the right to know who or who is behind the preparatory work, i.e. whose hands carry the pen.  It was also astonishing to see in the spring of this year how the Commission cannot survive without scandals in its own nomination policy. I am referring now to the appointment of Mr Selmayr to the post of Secretary-General of the Commission. It is good that this name has now been studied more. For European taxpayers, the most important thing is always to select the best candidate for all posts without discrimination, without favouring anyone.  The Ombudsman's report on the 2017 Annual Report also commendably highlights the publication of commissioners' meetings and waiting periods. The report as a whole is a good one, and I hope that the shortcomings it has found will lead to concrete measures.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, I want to address the elephant in the room, which is the ease in which EU institutions can ignore or miss the recommendations made by the Ombudsman. As an example – and I want to commend Ombudsman O’Reilly for insisting that ECB President Mario Draghi resign his membership of the secret bankers’ club, the G30 – the outcome of the process of investigating and reporting has been that nothing has changed. Less than a fortnight ago, Mr Draghi took part in another G30 meeting in New York. The ECB is charged with directly supervising many of the financial institutions that are represented in the G30, including Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan and many more. There is no system in place to ensure an ethically appropriate level of distance between the ECB decision-making and supervisory processes and their friends in the G30 bankers’ club. There is no way to ensure that the private bankers and finance CEOs of the G30 don’t influence ECB policy. Mr Draghi’s membership of the G30 is beyond inappropriate. The ECB appears to believe that it is beyond the basic norms of public scrutiny, accountability and transparency, and it faces no consequences for its outright rejection of the Ombudsman’s report. So this Parliament needs to address this situation as a matter of utmost urgency. The EU needs to impose real consequences on any institution that simply dismisses or ignores the recommendations of our Ombudsman’s office.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, I would like to a congratulate Madam Ombudsman and her team on another fruitful year of work that was outlined in her balanced and well structured annual report. First of all I would like to mention the interactive guide as an example of using available resources efficiently. Out of the 15 837 citizens who called on the Ombudsman Services for help, 12 521 were given advice on her website, and 447 inquiries were opened of which 433 were complaint-based and 14 were own-initiative inquiries. The European Ombudsman performs therefore not only efficient work with regard to complaints but also takes own-initiative inquiries regarding current EU policy areas. Finally, I would like to mention a very important thing. We have to provide as much transparency and communication as possible to our citizens, but we have to keep in mind that this transparency should not undermine the negotiating positions of the European Union, so finding a proper balance is very important.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, ombudsman O'Reilly, I am sure you have noticed that those of us who regularly participate in this European Parliament in the debate on their activities do so from the appreciation, from respect for the work that a woman has developed at the head of a major European institution. I recall that, in his presentation to this European Parliament seeking the qualified majority he needed to practice, he undertook to reinvent the figure by relaunching it with initiative, and I encourage it, particularly in three areas. You have seen how many times we have insisted on the fundamental rights of Articles 41 and 42 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union — good administration, access to information, transparency — but they are connected with the guarantee of confidentiality in the handling of data; communication with the European Data Protection Supervisor.  The second area is communication with the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, because there is discrimination in the behaviour of the institutions and, of course, a source of complaint is the objective profile with which it is discriminated against from the institutions.  And the third is, of course, OLAF and the newly created European Public Prosecutor's Office, because there are so many allegations that have to do with abuse of power and corruption. All the luck in your work, ombudsman.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Honourable Members for this interesting debate. I would like to conclude by expressing, on behalf of the Commission, my gratitude to Ms O’Reilly for the consistently good cooperation between the Commission, her and her services, and the constructive approach. This cooperation is a key element for improving the administration of the EU, and to ensure that our citizens get the good administration that they deserve.

name: Emily O’Reilly
text: Ombudsman. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Members for all of their observations and also for their appreciation of the work of my office, which I will pass on to my colleagues who work so hard with the complaints and the investigations that we do. I always find this debate very inspiring, because it gives me a sense of the issues that we’re working on in the office that are of our particular interest to you, and also it shows me that some of the issues that we have laid particular emphasis on – such as Council transparency – have also found significant resonance right across the Parliament. I noted the comment of Mr Mandl about anti-Semitism and suggesting that the European Network of Ombudsmen take a greater interest in that, and I would like to assure him that that is something that we are actually doing: increasingly, some of the network ombudsmen have that specific task, and I have suggested that that is an area that we could discuss at our seminar in Brussels next year. On Council transparency: yes, on the opacity of decision-making, I think Ms Auken pointed to the fact that this is really about the exercising of every citizen’s right to participate in our democracy, and of course that is the cornerstone of the inquiry and that is essentially why we’re doing it. A number of Members talked about our inquiry – not an own-initiative inquiry, but because we got complaints in relation to it – on the appointment of the new Secretary—General of the Commission. The Commission has responded to us, and I shall be very shortly responding to them. I was interested in a comment by Mr Csáky acknowledging that my office can’t do everything, and also acknowledging the difficulty that there is sometimes in getting some of my recommendations fully accepted. I should point out that, depending on the year, between 80% and 90% of recommendations are accepted, but there are some that aren’t accepted. This can be an issue because in most Member States, with the standards of administration that we see in the EU, it is a relatively rare event that an ombudsman’s recommendation is not accepted. I think it doesn’t mean that you have to make recommendations that are so easy that everybody accepts them; I think you have to be a little bit brave and not shy away from difficult recommendations. But when there are particularly sensitive ones, then it is important that I get the support of Parliament, and I think that that puts pressure on it. I recognise the Members talking about Brexit. Yes, I have looked for opportunities that I can appropriately use in my office to support citizens in relation to that. I was pleased that the mapping exercise has been published, and I will continue to work on it and I take note of the other comments that were made. So thank you again, Members, and thank you President for this opportunity to present my work. I’m really deeply grateful for the support that I get from Parliament for the work that we carry out on behalf of the citizens. (Applause)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Thank you very much, Ms O’Reilly, for your important work.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – First of all, it must be emphasised that the European Union is still experiencing the worst economic, social and political crisis since its establishment. All EU institutions, agencies and services should feel obliged to ensure full transparency and the highest standards of ethics and accountability. According to the European Parliament rapporteur, unfortunately, the ineffective approach adopted by the EU institutions to combat the lack of transparency, both in the EU decision-making process and in lobbying and on other important ethical issues within the institutions, contributes to further harm to the image of the EU, to the frustration and dissatisfaction of citizens. In this area, Parliament's rapporteur recalls that the EU has still not adopted a mandatory EU transparency register in order to ensure full transparency of all EU institutions, agencies and third countries in relation to lobbying activities. In addition, the rapporteur stresses that EU legislation on access to documents is very outdated. The European Parliament also believes that the European Ombudsman has a key role to play in ensuring the transparency and impartiality of EU decision-making processes and administration in order to successfully protect citizens' rights, and supports the European Ombudsman's inquiry into the informal negotiations between the three main EU institutions (trilogues).

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – The European Ombudsman has a key role to play in ensuring the transparency and impartiality of decision-making processes and in the EU administration, in order to successfully protect citizens' rights. I am concerned that most of the investigations carried out in 2017 continue to be on transparency, accountability and public access to information (20.6 %), the culture of the service (16.8 %) and respect for procedural rights (16.5%). With the European Union currently facing multiple crises and challenges, all European institutions should ensure full transparency in decision-making and lobbying and the highest ethical and accountability standards. All the more so, the European Court of Justice has confirmed that the principles of publicity and transparency are inherent in the EU legislative process, and that citizens must be able to follow the decision-making process within the institutions and have access to all information of interest in order to fully exercise their democratic rights. I believe that full transparency of the decision-making process at European Union level is needed, because in a system based on the principle of democratic legitimacy, all institutions must be held accountable for their actions before the public.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Cecilia Wikström, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2017 (2018/2104(INI)) (A8-0404/2018).

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, the petitions we receive in the Committee on Petitions (PETI) help us to better assess the impact that EU legislation has on people’s daily lives and to find loopholes and problems with the implementation of EU legislation. By acting as a bridge between citizens and institutions, the Committee on Petitions can contribute to both the creation of better legislation and helping people in their everyday lives. The number of petitions received per year is rather constant, even if it is important to note that the petitions received during 2017 was the lowest number during this mandate. However, the new system put in place via the PETI portal, which allows citizens to support existing petitions has increased greatly this past year – up from 6 000 users who supported a petition in 2016 to 15 000 users who supported a petition in 2017. This is a very positive trend which means that citizens can show they have support for an issue without having to file a petition by themselves. It was therefore an important milestone when the petitions network was launched in March 2017. It serves as a useful tool for better follow-up on petitions in parliamentary and legislative work, increases the visibility for the petitions received within the House, and intensifies cooperation with colleagues in the other committees. The main area of concern of the petitions received during 2017 were environmental matters such as such as water and waste management, and preservation. This demonstrates the need for proper environmental legislation and implementation. Other areas of concern were fundamental rights, especially voting rights and children’s rights, the free movement of persons, and social affairs such as working conditions. The Committee on Petitions had discussions on petitions covering these subjects in various committee meetings during 2017. The work in the Committee on Petitions is very rewarding, due to the direct contact with citizens. It’s a constant reminder of the results of the legislation that we are working on, and for whom we write the laws. It’s both interesting and demanding to meet the various petitioners who come to the committee and talk about their problems. We cannot always solve the citizens’ problems but we can at least raise awareness of their concerns. We can all always do better and together we should strive to improve our citizens’ support even further. The chair of the Committee on Petitions, Ms Cecilia Wikström, looks forward to continuing this work together with her colleagues until the end of the mandate. Finally, the chair of the Committee is very pleased with the work done in the Committee on Petitions and the results achieved together. She would like to thank all the colleagues and the Secretariat of the Committee on Petitions for the good cooperation and work done during 2017.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me begin by thanking Ms Wikström, Mr Csáky and the whole Committee on Petitions (PETI) for the comprehensive report on the activities of PETI in 2017. Like its predecessors in previous years, the report gives evidence of the wide range of issues that petitioners bring to PETI’s attention each year, and of the committee’s efforts to ensure that the voices of those petitioners are really heard. The Commission shares Parliament’s view that the right to petition is both a fundamental right of all EU citizens and a key element of participatory democracy, allowing for citizens’ active engagement in the fields of EU action. Citizens often turn to the committee as a last resort because they feel that they have exhausted all other avenues, and we, both the Commission and the Parliament, can demonstrate that we listen to their concerns and take them seriously by offering proper responses and, where possible, showing them existing solutions at European or national level. This is a concrete example of how we can collaborate to bolster citizens’ confidence and trust in the European project. However, we should also recognise that there are often cases where the expectations of citizens supersede the powers of the EU. Unmet expectations can lead to frustration and the argument that the EU is simply not up to the task. While this is understandable, though lamentable, it is impossible to answer citizens’ calls that go beyond our competences and EU law. It is our collective duty to inform citizens of the possibilities and limitations of EU law in order to stem unfair accusations that the EU doesn’t want to listen and/or is unfit to act. As the report points out, our institutions have built good working relationships in recent years when it comes to handling petitions. Of the petitions declared admissible by the Parliament in 2017, about two-thirds were referred to the Commission for an opinion. In return, the 670 replies that the Commission sent back to the Parliament in 2017 testify to our engagement to support the critical work of the committee, which the Commission takes very seriously. All Commission replies are prepared with care and are widely consulted upon among its services. Appropriately ranked officials with expert knowledge of the issues discussed participate in the committee’s meetings with the aim of providing the most meaningful and up-to-date information in a timely manner. Here I am therefore pleased to reaffirm the commitment of the Commission to continue our good collaboration and to bring forward the EU added value in the resolutions of petitioners’ concerns. The report calls on the Commission to make proper use of its powers stemming from its role as guardian of the Treaties, and for a timely handling of infringement procedures. The Commission’s new enforcement policy sets out a more strategic, effective and proportionate approach to infringement policy to allow us to deliver on our policy priorities. We will give priority to pursuing the most important breaches of EU law affecting the interests of citizens and businesses. One key development is that we will launch infringement procedures without relying on the EU pilot mechanism unless recourse to this mechanism is seen as useful in a given case. This will allow us to act firmly and quickly when infringements obstruct the key EU policy objectives and to ensure timely handling of infringement procedures. The main objective of infringement procedures is to ensure that Member States give effect to EU law. These often lengthy procedures are conducted between the Commission and a Member State and are not designed to provide for individual cases. As guardian of the Treaties, the Commission enjoys discretionary power which allows it to decide to open or not to open an infringement procedure. According to the Treaties, where citizens’ rights under EU law are affected at national level they must have access to rapid and effective national redress mechanisms. As the Commission stated in its 2016 communication, national courts are the common courts for upholding EU law and contribute effectively to enforcing it in individual cases. As for informing the Parliament about ongoing EU pilot investigations and infringement procedures related to petitions, the Commission strives to give as much information as possible in its written replies to Parliament. However, it has to respect the necessary confidentiality with regard to the Member State concerned, as recognised by the Court of Justice. More generally, the Commission proactively disseminates information on infringements and publishes it on the centralised platform of the Europa website. The report also touches upon a number of other important issues for which the views of Parliament and the Commission largely converge. Let me only mention the high priority in preserving citizens’ rights after the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the Union, or the protection of the rights of persons with disabilities. I will, however, end my remarks here once again thanking Ms Wikström and the PETI Committee for your very helpful report. I look forward to hearing the views of the Honourable Members in the debate.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by saying that the right to submit a petition offers EU citizens the means to address their directly elected representatives. It constitutes, in fact, a bridge between them and the EU institutions. In my opinion, our committee has an important role in raising awareness through a debate, ensuring public participation and cooperation with Member States, and within the House through the petitions network that was launched last year. The subjects raised in the petitions of 2017 pertain mostly to environmental matters, fundamental rights, free movement of people, child welfare and social affairs. Our work is not limited to the handling of petitions. The Committee organises fact-finding visits and hearings, commissions studies, gives opinions to legislative committees, is a member of the European network of Ombudsmen, and had a role in revising the regulation on the European citizens’ initiative. Last year, we dedicated a lot of time to petitions on Brexit, as they encompassed vital contributions to citizens ahead of the negotiations. As a committee we raised important questions to plenary by means of oral questions and resolutions. Here I would like to firmly state that we should stick to our mandate as a committee. I have the impression that some of my colleagues would like to take over the role of legislative committees. Last but not least, I would like to underline the importance of communication and social media presence on topics that we are dealing with, and the difference between our committee and other services such as SOLVIT, so that our citizens and their enterprises can properly address the alleged breaches of European Union law.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is indeed a pleasure for me to speak in this House and to talk about the work done by the Committee on Petitions, of which I have the honour of being a member. In recent years – and I can say this because it is now normal for us to take stock of our mandate as a Member of the European Parliament – we have done an enormous amount of work in the PETI Committee, and I would like to thank Mrs Wikström and also our coordinator of the S&D Group, who have always been present and constant in a work that, in the end, we can say. , is a work of truth. The committee, which is, by the way, the least coveted, let us be honest, among those of the European Parliament, precisely because it does not deal with and does not produce legislative processes, has all kinds of cases and it can really be said that our work is a work that sometimes becomes almost investigative. I remember over the years the many cases dealt with, the many answers we have given to the European citizens who have addressed us. I will mention one for all: the case of the children who disappeared in Spain under the regime of Francisco Franco, a story that marked me, also personally and in particular, to which we committed ourselves with a mission that had touching moments, when we met the now elderly mothers who are still looking for these children. I would therefore like to say, commenting on this absolutely timely report that we have brought to this House, that the work of the PETI Committee must be absolutely increased and intensified, that the Commission, but also Parliament, must give us the opportunity to work more and better. That is what the citizens of Europe expect, and that would be a wonderful signal to the Eurosceptics. The Committee on Petitions is the real link between the citizens and this institution, the European Parliament. Let us ensure that it is ever closer to its citizens and that it represents true European values.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the Committee on Petitions really is the committee which is directly linked to the citizens. It is the only committee in which citizens can come forward and speak, and that is a qualitative difference. Although some people think it is a degraded committee, they are wrong, because the Committee on Petitions is listening to the rights, the citizens' demands are being heard, and we have dealt with very important issues such as the rights of disabled people, we have dealt with the issue of child abduction, we have dealt with the famous Jugendamt, we have dealt with social rights, access to documents. , the role played by the Commission in the well-known pilot cases, i.e. those which highlight issues of violation of European law, environmental protection, and also to protect citizens from pesticides. I think this has had an important effect, especially for Greece, because we have given space to this committee and we have more and more petitions, more and more intervention by the Greek citizens, even though some people regarded this committee as minor.  Let me just point out that once again the Committee on Petitions rejected my request to hold a public hearing on the serious issue of German compensation, an issue of concern to Greece, but unfortunately once again the Committee on Petitions did not accept my proposal. I hope that he will deal in the next period with the new report that I will be reporting on the issue of German reparations, the issue of German debts, which include the compulsory occupation loan, the compensation of the relatives of the victims executed by the German occupying troops and the war reparations. This is an issue that I will bring back in 2019 and I hope that this time our own committee will be much more positive in addressing this demand, which is an issue that all Greek citizens are asking for.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, during the last year we have observed in the Committee on Petitions that complaints on environmental issues and fundamental rights have increased to the point where they are the main sources of denunciation by our citizens. Unfortunately, we continue to see an absence of interest from States to transpose or implement the legislation correctly. We have seen an irresponsible attitude on the part of state authorities in implementing, for example, the Air Quality Directive, the Water Framework Directive, international obligations in humanitarian aid, the Directives on the protection of precarious workers, the ratification of the Istanbul Convention or respect for the principle of the free movement of citizens to prevent expulsions in Member States. After assessing so many cases, which also affect my country, we cannot be surprised by the crisis of legitimacy of this Union, which we are currently seeing and suffering. I am also still outraged at the European Commission's lack of reaction in many cases. The European Commission needs to be more involved in its replies, please, and with its actions. On many occasions, the Commission takes several years to bring the offending States to the Court of Justice. We must be clear that, in matters of protection of fundamental or environmental rights, health rights, for example, infringement procedures should not be extended as well.  Finally, I demand that we be able to access as much documentation as possible on open investigation procedures, based on petitions and that the involvement of the other parliamentary committees in this House should be strengthened when we demand it from the Committee on Petitions to report on the issues that also affect them.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, this report on the annual deliberations of the Committee on Petitions in 2017 highlights the most important task of our committee: to be the bridge between citizens and the European institutions. The report underlines the strong concern of Europeans and Europeans about environmental issues, water, air quality in our cities, but also issues such as railway safety. It should be remembered that on 17 January there were victims in the most serious accident in European history in the last 25 years, the accident in Santiago de Compostela, in my country. For the future, I think it is important that we have a strengthened Committee on Petitions, where it is even more obvious that the role of the committee should be the centre where whistleblowers can express their concerns to their representatives. The committee should be more easily accessible and transparent in handling complaints. Moreover, it is very important that we, as MEPs and MEPs, can see and hear our hopes on the ground and invite petitioners to Brussels to present their cases at meetings that are at the heart of our work on this committee in the European Parliament. I came to this Parliament on 1 March and i had the very clear idea of returning to this parliamentary committee because it is the best of the European Parliament.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is true that the Committee on Petitions is a real committee that opens up to citizens to hear their voice.  The work of this committee, in 2017, recorded some very appreciable positions on issues denounced through the many petitions from thousands of European citizens: I am thinking of the fight against precarious employment, the issue of protecting the well-being of minors, I am thinking of the promotion of renewable energies and also of the many cases in which the protection of the environment and human health was at stake. However, the hearings carried out, the recommendations made and the resolutions adopted cannot and must not be regarded as a point of arrival. In practice, if there are no concrete results which lead to a real improvement in the daily lives of those citizens who have addressed the European Parliament with hope, we cannot stop there. This remains the greatest challenge facing the Committee on Petitions: to exert tireless political pressure on the European and national institutions, so that the voice of the citizens can be constantly heard.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. A year ago, I was talking about the activities of the Committee on Petitions last year about the fact that the largest number of petitions come from Romania and Greece in proportion to the population. Romania is ahead of only the large Member States, Germany, Italy and Spain. Unfortunately, nothing has changed in this respect. In 2017, 5.2% of petitions came from Romania, making it the fourth in a row and 3.7% from Greece, sixth in order. Romania has already outsked the United Kingdom in this area in the previous year, which is a major concern. It is also interesting that if we look at the nationality of the submitters, the order does not change, but the proportions do: 6.8% of the submitters are Romanians and 4% are Greek citizens. On the one hand, these facts give rise to optimism, because Romanian and Greek citizens are increasingly exercised their rights to EU citizenship and petition the European Parliament, and on the other hand these figures also highlight the fact that, in addition to the large Member States, Romania and Greece are attracting an outlier number of petitions, i.e. these two Member States deserve special attention from the European Parliament. It is also clear from the Committee on Petitions' activities in 2017 that a very large number of petitions submitted concern fundamental rights and justice. In addition to environmental protection, the European Union has much to do in this regard, as citizens have a legitimate expectation that European law will be applied to the same standards throughout the EU. Therefore, in addition to the European Commission, the Council, and therefore the Member States, must pay more attention to the resolution of petitions. After all, this is what citizens expect of the European institutions: solve the problems they are signalling to us. If we cannot do this, we cannot hide behind various legal explanations and lose the trust of citizens.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, it happens to all of us to listen to people disappointed in the EU, blaming Brussels and feeling that nobody cares about their needs. This is partly due to the lack of information about the EU, but also partly due to the lack of reaction from the institutions. Unfortunately, numerous petitions get superficial replies from the Commission, which leads petitioners to conclude that the whole institutional system of the EU is inefficient. The European Parliament, as the institution receiving the petitions, has a special role to play in the process of turning citizens’ claims into a real political change. But to make it a reality, we need to intervene on multiple levels. First, we need to ensure that information on EU law is made available to specific groups of citizens in the most user—friendly way. Information on filing a petition should also be made clearer. Second, we need to make sure that petitions manage to bring a mindful impact on EU policies. Petition is the right of any EU citizen, but we cannot give a right that does not really empower people. Some petitions are closed without people getting a concrete reply. This is the case of numerous petitions on the problem of non-citizenship in Latvia: this is a problem that affects 12% of the population, and has lasted for 27 years already. The only hope of Latvian non—citizens is an efficient reply at the EU level. When the petition becomes the only one and single tool, we cannot allow this single tool to be useless. Third, based on the petition statistics, we need to enhance cooperation with Member State authorities on the matter of implementation of EU law. Petitioners should be at the origin of the claim, but they should also be the final beneficiaries of our replies.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wholeheartedly support the report's recommendations that the Commission should exercise its powers properly in relation to its role as guardian of the Treaties, as that role is crucial to the functioning of the EU for citizens. Logically, infringement procedures should be initiated in an objective and neutral manner where necessary in order to put an end to situations where EU law is not respected.  I would also like to thank the Committee on Petitions for giving its opinion in various contributions to parliamentary reports on various issues, such as the European Accessibility Act, the Marrakesh Convention on Promoting Access to Published Works for the Blind and Visually Impaired and the European Disability Strategy.  The annual report also shows that for people with disabilities, access to public transport and the built environment, and discrimination in the labour market for people with disabilities, pose the most problems. This highlights the importance of the European Accessibility Act, which was recently adopted and which member states must now transposing into national legislation. Hopefully that will effectively make a difference on the field.  Furthermore, it seems to me that the Member States are not doing enough to implement the 2000 Equality Directive, the Employment Equality Directive in English. Given that work is an important lever for inclusion of people with disabilities in society, Member States urgently need to step up their needs in this area.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I am pleased to read this report. It seems that if the European Parliament is the only European institution directly derived from citizens' choices, it is also the only or the first institution to which citizens have the right, or even the duty, to turn and turn. They turn not when they are very well – we do not have many petitions from citizens from Denmark or Luxembourg, for example – but when they feel injustice, when they have problems, when they need someone to just give them a hand. They also turn to issues that we widely regard as broader but relevant to our environment.  Here, Mr Mamikins very rightly emphasised that it is important that they translate into decisions. This is our role to treat these petitions as a source of information, as a way of getting down to earth sometimes. At the same time, let us be aware that even if sometimes we do not help directly, we will at least listen. The hearing itself also brings relief to many people who believe that someone has helped them.  Lastly, the invitation to Brussels for a hearing. I like this idea. We should therefore also consider in the budget provisions the appropriations for the committee to implement this demand.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this debate, which provides proof not only of the importance of the right to petition in our Union but also of the importance of our collective efforts to respond to the concerns that citizens bring to our attention. My choice of the word ‘collective’ in this context is a deliberate one, as both Parliament and the Commission have key roles to play in this area. And as Vice—President Liberadzki said, there is always something uncomfortable at the beginning: this is always the complaint of people about something wrong; something that they find unjust; something which they would like to see solved. A large number of petitions and a diversity of issues entail a combination of this bad start but also something very good: it is the proof that the people have confidence that if they come to us with their complaint we will do something useful. That we will deal with the complaints, that we will come up with a solution if it is within our power, and that we can come up with a workable solution which will change the situation for the better. This high level of confidence which the people show to us through their petitions is also a very strong commitment for all of us.  So I would like in this context to reiterate that the Commission attaches great importance to the good working relationship built during these years with the Committee on Petitions, and that I take this commitment very seriously and am ready to cooperate further on finding proper solutions to the problems of people. I would like to reassure the Parliament of our continued and strong commitment to cooperate closely together in the handling of petitions.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Deputy Rapporteur. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. If you don't mind, I'm going to use my native language. After the European People's Party has asked me to speak on this subject, allow me to summarise my own opinion and that of the European People's Party in three points and then conclude this debate from the position of The President of the Commission. Firstly, I would like to emphasise once again to all colleagues that the Committee on Petitions is the only committee in this House that has direct contact with citizens. It is very important what image we give of ourselves when we develop relationships with citizens and try to solve the problems they raise. I would therefore also like to ask the European Commission, I would also like to ask the other commissions, to give the Peti Commission more prestige, to take the requests of the Peti Committee seriously. I believe that the good work that has been done so far can still be improved, and let us not forget that the Peti Commission can essentially function as a conscience of the European Union, because if there are problems and citizens turn to us, it is also a show of trust. The other thing, Mr President, I, you know, come from Eastern Europe, Slovakia, a small country – I am also a representative of a small community in the Hungarian community, which is 10% of the country – and I have also been Deputy Prime Minister of Slovakia on two occasions, so I can also judge the activities of the offices and judge the opinions and requests of the citizens. I therefore consider it one of my tasks and I am very pleased that several of my colleagues on the committee have joined me in reinforcing people's legal consciousness and reinforcing their civic consciousness. If they can articulate a petition well and stand up for their rights, I think it will strengthen Europe because we need strong citizens in Europe. And the third thing, dear Mr President, if you will allow me – and now, as Vice-President of the Committee, on behalf of the Committee – I would like to thank my colleagues for their cooperation in committee, and I would like to thank parliament's plenary for its support. In February this year, something happened that has not yet happened: on the proposal of the Committee on Petitions, a 'short resolution', a decision has been taken on the protection of indigenous minorities, for example, which I would like to thank you for now! I would also like to thank the Secretariat for its work. The head of the secretariat will now be transferred to another position, leaving the secretariat, Mrs Virpi. Allow me to thank Mrs Virpi by name for her work. And I would like to ask that there be excellent cooperation in the committee in the future, not on the basis of political considerations, but on the basis of a discussion of the material problems.
