name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Massimiliano Salini, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Eu ropean Space Programme and the European Union Space Programme Agency and repealing Regulations (EU) No 912/2010, (EU) No. 1285/2013 and (EU) No 377/2014 and Decision No 541/2014/EU (COM(2018)0447 - C8-0258/2018 - 2018/0236(COD)) (A8-0405/2018).

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we have the opportunity to present one of the programmes, that relating to the European Union's space strategy, which, with less uncertainty, documents, I believe, the usefulness of a strong Europe, of a Europe with concrete leadership. The Great Space Tradition of the European Union finally has the opportunity to be achieved through an integrated programme, as proposed by the Commission. There are a number of elements on which the work we have carried out in recent months is based, a fruitful work in which we have tried to build on the Commission's proposal, which has certainly put us in a position to operate properly. First of all, the theme of the budget. The budget proposed by the European Commission is an important budget of EUR 16 billion. We have worked to improve, to a certain extent, its ability to cover all the needs that have emerged, in particular on Copernicus and, I have to say, a strong discussion on the new programmes, namely SSA and GOVSATCOM, and maintaining the primacy in terms of the budget allocated, in our opinion correctly, to Galileo and EGNOS. From this type of work, our proposal, which emerges, as you know, Commissioner, now amounts to EUR 16.9 billion and it is important that it is not reduced. Then, among the various pillars on which the space strategy is based, there is the industrial theme. European industry in the space sector has an enormous impact capacity and we believe that the Commission's proposal to propose an integrated programme, which will put all the various programmes in a solid and structured relationship, including the EGNOS, Galileo, Copernicus programmes and also the new SSA and GOVSATCOM programmes, is correct. This will, in our view, generate efficiency and, on the other hand, reduce unnecessary costs, thus reducing unnecessary duplication and repetition, which have sometimes, in the past, reduced the programme's firepower from an industrial point of view. A second central element from an industrial point of view is the whole game linked to downstream: we need an articulated and detailed dissemination and use of all the data and services generated by the space programme. This will be of great benefit to end-users and, of course, to the whole industry which must be able to make use of these services. We are very strong on the upstream, we must also become so on the downstream, so that the supply chain is complete. This is a judgment that also emerges from the assessment of the enormous impact that a good space programme can have on the geopolitical game. Today we are living in a context of serious geopolitical uncertainty. In a nutshell, we can say that a space programme with the above characteristics would allow us to have four major points of advantage for the European Union: competitiveness, first of all, sustainability, autonomy – why not? especially in the management of some sensitive data – and security. The articulation of these four major pillars will generate the expected result, namely real European leadership through a completed space programme worthy of the name. The second part – and I will close, I am going to conclude – which concerns the negotiation phase that we have been through so far, and which we will be addressing, is the great game of governance. I would like to say a few brief words on this but, in my view, useful and determined to achieve this. The European Commission has overall responsibility for the space programme, oversees its security and coordinates all the bodies involved in the implementation of this programme, in particular what is now the GSA, that is, the Agency that will become the European Union Agency for the Space Programme, and the European Space Agency, which traditionally contains the best expertise within it. So the European Union Agency for the Space Programme with increased competences, but above all constant coordination by the European Commission: these are the secrets for the space strategy to be carried out. I would like to add one final point because, Mr President, Commissioner, in addition to being rapporteur in the ITRE Committee, I was, and am also, draftsman of the opinion of the TRAN Committee and therefore brings together in this speech the two elements, the two horns of the problem. With regard to the important impact we have on transport, within the framework of the space strategy, I am not going to dwell on it, of course, it is part of what I have already said as far as industry is concerned. But let us think about the theme of sustainability, the theme of the use of drones in the improvement of postal services, the theme of the game of environmental sustainability through more careful and articulated management of traffic, especially road traffic. Then there is the question of aircraft: there is a need, as far as air transport is concerned, to ensure that the I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work on this subject, and i.e. the commission of the European Parliament. That is why I would like to say thank you: thank you to all my colleagues and to the shadow rapporteurs with whom we have worked so far, creating compromises, in my opinion, that are equal to the great challenge and thanks to the Commission's proposal, which has put us in a position to work properly.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I want to personally thank the rapporteur and also the shadow rapporteurs for their work and for their really devoted support for this file. We see this file as very important for the future position of Europe as a global and competitive space actor. Let me just briefly say a few words on what the idea behind it was and why we decided to table this proposal. Europe has definitely gained momentum in space. Our space programmes, as we call them, ‘flagship’ ones – Galileo, Copernicus and EGNOS – are operational. They are on time and on budget. They offer really quality services to users with performances that really exceed expectations – ours and everyone’s. In the coming years, the European space sector will also have to deal with major challenges in relation, of course, with global evolutions on environmental, economic, security and geopolitical levels, and additionally there is a disruptive wave in the making. Of course, it is especially coming from the US, and we also see the emergence of the new private space actors, new business models and new technologies in this field. This is what the space programme that the Commission proposed is all about. Climate change, digitalisation, data economy, security, safety of people and goods, competitiveness of the European space industry, strategic autonomy – that was mentioned before – and technological independence are all issues that are directly linked to the space programme that we are discussing here today. Following that space strategy that we adopted together and that was endorsed by this Parliament just two years ago, the EU space programme has the following objectives in order to address those key challenges that we are facing. The first very important one is to ensure the continuity of the existing space infrastructure and the services, and at the same time, the development of the new and enhanced ones. The second is to foster an evolution to ensure that our current programmes and projects are responding to the new needs – more precise positioning for connected cars, for example – but also fighting climate change and ensuring more security for Europeans. These are all issues that we want to tackle with our space programmes. Additionally, we want to promote the emergence of the European ‘new space’ approach. This is not about copy—pasting what is done in the US, but to invent a genuine European approach to maintain an innovative European space sector that is able to compete globally. The third point is to adapt to new realities. We must see the space sector as an enabler of our security. That is why we are proposing to launch two new components: space situational awareness (SSA), allowing to protect our satellites in orbit, and GOVSATCOM, to allow secured communication by satellites. We also proposed an element to maintain the EU capacity to have autonomous access to space, relying on EU independent industry – again, it was mentioned by the rapporteur.  For all these priorities, we proposed a budget of EUR 16 billion for the next MFF. This is, of course, an ambitious agenda, but one we think is necessary to make sure that Europe remains the second space power globally. I’m happy that the Commission’s proposal for the EU space programme has been equally supported by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), but also by the associated committees: the Committee on Budgets (BUDG), the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI), the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI). I know that these committees have, in particular, raised some important elements to our discussion: for example, the importance of ensuring the adequate funding necessary to maintain state—of—the—art and innovative Galileo and Copernicus initiatives, and the importance for the European Union to be ambitious on the new programmes, including SSA and GOVSATCOM, as I mentioned. These programmes are really crucial to protect the key interests of the Union, and the Commission noted with great interest the remarks from the committees on the need to ensure sufficient budgets for them. The impact of the space programme on the whole European economy, in particular for small and medium—sized enterprises, but also for mid—caps, and the need to better support space startups, the importance of maintaining an autonomous access to space and the impact of the European space initiatives on the other policy areas – that was also mentioned before – agriculture, transport, of course, environment, climate monitoring, security and defence. I cannot agree more with those comments, so I’m looking forward to this important discussion and to your remarks.

name: John HOWARTH
text: Rapporteur BUDG. – Mr President, the space programme is a good investment for the European Union. It enables Member States to realise technology benefits that are too substantial for any individual Member State, and as well as that obvious economy of scale, the added value created by the space programme is considerable: the direct benefits, for example, of a competitive space sector worth around EUR 60 billion a year, providing 230 000 high-skill, high quality jobs. Value—added benefits already realised in fishing policy, environmental programmes, precision farming, transport and traffic modelling are also contributors of added value. In this way, we get a greater return from EU budgets, and we also get data for better informed budget decision—making. A couple of cautionary words: the Commission is creating a European Union agency for the space programme from another agency. This carries some risks, we believe, of duplication with the activities of the European Space Agency. A tight definition of that agency’s brief and diligent scrutiny is the way to mitigate that risk. The progress of this departure, along with the adequacy of funding for Galileo, Copernicus and the new streams, should be reviewed at the mid-term of the MFF. And finally, it is worth observing as a cautionary note that some of the discussion has focused on the notion of a uniquely European Union space industry. The trouble is that there’s no such thing as a uniquely European satellite – space is global, and to approach it any other way may well prove an expensive mistake.

name: Werner KUHN
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you very much, Commissioner Bie kowska, but also, in a special way, Mr Salini, for putting this dossier, which came as a proposal by the European Commission to tackle an integrated space programme, into practice. I think it is insanely necessary that we take the existing activities with Copernicus. network with EGNOS, GNSS and, of course, Galileo, and then be able to use the data available there for the different areas. I say to you: this space programme is critical infrastructure, and we can no longer rely on the comrades on the other side of the Atlantic that we used to rely on. I think collaboration with Russia and China can be safe, but Europe needs its own space programme in the digital age. With Galileo, we do not need to put our light under the bushel either. We have our own space station, a space station with launchers, the 20th satellite will go into orbit in 2020, and Galileo is operational and can provide data – in a special way for ship safety. In the Committee on Transport and Social Affairs, we have often discussed this with each other: is it necessary to use pilots, or can we guarantee ship safety, I say on the Strait of Gibraltar, I say on the Bosphorus, I say in the Mediterranean as a whole or also in the Baltic Sea on the Kadetrinne with such a programme? That is possible. Pilot programmes are already under way in this respect, and this is very important.  I am vice-chairman of the Committee on Fisheries. We are discussing a control regulation, which should then have, so to speak, a vessel monitoring system. This can only be done through the appropriate satellite systems that we have. It is then also clear and necessary that the European Fisheries Control Agency in Vigo should be able to record all the data that is then necessary in this regard in order to have real control. This, of course, has something to do with ship safety. Finally, I would like to mention one point: if we have our own GPS system, which is even better than the American one, it should be built on an Android Samsung, so that every European citizen also has an identification with his continent and with his own space programme.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: on the ecr group. – Mr President, let me start by thanking my colleague Salini. I very much appreciate his consensual approach. It is good that the report will have such broad support, and I think that is very important. First, on the issue of programme management. I have long called for the synergy between the Galileo and Copernicus programmes covered by the GSA to be strengthened. Extending security accreditation to other programmes was the first logical step. I am glad that Parliament will now go further and entrust the Agency with other tasks, such as marketing or cybersecurity. The space program is now hiding all space projects under one roof. I have repeatedly said that Galileo and Copernicus have a clear added value for cooperation at European Union level. Some colleagues expressed skepticism about the SSA and, in particular, the GOVSATCOM component. On the contrary, I think that we should also move towards a greater scale here. But at the same time, I see a limited budget.  Furthermore, the involvement of third countries. Here we would like to see greater flexibility mutually beneficial for the European Union and for the friendly countries with which we cooperate in the field of security. Of course, I am thinking first and again of the United Kingdom, whatever the future relationship may be. On the related issue of public procurement: If we have a security agreement with third countries, we should also open tenders for their industry. I also perceive the sensitivity of the issue of ownership of European companies. However, we must proceed with caution here so as not to destroy the space ecosystem, which includes companies owned by entities from friendly allied third countries.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Dear Commissioner, 'The sky is not the limit' I like to say in good Rotterdam. Especially when it comes to space travel. And with this EU space programme, we are in the leading group worldwide. We're proud of that. This is not about dreamy March trips, but about concrete progress that benefits the hard-working Europeans here and now.  For example, in my own Member State, the Netherlands, we know exactly where and how the soil is falling through space, so that we can maintain our dikes and our infrastructure properly. It helps us to innovate agriculture even further, to tackle the climate problem and to make the most of space during military operations. But there are also concerns. All data produced must be secure and used only for good purposes. Our Galileo and also our Copernicus programme make a lot of data available at the level of detail and we should not run the risk that the influence or application of data will lead to damage to our societies.  With this package, we will not only invest money, but also standardize and open up data to our companies. In this way, we give start-ups and SMEs more opportunities to accelerate their development. This means not only better space technologies, but opening up allows us to innovate on everything. This means making agriculture more environmentally friendly with new techniques, making the transport sector cleaner by further optimising transport flows, and also allowing our medical sector to make people better faster. The frontrunners have the best chance of doing this, so with this package we are going to take start-ups and SMEs in Europe a step further. In short: "The sky ain't the limit."

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Club. – Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioners, respected colleagues, I would first, at the outset, thank my colleague Salini and other shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation in reaching compromise solutions to make the European Space Programme a driver of the development of the European space industry, but also of the entire economy of the European Union.  The specific purpose satellites we have in orbit, our network of navigation satellites, not only represents one technological breakthrough compared to the rest of the world, but also one social, social step forward, because that data is open. It is from all the use, about the overwhelming control of our system and what we have managed to fight for, that this system, with increased funding, will also be so in the future.  Satellites, of course, are also an area of innovation, but not only innovations in technologies and hardware, they are an innovation and in the development of various applications and applications that they also bring. Data and information are the greatest value today. A few weeks ago, a publication by the European Network of Regions using space technologies was presented in the European Parliament – 99 examples of how Copernicus data is used in everyday use in our regions. This shows the recognition not only of the regions but also of all those entrepreneurs and economies who have managed to use this data in the right way.  Galileo, as the backbone of our future intelligent transport system, is very important, but I must note that the budget we have provided for the Space European Agency must correlate with the budget we provide to our regions, to be even more successful in using this satellite data.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to add my thanks to Mr Salini, with whom we have worked very well. The report voted on in the ITRE Committee takes into account many of our requests and we are particularly pleased to see the User Fora, which we have proposed, in the text we are about to vote on. User Holes are a crucial tool, the voice of those who use the data provided by satellites. I would, however, like to draw the attention of my fellow Members to a somewhat particular concern, which is subsidence. I have tabled an amendment to include subsidence monitoring among Copernicus' activities. Subsidence, the soil that slowly sinks for natural or human reasons, is a phenomenon that is spreading throughout Europe. Just one example: Venice is threatened by subsidence. Subsidence can cause serious damage to property, infrastructure and agriculture. It is not a well-known problem, because our senses do not warn us of the subsidence in progress, only a satellite can do it. I therefore ask you to vote in favour of our Amendment No 227.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, in conjunction with other key programmes in the field of strengthening the scientific and technological capacity of the European Union, this European space programme is a strategic instrument for political and economic affirmation in the new global framework. The objective of the programme is very meritorious: to integrate the various initiatives and implementation programmes and to give them a new impetus in order to ensure a competitive position of the European Union in the space industries. It involves not only its reference companies, but also knowledge centres and the network of small and medium-sized enterprises with high potential in this area. Commissioner, the development of a network of small and medium-sized enterprises spread across the Territory of the Union and with contributions to the European space strategy is a condition of convergence that is worth betting on. The planned investment, as I said, EUR 16 billion for the European space programme, includes a budget of EUR 9.7 billion for the Galileo programme and EUR 5.8 billion for the Copernicus programme. The remaining 500 million are earmarked for initiatives in the field of satellite government communication and knowledge of the situation in space. These are key initiatives of coordination, integration and supervision, but they are clearly underfunded.  The Union needs all its programmes to be perceived by its citizens for the importance they can have in daily life. In the new technological framework, the scope of the defence of populations and vital interests is wider than that established by the traditional reading of past conflicts and, therefore, establishing a rigid boundary between civil ends and the purposes of protection in the event of conflict is an academic exercise. It is important that the emphasis is not placed on military uses and the report under consideration does not.  However, European citizens should be able to feel that, with these programmes, their economic security, their technological security and also their physical security are strengthened.  And this is also an added value of the integrated approach of this program that we cannot afford to waste.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to join in congratulating my colleague who has followed this report: Mr Salini has done a really good job. With tomorrow's positive vote on this regulation, we will be taking another essential step towards the implementation of an increasingly integrated European space programme, which can guarantee europe's more autonomous, independent and reliable access to space. Many things have already been said and I agree with them. I am particularly pleased with the result achieved in the parliamentary process, although I believe that we must continue to be ambitious in the next legislative steps and in future initiatives, so that Europe can be fully in step with its international competitors. That is why I believe that space diplomacy must play a key role and that it is crucial to enhance the Role of the European Union in the international space scenario, giving full emphasis and support to the excellence achieved in this area. It is important to recognise the importance that spatial data can have in areas such as agriculture, the environment, civil protection, cultural heritage and infrastructure, and I have named only a few. In addition, the space programme must increasingly promote the space economy and enhance the applications and use of data for the benefit of users, European industry and small and medium-sized enterprises, thus promoting growth, employment and all services for European citizens. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to thank Mr Zanonato very much, because he has, of course, also seen that the value chain in space plays an important role.  Now I wanted to ask him: what about small and medium-sized enterprises? Do you see an opportunity for SMEs and SMEs in this area to be more closely involved in the value chain in the future?

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Thank you for that question. Although they are not directly able to manage this part of the potential of the European space programme, it is clear that a whole series of data that are provided are able to favour not only large industry, the industry that bases its activity on research and innovation, but also small and medium-sized industry, which absolutely needs data on which to build its business and projects.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Dear Colleagues, Honourable Mrs Binkovska, the European Space Programme is the answer and is a solution to some of the agricultural issues. In agriculture, there are increasingly acute trends of ageing populations, depopulation and the resulting lack of labour. Also, the technique in a sector with a small profit margin is a big expense. Bureaucracy and on-the-spot checks are also time, expert and resource costs.  All this determines a broader uptake of technology in agriculture, and precise and accurate information is needed for this. One such channel is the use of satellite technology, data and photos. The data collected can be used to monitor biodiversity, land use, the state of agricultural crops and soils, as well as overall rural development.  In this regard, I believe that an increase in targeted funding for Copernicus and GOVSATCOM will help to address the needs of European agriculture. I think the increase could have been even more ambitious, as we had proposed in the Committee on Agriculture, for EUR 18 billion, but I nevertheless support the proposal.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, I had asked for catch-the-eye earlier and thank you for giving me the floor. Space exploration really is progress for civilization itself, for the economy itself. But we must pay attention to two issues: firstly, not to enter the service of the militarisation of space, because this will be a very negative thing, and, secondly, not to enter the service of business profits, because this will also be a direction which will not help space exploration in general. It is certain that we have applications in transport, such as navigation for shipping, roads, satellites, which really play an important role for telecommunications for meteorology and for the rural economy. I think the Galileo system and Copernicus play an important role. The European Space Agency should obviously be strengthened but should always cooperate with the relevant committees and bodies of the Member States.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Honourable Members very much for the discussion. I want to start with one sentence: every one of us needs to know that the European Union’s space sector has recorded a tremendous achievement in this field. This is really something that we should be proud of and we need to repeat this again and again. Our Galileo and Copernicus programmes are the best genuine system in the world and 10% of our newly established start—ups are rooted and have a base in data given by the European Union from those two programmes – almost 10% of newly established start-ups. This is important data and we all need to keep this in mind. The current proposal for the space programme creation is another important milestone in the development of the sector. Let me refer to two points. First, on the overlaps between the European Space Agency and our European Union agency for the space programme in Prague. I want to underline and stress very strongly that there is no overlap in our proposal between the role of those two agencies. Our objective was to clarify precisely the competition between those two agencies and, according to this, to make a very slight adjustment in the governance. We now also have to take the new realities into account of course – Brexit, but also the increasing role of security issues. We are not removing any competition from the European Space Agency. We need to rely on them because they have a lot of genuine and top—quality technical expertise, which is very much needed once the programmes are operational. They need to be managed and be employed by the agency and this will be the European Agency for the space programme in Prague. On the involvement of third countries, we all know that space is about cooperation and that space is global, as one of you said. At the EU level, it is also about cooperation because what we have achieved in our space programme could not have been achieved by any one Member State alone. We understand this, but of course there are some components of our programmes with some essential security elements which are increasing and growing. We must not be naive but must preserve Europe’s strategic interest. We need a kind of flexibility to be on some points strict on the participation of third countries because those security concerns and issues are growing and they take up more and more space in the space programmes. So I want to call on the Parliament to allow us – and allow the space sector – this flexibility through Article 25 of our proposal. These were the two points that I wanted to clarify a little bit, but I think that we can all see what a long way we have come since the first space programme was launched. Parliament has been extremely supportive in this direction and now we must keep this momentum going. This is the most important thing. Our request to you is to have a really constructive and rapid negotiation between the Council, the Commission and Parliament on this really important instrument for European industry, and not only for big companies. This is the most important thing for our start-ups and for our smaller companies, as I explained before. This is important for European citizens – every one of them – and for the European economy. So I very much trust that you will give the mandate to move the proposals to the negotiations tomorrow.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I must say that I strongly agree with the words with which you have initiated this synthesis, this conclusion. We Europeans are the best on the space game, he is absolutely right. The performance of our solutions in the more mature programmes such as Galileo and Copernicus document our absolute leadership capacity for the solutions with which we have occupied the construction of truly important infrastructures in these constellations. Now our big game is about downstream. I am only referring to this point among the many that we have touched. The issue of applications, for example: the use of the benefits of Galileo technology forces us to be rigorous. Today, many of the utilities deriving from the Galileo constellation are exploited by non-European applications. The application geolocation systems that we all have on smartphones refer to applications that are not born in Europe, are born outside Europe, and therefore generate benefits outside Europe, free of charge! They use the services of our constellation and make profits that are not here. You rightly mentioned startups and the many challenges we are winning. Let us also win this one of the downstream and we will have taken that path, thanks to the huge public and private investments that we have generated in recent years within space, we will have made the parable and given Europe one of the programmes that, more than any other, in my opinion more than many others, can convince Europeans of the usefulness of the European Union. The European Union has one of its biggest sponsors in the space programme, and so let us defend it as such.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 13 December 2018.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Angelika Mlinar on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and energy on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Digital Europe programme for the period 2021-2027 (COM(2018)0434 – C8-0256/2018 - 2018/0227 (COD)) (A8-0408/2018).

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I’m very glad to be speaking today as rapporteur for the Digital Europe programme which is in fact the first pan-European programme for digital investment of approximately EUR 9.2 billion that will be deployed within the next multiannual financial framework between 2021 and 2027. First of all, let me thank the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) shadows for the effective, positive and very smooth cooperation we had in committee negotiations. Since the beginning, I very much welcome the Commission proposal as the long-awaited answer to the lack of EU coordination in the digital race with other global competitors such as the US, China and Japan. Member States are multiplying public and private commitments to acquire state-of-the-art technology and to make it easily available for companies as well as for citizens. However, these efforts are too small on a global scale, and they can result in overlapping actions which we cannot allow since resources would be wasted. The EU is a pioneer in research and innovation, but our digital single market witnesses a growing demand for advanced digital products, services and professionals without us having the European capacities to answer it. This programme will focus on five objectives to reinforce the digital transformation, proposing more investment in artificial intelligence, super-computing, cyber security, skills and the spread of technology. Companies, especially SMEs, will be able to approach artificial intelligence and innovative solutions within a framework that preserves our European core values. Researchers and developers in the Union will have easy access to high-performance computers without depending on third countries. In this respect, I would like to remind you that of the top 20 super-computers on this planet, only four of them are at the moment located within the European Union. The European Union needs to count on its own digital serenity when confronted with cybersecurity. We need to catalyse investment to develop within the Union hardware and software applications that ensure a high level of security and also, not to be forgotten, data protection. The programme will also ensure that citizens get the opportunity to acquire advanced digital skills to be able to use the new tools at their disposal, especially in the public administration and public services. As rapporteur, I would like to highlight the key elements that will ensure the success of the programme. We will have in place a network of European digital hubs across Europe that will act as a one-stop shop for our companies to easily benefit from the programme. We will counteract the skills gap in our labour market, offering targeted high-level training to upgrade our professionals’ competences thus unleashing the creation of new job opportunities. And we will promote our European liberal values by prioritising solutions that are fully in line with EU legislation, especially on data protection, that are based on open licensing policies and open standards, and that respect Union ethical principles as we wait for the release of a set of ethical guidelines by the Commission next month.

name: Bogusław SONIK
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab For the Committee on Education and Culture, the Digital Europe Programme is of paramount importance, particularly in terms of strengthening Europe's leading role in the world in terms of digital transformation and impact on European culture. This first Pan-European Digital Programme will benefit not only citizens, but also businesses, cultural and creative sectors. One of the main pillars of the programme is investments aimed at enabling citizens to acquire advanced digital skills enabling them to access and use the latest technologies. Under this programme, employees will have the opportunity to acquire advanced digital skills during long- and short-term training courses and in-service traineeships. This objective is particularly important for the cultural and creative sectors. It also stresses the need to guarantee access to the most advanced technologies and effective digital technologies, from Artificial Intelligence to advanced computing techniques; Synergies between the Digital Europe Programme and all other programmes covered by the Multiannual Financial Framework are also an important point. In view of the ambitious objectives of the programme, it is necessary to guarantee adequate appropriations in the budget. Unfortunately, as a member of the Committee on Culture, I very much regret that the rapporteur has not taken into account one of the most important demands of our committee on the possibility of supporting the Europeana digital library programme from this programme. The digitisation of European works, as europeana has witnessed, provides an important opportunity to improve citizens' access to Europe's cultural heritage.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mrs Angelika Mlinar. Thank you very much for all the work done with the shadow rapporteurs, thank you also for the strong support you have expressed to us. I would like to thank the members of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy for their massive vote in favour of the report on the establishment of the Digital Europe programme for the period 2021-2027. This vote also reflects the importance and necessity of this programme for the future of our citizens, our businesses, and for our European leadership. For the first time, we have proposed in a EU budget a digital programme that puts priorities at the forefront, which are based, on the one hand, on what we have already achieved in the Digital Single Market strategy, but also on a vision, on a very clear ambition to continue together to maximise the benefits of digital transformation. , both for our citizens, our businesses and for the public administrations of the Union. So we have somehow prepared the ground, we have prepared the ground with the establishment of EuroHPC, the joint venture for high-performance computing, with the proposal of a European network of cybersecurity skills centres, as well as with a new centre of expertise for industry, technology and cybersecurity research. This 'Digital Europe' programme is essential. We must act now, without further delay, and give Europe back the tools to ensure our digital leadership. To do this, let us be clear, Member States on their own will not be able to cope with the scale of the changes and investments needed to compete globally. Here, the key word is union. Together, let us put our resources at the service of the common European interest. We can take the reins of this digital transformation and reap the benefits. With this in mind, the Digital Europe programme aims to strengthen digital investments in key areas such as artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, high-performance computing and advanced digital skills - you know how important this topic is to me. But our European approach wants to put new technologies at the service of all our citizens, our businesses and public administrations. The example of the digital innovation cluster network is a good example of how all these benefits must reach all regions and people living in rural and urban areas. Now is the time to take action: we need to significantly increase our investments in the digital future, and this is essential to regain our leadership. At this level, the ambition will not be sufficient, it will be necessary to continue to have broad and solid support, including from a financial point of view. We take note of the fact that today's report indicates that the budget proposed by the Commission should be considered the minimum amount for the Digital Europe programme to aspire to success. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, like you, we are convinced that the 'Digital Europe' programme, the Horizon Europe programme, the mechanism for interconnection in Europe, in synergy and complementarity, will enable us to support and encourage the digital transformation of our European society. It is time to act together, to achieve our goals together and to jointly defend the interests of our citizens, our businesses and our economy.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would particularly like to thank Commissioner Mariya Gabriel very much, because she is constantly setting new initiatives and, of course, it is precisely these initiatives that are important not only for our small and medium-sized enterprises, but above all for our citizens, who are now growing up in the digital world and have to recognise that we can actually reflect the real world in the digital world and that new rules of the game apply in the mirrored digital world. The digital mirrored world has become predictable: with algorithms, with artificial intelligence. That is why we want us to say: OK, what can we do to make this world more transparent?  Of course, we need a mapping of algorithms so that people can understand what activities can be done with algorithms, that we can also explain to younger people who go to school what coding is, that you can learn this in a playful way. We need to see aspirations since the first push, where we discussed roaming, and Pilar del Castillo Vera and Adina-Ioana Vélean, and we have all fought to make the digital single market possible across borders at a reasonable cost.  The truth is that the first Roaming Regulation was the starting signal for the Digital Single Market. I hope that we will have a global digital single market. That is why we should also focus more on new technologies such as blockchain or ledger technologies, because, of course, confidence-building measures in the future will be crucial to whether our children are able to maintain their digital integrity in these systems.  Digital identity is actually the most important thing; these are the ethical principles that we find in the real world, and of course we want to find them in the digital world. I can only support Mrs Mlinar: we must do more here.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Madam President, this programme is about high-performance computing, artificial intelligence, cybersecurity and advanced digital skills, and I think our message is quite simple: we need to reinforce our capacity in these fields. We need to reinforce our capacity and ensure that it is widely used in our economy and our society. I think that was the main message when the European leaders met in Tallinn and it’s also a conclusion that we can widely share in this House. We already have the Digital Single Market, and the programme we’re discussing today has to make sure we get the much-needed investment to match the ambitions of that strategy. It’s already important. If we want the EU to play a role in the digital transformations of the future we need to act today and we need to invest today. Already the demand for new technology is growing at a much faster pace in the EU than the supply. In high-performance computing we see that the lack of adequate resources actually pushes scientists and researchers out of Europe. We have an excellent artificial intelligence community, but it is still underdeveloped compared to other markets. Fragmentation and relatively low public investment in cybersecurity put our society and economy at risk while the European cyber industry remains very fragmented. From the perspective of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), this last point especially is very important. Cybersecurity is critical to both our prosperity and our security. As our daily lives become more and more digital, they also become more and more exposed, and the risks in recent years have grown exponentially. Increasing the trust of citizens and businesses in digital communication, in cybersecurity, is an absolute priority for the EU and I’m very happy that with the report that we will vote on tomorrow, with this programme from our Commissioner, this is exactly what we will do. Thank you all and we look forward to voting on this tomorrow.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I’d like to thank the Commissioner for being here with us today, and thank you very much, too, to the rapporteur – she was an excellent rapporteur and our cooperation with her was excellent. We now have the first ever Digital Europe programme, and this is something we can congratulate ourselves on. This programme, by investing EUR 9.22 billion, will align the next long-term EU budget 2021-2027 with the increasing digital challenges, providing the digital capabilities needed to seize all the opportunities of the digital transformation. Who will the main beneficiaries be? The main beneficiaries will be European companies and especially SMEs, setting a precedent for future initiatives. The key capacities that the programme will focus on concerns high-performance computing, artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, advanced digital skills, and ensuring its wide use and accessibility across the economy and society by businesses and the public sector alike. European SMEs will have the possibility to use our future super-computers to perform their data analysis and to exploit the future AI capacity that will lead to innovative businesses and services. We must not forget that currently the super-computers we use extensively, paying very high fees, are located in third countries. From now on that will be possible here in the European Union. This is a real opportunity to put Europe in the front line of the digital transformation. Now our economy can be the most competitive in the world.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Madam President, Commissioner, the success of the implementation of the programme under discussion today will depend, as I have said to a large extent, the future of the European Union as a shared area of peace, freedom and democracy. As the poet Paul Éluard said, the future is no longer what it was and today, failure to include the technological frontier in areas such as those in which this programme would mean an irreversible social, political and economic backwardness. We must therefore be thoroughly rigorous and determined in defining the priorities, rules and methodologies to be applied. Only a narrowand short-sighted vision can call into question the funding which, although significant, is still small and results from the lack of overall ambition of the European Commission's financial package. €2.7 billion to develop a powerful high-capacity computing network; EUR 2.5 billion to strengthen artificial intelligence skills; EUR 2 billion to develop cybersecurity capabilities; EUR 1.3 billion to ensure digital transformation in public administration, with citizens' access and care of services as a priority; EUR 700 million to develop the necessary skills, so that this information generates a significant volume of new high-quality employment opportunities, we are talking about EUR 9.2 billion. Sounds like a lot of money.  However, when we buy this potential investment with what is foreseen by other major powers, namely the United States, China or Japan, we realize that, after all, it is not an excessive investment, on the contrary, it is a small investment. And it is also because of this differential of financial effort that we have to be particularly strict in implementing the programme. As shadow rapporteur for the Socialists and Democrats, I would like to like to see the excellent work of working with the rapporteur, which I welcome, and the other groups, which has made it possible to give consistency and translate into a report strong ideas, strong ideas which I would like to summarise. Firstly, since Digital Europe is not a programme to develop infrastructure, it needs infrastructure to succeed. It is therefore very important to link this programme with other programmes, such as the Cohesion Funds, Horizon Europe or the Connecting Europe Facility. Secondly, it is very important to set a strong ethical standard in the evaluation of projects funded by the program. Important steps are taken in the report in this direction and must continue to be deepened overall in the context of the European Union. Cooperation with third countries is another key issue and this report provides a balanced, flexible but robust response, setting relationship levels and clear criteria for defining winning partnerships.  It is also important to ensure the dimension of convergence and inclusion associated with the programme. Therefore, the fact that each Member State has at least one innovation and development hub within the Framework of the European Network is an important element of protecting the geographical and territorial balance. Data protection is also a cross-cutting trait to the development matrix of the program's objectives.  We live, Commissioner, Madam President, a time of energy and digital transition that is a technological revolution. A revolution must always be guided by values and must have the interests of citizens as a watermark of its development. Deepening inequalities, the perception of injustice and the fear of change have been driving citizens away from the European project. Digital Europe must be a connection program and not an exclusion programme. This week, as the Commissioner well knows, the first 2 800 European municipalities that will have guaranteed high-quality connections in their public spaces under the Wifi4you initiative were known. There were 2,800 municipalities selected from 13,000 local territories.  The Digital Europe programme must be able to feed the new European network of services for citizens and the defence of those citizens; it has to be the embryo of a differentiated digital identity based on our common values. This will also be the measure of your success or failure. We all, who believe in this project of peace and freedom that is the European Union, to cooperate to make a lot happen with the resources we have, mobilizing civil society and European companies to this key strategic challenge, the challenge, after all, of putting the technological and digital revolution at the service of people, the decentrality of the planet, justice and quality of life.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to join in congratulating previous speakers and also on the comments on the importance of this programme. Perhaps the funds are not as large as they seem. I would also like to point out one thing: in the past, a society and an economy have been built so many times on the basis of certain technological innovations and too often the side effects have not been prevented. Even in the transition to digital we have side effects that are already manifesting themselves in our societies, given that there are some problems such as the degradation of psychosensory balance, cognitive and emotional fragmentation, chronic distraction, especially in children and adolescents – there is already a wide medical and scientific literature – these are problems that will increase with the inevitable transition to digital , which is also a good thing.  Then maybe we should also start taking precautions. We have tabled amendments on this subject, because prevention is always better than cure and go back, then it is very difficult. I count on your wisdom.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Dear Madam President, Honourable Mrs Gabriel, honourable Members, I am pleased to see that in the next multiannual financial framework investment in digital skills is a horizontal priority. We must not forget that within the European Union 70 million Europeans do not have basic digital skills. In the world of fast-growing technologies, the mastery of basic skills is proving to be extremely insufficient. In this sense, the new Digital Europe programme sets the right direction, defining as one of its main objectives the development of advanced digital skills. I think the budget of the programme is ambitious enough.  However, I am of the opinion that more balance is needed in allocating funds to individual items. I share the view that the target resource for advanced digital skills is extremely insufficient. Financial support under this strand must represent at least 12 % of the total budget. I believe that the mistake in which huge funds for digitisation should not be made again, while at the same time people do not have the necessary skills to use advanced technologies. As regards the digital innovation hubs, which will play a key role in the implementation of the programme, I believe that, in addition to respecting the geographical principle of their allocation, preference must be enjoyed by poorer and sparsely populated areas in the Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the digital economy really is the future of Europe, because that way competitiveness can be strengthened. A competitiveness that has been wrong for many years in the European Union has been based on the Chineseisation of wages. Fortunately, they have recently realised that they need to invest in the digital economy, in new technologies. But, in order to make an investment, there must be a comfort in public investment. But how will there be public investment when the Stability Pact creates certain problems and limits the Member States themselves to the possibility of making funds available? So here you have to make sure that there is an exception, that it does not count in the deficit, when there is investment in the digital economy and especially when it is an investment in order to have opportunities to develop the digital economy. At the same time, we must also look at it from the central bank's point of view, because Mr Draghi bought bonds from companies that have not invested in the digital economy. These are simple things that we need to see, because the funds invested, what you mention in the programme, are not enough, so we need to find other ways of financing.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, first of all, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for the strong support you have expressed. The European Parliament has always supported European citizens, European businesses, small and medium-sized enterprises as well as our European champions. The man at the centre of our digital policy, the man in charge, our values, ethical issues, our researchers, our young people, but also rural areas, vulnerable people, all these keywords were words you put forward and they are at the heart of the digital Europe programme.  We can take them to the next level if we join forces, and with this first pan-European digital programme we are sending strong messages to our citizens: we would like to support you in this digital transition, we would like to retain our talents. That is why, in the program, we have advanced digital skills. These are not basic digital skills, beware, we will continue to ensure that there are complementarities in other parts of the budget. We send a strong message to our companies: we believe in you, we would like to see our European champions grow. And we are sending a very strong message to our international partners: Europe is lagging behind, but it has strong assets, from scientific research to industry sectors, to get back in the race. It is now time to move quickly to the inter-institutional negotiations and to continue to work hard to make the Digital Europe programme operational and beneficial to citizens and our businesses. Thank you all so much for your work. The Commission remains at your disposal so that the negotiations can be concluded as soon as possible.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commissioner and all her staff because they have been extremely helpful from the outset, and we hope to continue in that way in the future. Thank you also to my colleagues for the constructive comments they have made and for the cooperative, to-the-point approach in this debate. As the Commissioner mentioned, I would like to remind everyone that the lead committee voted on the report with a large majority – 57 votes in favour, only 2 against and 3 abstentions – and I would ask the House to vote tomorrow in line with this outcome, thus enabling us to keep the balance that has been reached among all the political groups involved. I’m eager to start the negotiations with our co-legislator and I wish to work with the incoming Romanian Presidency in the same positive and efficient spirit that has prevailed so far. On a final note, regarding the programme’s financial envelope, I have taken the path of being quite a pragmatic rapporteur and I did not table any amendments to the Commission’s proposed budget. That approach was also shared by my shadow rapporteurs. I consider that the novelty of the programme will be a key factor in the negotiations on the overall EU budget, and therefore I will advocate keeping the proposed EUR 9.2 billion as a minimum acceptable amount consistent with the programme’s needs and ambitions. If we start reducing it, we will get into problems. I’m aware that, most probably, we will not be finalising the Multiannual Financial Framework within this parliamentary term: however, let’s keep this in mind in order to have a successful programme in place for the years to come. (Applause)

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 13 December 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – It was already time not only to recognise the potential of new technologies and how they can move forward Europe’s economy, but also to take action for it to happen. The Programme focuses on five areas – AI, supercomputers, cybersecurity, digital skills and digital transformation of public administration – where the funding should go. I support the Commission’s ambition to finally establish such a programme but the proposed amount of EUR 9.1 billion rather limits its ambition. For example, for AI an allocation of EUR 2.5 billion is planned for 2021-2027 to boost Europe’s economy and enhance society, and help Europe in the AI race with the US and China.  I believe that unfortunately it will be rather difficult for Europe to become the front runner knowing that the US and China have already invested billions in AI and are planning to continue. By 2030 China plans to build an USD 1 trillion AI industry. Europe needs a clear vision and a common European industrial policy on AI, so the allocation of funds would be successful. Also, I welcome the allocation of funds for digital skills which is crucial for Europe due to an already existing shortage of qualified people in ICT.

name: Czesław HOC
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Digital Europe Programme 2021-2027 is an important element of the broadly understood foundation for the sphere that already surrounds us and which will be increasingly important for everyone every year. The digital world permeates many levels of our lives, from the cultural area, to health, education or even cybersecurity. That is why we need to make the most of the resources that this programme sets out so that Europeans are prepared to live in this digital reality that the world has not yet fully known. We must be competitive on the global stage in this area so as not to lag behind other continents. However, we must bear in particular mind the values and that it is man who is the beneficiary of the digital world, not his victim or slave. This is a sine qua non condition – the development of this area of our lives must not exclude anyone, especially the elderly or the difficult access to the benefits of the digital world.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – The overall objective of the Digital Europe Programme should be to support the transformation of the digital industry. Better use of the industrial potential of innovation, research and development policy instruments for the benefit of businesses and citizens across the Union should also be encouraged. The rapporteur rightly notes that this is inevitable in order for Europe to keep pace with the rapid industrial and digital revolution and to ensure that we can ensure proper preparedness for our economy and society. It is essential to ensure Europe's competitiveness and smart, inclusive and sustainable growth. In order to create a well-functioning digital single market for europe as a whole, certain basic preconditions should be fulfilled in all Member States. The lack of digital service infrastructure and capacity still hampers the development of smooth cross-border services. The Union and its programmes should support and allocate adequate funds to fulfil the basic preconditions and the establishment of digital service infrastructure. The start should be made for the analysis of the missing interfaces, functions and attributes needed for digital services and their deployment on a large scale at local, national and European level, covering all sectors of the European economy. Cybersecurity is a challenge for the union as a whole, which can no longer be tackled by fragmented national initiatives alone. Europe's cybersecurity capabilities should be strengthened, especially in the context of the financial sector.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Before concluding the sitting here, I would like to thank all the people who have worked here, including the interpreters, for their excellent work, because this is the last night session of this Parliament this year 2018. All these people ensure that we can make good decisions. I hope that we will again take good decisions tomorrow, and that is my end of the sitting. (The sitting was closed at 10.46 p.m.)
